Intercut scenes capture Walker, frozen in place, watching the inevitable onslaught as the British police commanding officer, struggling to control his emotions, gives the first order.

Back in shadows, Irwin sits behind his desk, still in shock, staring at Gandhi. He faces Gandhi stiffly.

The sound of a camera whirring transitions to a wide, slightly under-cranked screen reminiscent of old newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are seen waving goodbye from the deck of their departing ship. Mirabehn holds the tether of a goat, and all three smile at the camera, embodying the spirit of voyagers everywhere.
154:
In the East End of London, a jubilant crowd greets Mahatma Gandhi as he stands on the steps of Kingsley Hall. By his side, the gray-haired Charlie Andrews radiates a possessive pride. Transitioning scenes, Gandhi, clad in his traditional dhoti, waves to a smaller crowd while entering the gates of Buckingham Palace. He then takes his place at a conference table surrounded by formally and elaborately dressed delegates, including some Maharajahs. The session begins with the sound of a gavel, followed by Ramsay MacDonald's opening address in his white suit and black-ribboned pince-nez.

In another setting, Gandhi sits in a wicker chair with Nehru and Patel leaning against a railing, while Azad and Kripalani sit on the floor as Gandhi does. As the meeting concludes, Gandhi rises and begins to move towards the steps. He pauses to exchange a wry, gentle smile with Patel before looking over at Jinnah and shrugging dismissively. Jinnah, visibly less philosophical, watches with burning anger as Gandhi approaches a young girl with an injured goat.

The scene shifts to Gandhi walking amidst a stream of passengers exiting the Third Class section of a train. Struggling behind him are Ba and Mirabehn, with Desai and Pyarelal completing their small group. At the station, a British captain stands before a platoon of Indian troops. As Gandhi nears, a British Lt. Colonel and his Adjutant, a Captain, step forward from the ranks. Gandhi, looking up at them and then at the troops, shakes his head with a weary grin. The Colonel signals to his troops, and as a detail approaches, the adjutant speaks gently to Ba, who responds with a belligerent stare, leaving the adjutant flummoxed.

The Colonel and his adjutant then stride toward the station's exit, followed by a detail of six soldiers accompanying Gandhi. The camera follows, revealing another detail of six soldiers accompanying Ba, and yet another with Mirabehn.

Switching scenes, a jeep driven by an American lieutenant with Margaret Bourke-White, dressed in an American War Correspondent's uniform, bounces along a road. As they pass the camera, it pans to reveal the walls of a palace ahead. Bourke-White absorbs the sight, her gaze intense, driven by both professional curiosity and personal sensitivity.

The final scene shows Gandhi seated by a window, its grillwork substituting for bars, spinning in a shaft of light. His focus drifts as the sound of a camera clicking and the rustle of movement are heard. His hair, once half-gray in London, is now fully white, marking the passage of time and the weight of his experiences.
158:
Gandhi, accompanied by Nehru and Azad, advances forward with Pyarelal closely following behind them. Earlier, Azad and Pyarelal had emerged onto the porch behind Nehru. As Gandhi approaches a car, a Hindu youth brandishing a black flag calls out to him. The group is struck with awe and a sense of timidity in Gandhi's presence, transforming the atmosphere of their gathering entirely. Gandhi's gaze sweeps over the youth and the line of others standing there, his stern look betraying his fatigue and strain. Lowering his head, he proceeds to the car where Kallenbach is ready at the door to assist him, followed by Nehru, Azad, and Pyarelal. As they enter the vehicle, the car is parked next to two trucks that had transported the youths. In the back seat, two men are visible, one of them being Prakash, who would later be present at Gandhi's assassination.

Meanwhile, Jinnah stands on a small balcony of a grand room, gazing down slightly superciliously. He is, as always, impeccably dressed. From his vantage point, he observes Gandhi sitting on the floor of a spacious room, just lifting his head from prayer. Nearby, Nehru, Patel, and Azad also occupy the same side of the room as Gandhi and rise from their prayers as Jinnah descends the steps toward them. Gandhi hesitates before starting to speak, while Jinnah straightens himself, his vanity visibly stirred by the prospect. Jinnah studies Gandhi momentarily to gauge his sincerity, and once convinced, he slowly turns his attention to Nehru, Patel, and Azad. Nehru exchanges a glance with Patel, both surprised by the offer and lacking the sentiment that Gandhi holds. Nehru looks hesitantly at Gandhi, the truth of the situation undeniable. Gandhi’s eyes droop in despair, reflecting the collapse of his last hope and faith.

The scene shifts to a platform where Mountbatten and Nehru stand in the foreground. A band plays the Indian National Anthem with vigor as a massive crowd roars in response to the raising of India's green, white, and saffron flag on the flagpole. On another occasion, Jinnah and a British plenipotentiary are on a platform, with a band playing Pakistan's new national anthem loudly. The crowd responds with thunderous applause as Pakistan's flag, white and green with a white crescent, is hoisted up the flagpole. Later, a small flagpole stands empty, its rope dangling and flapping loosely.

Gandhi is seen sitting alone on the porch of his bungalow, engrossed in spinning. The gentle hum of his spinning wheel fills the air. Inside the house, Mirabehn can just be seen, also spinning, but the rest of the ashram appears deserted, leaving Gandhi in solitude.
161:
The camera sweeps over a large, lively crowd, passing by loudspeakers mounted on poles. Amidst the throng, groups of surly, young rowdies linger at the edges, while the camera glides over the heads of the attentive audience towards a stage where Nehru is delivering a speech. Seated on the floor behind him are Azad, Suhrawardy, and others.

In another scene, Suhrawardy, a prominent Muslim leader, is seen leaning against a wall, his body tense as he observes an unseen action with evident strain. Nearby, five men, dressed in black trousers and vests, confront Gandhi. Their muscular arms are adorned with thongs, accentuating their strength, and despite the dirtiness of their attire and themselves, they lay down their weapons—knives and guns—at Gandhi's feet. From a rooftop, Mirabehn, Azad, Pyarelal, the doctor, and others watch this unfolding event, a mix of fascination and fear evident on their faces.

Gandhi, intensely focused, scrutinizes these men, refusing to accept any superficial gestures. As the men, known as Goondas, stand to leave, they glance towards Suhrawardy, who offers them a tight smile. They begin to depart, but one man, Nahari, hesitates. Suddenly, Nahari lunges towards Gandhi, pulling a piece of flat Indian bread (chapati) from his trousers and forcefully throwing it at Gandhi. Mirabehn and Azad instinctively move towards Nahari, who appears incredibly strong and unpredictably unstable. However, Gandhi, with a trembling hand, signals them to stop.

Nahari's face is a twisted mask of emotion, blending anger and a childlike fear, yet there's an undeniable menacing instability in his demeanor. Gandhi, seemingly understanding Nahari's inner turmoil, stares at him breathlessly, as if Nahari has revealed a deep, self-inflicted wound. Reflexively, Gandhi gestures to the height of his son, then locks eyes with Suhrawardy before returning his gaze to Nahari, who is now sobbing angrily, as if contemplating harming Gandhi in revenge. For a long moment, Gandhi confronts Nahari's pain and rage.

Despite sneering, a flicker of desperate curiosity crosses Nahari's face. Gandhi responds by raising his hand to the height Nahari had indicated for his son. Nahari listens, his face showing a brief moment of possible redemption, though it does not fully dispel his inner darkness. Light now focuses on Nahari, whose face stiffens as he struggles to suppress his emotions. He turns to leave but manages only a step before turning back, collapsing to his knees, and sobbing uncontrollably as he bows his head to Gandhi's feet in a traditional Hindu gesture symbolizing a son's respect for his father. Gandhi, after a moment, reaches out and touches the top of Nahari's head in a gesture of acceptance and peace.

Meanwhile, nearby, trucks filled with riot squads equipped with shields and truncheons are present but remain passive, simply waiting.
164:
In the midst of a tumultuous scene, a woman struggles to break free, but a constable grips her firmly. Amidst the chaos, the sergeant turns his attention away from the disturbance to witness Gandhi, blood trickling from his head, struggling back to his knees. Gandhi reaches for another card, and the crowd, along with a newspaper reporter, watches intently. Ba, overwhelmed with anguish, observes as Gandhi lifts the card. The sergeant, though visibly angry, manages to keep his emotions somewhat under control, yet after a brief hesitation, Gandhi drops the card into a basket. Despite nearly stopping, the sergeant strikes Gandhi again, a flicker of distaste at his own actions crossing his face as Gandhi sags. Ba's tears flow freely, reflecting her deep distress, while the reporter continues to observe without jotting down notes. Khan, positioned near the paddy wagon, watches in awe. Gandhi, now bleeding profusely from his head, rises to his knees once more, gasping for breath, and fumbles for another card. His fingers finally grasp one. The sergeant, his face a mask of confusion and uncertainty, watches as Gandhi, with painful effort, lifts the card and holds it over the fire before dropping it into the basket. The sergeant reluctantly strikes again with his billy club, showing a clear hesitation. The crowd holds its breath, and the reporter remains fixated. The sergeant, taking a deep breath while gripping the club, bites his lip as he sees Gandhi, feebly lifting his head, his trembling hands stained with his own blood, reaching for yet another card.

Later, in a gas-lit, overly furnished Victorian room, Ba gently helps Gandhi remove his suit coat, her eyes filled with fear as she looks at the bandages on his head and along the side of his face. Gandhi sits cautiously on the bed, where several newspapers, some in English, are spread out. Ba reaches out tenderly to touch the bandages on Gandhi's head. Before Gandhi can respond, there's a knock at the door. A proud, small, round ayah enters, leading Gandhi's sons—Harilal (ten), Manilal (six), and Ramdas (two)—into the room. All the boys are dressed in European suits, complete with ties and stiff collars. They approach Gandhi one by one, performing the pranam, a Hindu greeting, and then bend to touch his feet in traditional filial respect. Gandhi smiles warmly at them. Ramdas rushes to him, and Gandhi bends down to kiss him as the young boy wraps his arms around his neck. The boys, accustomed to household discipline, bow and exit the room in an orderly fashion. The ayah closes the door behind them, and their chatter can be heard fading down the hall. Gandhi stretches out on the bed and picks up another newspaper. Ba sits beside him, adjusting her position to attend to his bandage.
167:
In a tense moment, a man and a woman lock eyes, their mutual anger palpable. As she attempts to stand, he seizes her arm, only for her to break free assertively. She speaks to him with derision, her words striking him deeply, though he remains conscious of another man's presence and struggles to control his temper. Defiantly, she settles back into her seat. They exchange resentful stares before he suddenly reaches for her arm again, yanking her to her feet with force. In a hushed yet violent confrontation, he drags her towards the rear door, opens it, and tries to push her out as she resists fiercely. Following this, he gazes at her breathlessly, his anger giving way to dazed remorse. He then sinks onto a stool, overwhelmed, cradling his head in his hands. Observing him, she sighs as her own anger and breath calm down. She moves to kneel before him, soothingly stroking the top of his head, embodying the nurturing role of a mother and wife. He looks up at her, his expression blank and filled with regret. A weak grin crosses his face, which she returns with a warmer, less conflicted smile. He sighs, embracing her as she leans into him, their heads touching in a moment of reconciliation. He holds her at arm's length to look at her directly, meeting her steady, warm gaze devoid of a smile.

The scene shifts to a theater bustling with an audience. The front rows are occupied by wealthy Muslim merchants, while small traders, peddlers, and artisans of various faiths including Muslim, Hindu, Parsee, and Sikh fill the back of the stalls. The gallery overflows with indentured laborers, predominantly Hindu, contributing to a restless and belligerent atmosphere. As the protagonist steps forward, he signals for silence with a raised hand. On the stage sit Khan, Singh, and three other leaders from the Indian community, with Charlie Andrews and Herman Kallenbach at the end of the row of chairs. From his viewpoint, the protagonist surveys the packed audience, his gaze landing on two conspicuous plainclothes European policemen seated at the end of the front row, accompanied by a uniformed officer. A buzz fills the air, erupting into loud, defiant applause. As it fades, the protagonist fixes his gaze on the policemen. The audience erupts into applause once more, but the policemen remain impassive, seemingly unaffected by the rhetoric. A rhythmic pounding from the gallery, signaling anger and protest, spreads throughout the hall. Amidst this, the police maintain an imperturbable stare. Khan leans towards Singh, acknowledging the protagonist's presence with a nod, and Singh responds with a smile at the subtlety of the gesture. The protagonist again raises his hand, quieting the hall. Suddenly, a large, powerful merchant in the third row stands up, indicating a violent response is imminent.
170:
The film begins at a vibrant strip before transitioning to the bustling Mesas Casino. The scene then shifts to Epcot Center where the protagonist, Chili, stands alongside Fay. Inside an office, Chili sits across from Dick Allen, who is adorned in lots of jewelry with a giant neon cowgirl visible through the window behind him. Dick returns a snapshot to Chili, who then turns his attention to a minivan outside, staring at it intently. 

Amidst the rain, Chili gives the bus driver a stern look before exiting the vehicle. Left standing in the downpour, his seat gets wet as he has nowhere to go. The camera pans to a house where all the lights are off except for the blue glow of a television emanating from a downstairs room. Inside, a figure stirs and rolls over, revealing Harry Zimm, a balding, overweight movie producer. Harry sits up, grunts, and gets out of bed. A woman nearby looks at him as he peers out the window and begins searching the room for his clothes. 

A familiar voice catches Harry's attention, prompting him to listen at the door. He then crosses the entry hall of his nice home, drawn towards the flickering light of the television from another room. As Harry steps into the glow of a large Sony TV, the rest of the room remains shrouded in darkness. On the screen, Dave is interviewing actor Martin Weir until suddenly the screen goes black and the desk lamp illuminates the room, causing Harry to jump in surprise.

Chili emerges from the shadows, leaning into the light and speaking quietly and calmly. Harry, startled, presses a hand against his chest, then slides it down over his belly, taking his time to show he has regained composure. He stares back at Chili, trying to figure out who he is. Chili nods, almost smiles, as Harry slowly brings his hand down. Harry reaches for the phone, dialing '0', but Chili leans forward, hangs up the phone with his index finger, and casually reaches for the receiver. 

Harry sits down and starts to take another drink but pauses, looking at Chili, who shakes his head with a more thoughtful and curious expression. Chili nods again and leans forward on the desk. Their conversation escalates in volume as Karen descends the stairs. Chili and Harry are now seated at a butcher block table with a bottle of Dewars and glasses between them. 

As Chili turns around, he spots Karen standing in the doorway, her arms folded across her chest and wearing a Lakers T-shirt that barely covers her crotch. The atmosphere becomes tense as Leo grows visibly uncomfortable. As Leo motions for another drink, a plane taxis past the window behind him, and his head drops to the table. A massive fireball erupts in the background.

The scene shifts to Fay, who reacts dramatically as an FFA guy points to a little green hat on one of the tables. She grabs the hat, clutches it to her chest, and pretends to faint.
171:
As Karen reluctantly listens, a man escalates a deal from three hundred thousand to half a million dollars. Chili begins to speak, but Harry interrupts him. Harry then turns back to Chili, who notices Karen staring at him with a patient gaze. Karen shifts her attention to the two men sitting together as both Harry and Chili look at her. She meets Chili's gaze briefly before turning away and exiting the room, with Chili watching her departure. Harry nods thoughtfully before glancing at Chili again.

The camera pans up to show a young child engrossed with a walkman. Harry gestures toward the Cafe Med across the street, where a red Ferrari convertible is parked. Inside the cafe, Martin Weir and a woman with jet-black hair sit at a table, observed by Harry and Chili for a moment. As they continue their journey, Harry starts driving again.

In another scene, Chili peruses old photographs of Karen and a younger, blonde version of her with Harry. Amidst the clutter on the desk, Harry hands a movie script to Chili, who examines it curiously—it's his first time handling such a document. He flips it open to the middle and then tosses it back onto the desk, moving between a pair of plush red leather chairs. As Harry steps away from the window, he tugs on a string to lower the blinds behind the desk.

The sound of Ronnie singing fills the air just as the door opens, revealing Bo Catlett and Ronnie entering the office, guided by the Bear. Chili watches from behind the desk as they approach, with Catlett entering first. Ronnie takes a seat in one of the worn red leather chairs facing the desk, nonchalantly hooking one leg over the armrest and swinging it, clearly under the influence of some substance. Harry ushers them into their seats, but Chili, sitting down, ignores Harry's nod. Harry, seemingly forgetting his earlier instructions, leaves Chili in disbelief. Another man also fixates on Chili, who shakes his head, stunned at what he's hearing. Outside, men in a long black stretch limo nod at Chili, who returns the gesture while attempting to catch Harry's eye. Ronnie and Bo Catlett notice the exchange.

Tension mounts as Catlett locks eyes with Chili again, the situation intensifying between them. A man scrutinizes Chili, contemplating his next move, when Harry intervenes, reaching over the desk to pick up the script. Chili looks at Harry, pondering if there's a way to silence him without resorting to violence.
173:
He pauses, gazing at her intently before resuming his walk. They halt at her car, and he remains there, observing as she drives off. A plane descends onto the runway as he stands before a row of lockers, fixated on one in particular. The camera moves in closer, and he starts towards it but then shifts his attention elsewhere.

The camera swiftly focuses downward to reveal a bulge near a woman's ankle, dressed casually in slacks and a blouse, tapping to an inaudible beat, with a similar bulge noticeable near a man's ankle. He ignites a cigarette, his gaze freezing as it drifts off-screen.

Yayo, drenched in sweat, leans against a railing and exchanges a confident, accomplished glance with the Bear. Bo Catlett, leaning on the same railing, looks down at Yayo once more. Bear's eyes meet his.

Chili indicates a star on a map. Both turn their attention to the entrance where a tall, slender woman with wild, jet-black hair stands. As Karen begins to respond, Nicki briskly ushers Chili inside, where he examines the photographs adorning the walls, predominantly featuring Martin. A vast backyard is visible in the distance, and this sight somehow eases Karen's tension. Chili follows her line of sight, and they watch as someone hugs her tightly, leaving Nicki and Chili awkwardly standing aside. Karen struggles to suppress a smile while Nicki nods gravely. Meanwhile, a gardener is busy clearing leaves.

The walls are lined with Martin's extensive photography collection, displayed in cracked oils. Martin, Karen, and Chili sit on white couches. Martin scrutinizes Karen and nods thoughtfully before withdrawing his hand, lost in contemplation. Karen looks nauseated, on the verge of giving up, yet Martin amuses himself with his own antics. Karen and Chili join in the laughter, with Karen leaning closer to Chili. Chili observes as the movie star adopts a hunched posture and narrows his shoulders, yet his gaze remains fixed on Martin.

Karen shakes her head, her gaze briefly turning away as she fights a smile. She watches Martin, whose expression slowly shifts to a deadpan, sleepy look directed at Chili. Martin nods and gives Chili a chilling, emotionless stare. Chili shares a meaningful look with Karen, who relaxes back into her seat, clearly entertained by Chili's adept manipulation of Martin. Chili leans back, and Karen, increasingly amused by Chili's handling of the situation, looks from Martin to Chili and back to Martin, shaking her head once more. Martin's attention then shifts to Chili.

Finally, Harry looks up to see Bo Catlett, impeccably dressed as always, standing alongside the Bear, who sports a Hawaiian shirt.
175:
The movie opens with the Black Guy holding his open I.D. folder. As Ray Bones exits, another gate reveals two large men in sunglasses escorting a smaller, older individual. The smaller man glances back, offering a smile to someone behind him. Meanwhile, two agents exchange a glance, maintaining a neutral expression. Chili ascends from the stairwell, prompting the man to stand up straighter as Chili approaches. Chili sizes up the man, sensing either ignorance or an attempt at casual talk. The Bear, maintaining a silent gaze, watches Chili intently, his stare unbroken even as he nods, his eyes briefly closing and reopening.

Harry, roused from sleep with his hair tousled, is startled as Ray Bones enters his office. Quickly sitting up, Harry nearly loses control of his bladder as Bones saunters in. Trying to regain composure using Chili's advice, Harry gestures towards the red leather chair across his desk. As Ray Bones takes a seat, Harry moves to the blinds and pulls them open, only to find no glare due to the setting sun. Ray comments on the beautiful red sunset, and Harry, feeling the situation deteriorating, forces a smile as he sits at his desk, anticipating further trouble.

In another scene, Bo Catlett is engaged in a phone call from behind his large wooden desk. The Bear appears slightly hunched over. As a car arrives in the garage, Bo Catlett glances towards the outer office. He ends his call and rises as three men, cloaked in dark sunglasses, emerge from the vehicle. It becomes clear that one of the men, an older Latino named Mr. Escobar, is flanked by two younger bodyguards. Escobar steps confidently into Bo's office. Simultaneously, the limo's back doors close, revealing Bo Catlett seated between the two unyielding bodyguards, facing Escobar across from him. Escobar scrutinizes Bo for a moment, causing Bo to tense up slightly before shrugging nonchalantly. Bo barely acknowledges the bodyguards, flashing a gleaming smile towards Escobar.

Elsewhere, Ronnie maneuvers erratically through traffic, casting challenging looks at other drivers. On his carphone, Bo Catlett continues his conversation. Back in Harry's office, Ray Bones leans forward, having heard similar remarks before. With a shake of his head, Bones stands, pulling black leather gloves from his pocket and circling the desk. Seizing Harry by the hair, Bones lifts him and hurls him across the room, crashing into a wall adorned with pictures, many of which dislodge and tumble onto Harry as Bones unleashes a brutal assault.
178:
Laurie stands beside the telephone, lost in thought. With a casual shrug, she turns away from the window and strides back towards Tommy and Lindsey, who are seated comfortably on the couch.

In another room, the only source of light comes from a flickering candle that casts a gentle glow over the bed sheets, which rhythmically rise and fall, swaying side to side. Empty beer cans form a trail leading from the door to this bed, where the intimate moment between Bob and Lynda suddenly halts. Lynda, with her hair disheveled and a look of frustration on her face, is pushed down onto the bed by Bob. The camera slowly pulls back from their entwined figures on the bed, retreating through the bedroom doorway, revealing THE SHAPE standing ominously in the darkness, observing them silently. Eventually, Bob and Lynda reach their climax; Bob then rolls off her. Lynda, still in bed, lights a cigarette and passes it to Bob before lighting one for herself. After a moment, Bob gets up and leaves the room, leaving Lynda to smile contentedly to herself as she leans back against the pillows.

Bob makes his way through the swinging doors into the kitchen. He opens the refrigerator, grabs two beers, and then gathers some food and the beers into his arms. As he surveys the kitchen, he discovers a can of peanuts in another cupboard. Bob steps to the door to check outside; the yard is deserted except for the wind rustling the trees. He closes the doors, but then freezes as he stares at them. Curiosity getting the better of him, he walks to one of the doors, opens it, and turns away. He then approaches the other door and opens it as well. Right behind this door, THE SHAPE, donning a rubber mask, lunges forward, grabbing Bob firmly around the neck. Despite Bob's attempt to break free, THE SHAPE's grip is unyielding, causing Bob to cough and gag under the pressure. With a swift motion, THE SHAPE lifts Bob off the floor, his feet dangling helplessly. A guttural sound escapes Bob as THE SHAPE's hand tightens around his windpipe. Still holding Bob up with one hand, THE SHAPE forcefully slams him against the wall, suspending him several feet off the ground. Bob struggles in vain as THE SHAPE raises his other hand, revealing a butcher knife. With a powerful thrust, THE SHAPE drives the knife deep into Bob's chest, the blade penetrating through to the other side and embedding into the wall with a resounding thud. After this brutal act, THE SHAPE steps back, leaving Bob impaled on the wall, his eyes wide open in horror, lifeless.

Meanwhile, Lynda remains in bed, nonchalantly smoking another cigarette. She hears someone entering the room but doesn't bother to look up, assuming it's Bob. However, it's THE SHAPE standing in the doorway. Mistaking him for a ghost due to his mask, Lynda looks at him and tries to engage, but receives no response. She playfully slides the sheets down from her body, laughing at her own jest, but her laughter quickly dies as she notices the figure's stillness. Turning around to look more closely, she sees THE SHAPE just standing there, unmoving and silent.
179:
Lynda rises from her bed, her nude form bathed in the sensuous glow of candlelight. She moves gracefully to the phone. As she begins to dial, a ghostly figure appears in the doorway and advances toward her. The shape continues its approach as Lynda presses the phone to her ear.

Meanwhile, Laurie sits on the couch, engaged in knitting. She rises to answer the ringing phone. As Lynda listens, the ghost reaches her from behind and seizes the phone, disrupting the call. The ghost then violently wraps the telephone cord around Lynda's neck. She struggles fiercely, squirming and writhing as the ghost tightens the cord, cutting off her air. In desperation, Lynda gasps and attempts to scream, pulling at the sheet that covers her assailant. The sheet slips away, revealing a grotesque Halloween mask beneath. The ghost pulls the cord even tighter, and Lynda, fighting for breath, slumps forward and becomes still.

On the other end of the line, Laurie hears the disturbing sounds of squeals and rustling, which continue to echo through the phone until it suddenly goes silent. Puzzled, Laurie hangs up and crosses to the window, peering out toward the Wallace house. The street outside is quiet, dark, and windy, with Bob's car parked in front. Laurie, concerned, returns to the phone and dials Annie's number. After a moment of consideration, she finally hangs up the phone and heads upstairs. There, she checks on Tommy and Lindsey, who are sound asleep on the bed. She watches them briefly before closing the door and leaving them to their rest.

Elsewhere, Loomis sits silently behind a hedge, keeping watch over the Myers house. After a moment of contemplation, he rises and starts walking down the quiet residential street. As he turns away, he notices the street is nearly empty, save for a distant station wagon. A sudden thought strikes him, prompting him to look again. Frustrated, he approaches the vehicle. As he walks, the station wagon becomes more visible, and he recognizes it, breaking into a run toward it. The camera focuses on the state emblem emblazoned on its side. Standing by his car, Loomis scans the empty street, deciding quickly to move forward almost running, his eyes darting back and forth, searching the rows of houses for any sign of something amiss.
181:
Laurie stands frozen, horror etched on her face as she gazes upon her deceased friend. Gradually, our vision adjusts to the dimness, revealing the silhouette of a man standing ominously behind her. This shadowy figure becomes increasingly distinct, prompting Laurie to hastily retreat from the corner. Suddenly, the shape aggressively thrusts forward towards her, brandishing a knife and lunging multiple times with menacing intent. He brandishes a piece of fabric—her blouse—rips it violently, and then slashes her arm with the blade, causing her flesh to tear as she emits a piercing scream and whirls around in panic.

Stumbling backward, Laurie collides with a railing, desperately attempting to evade the blade's arc. In her frantic escape, she slips over the edge of the railing, and the camera captures her terrifying descent as it crashes to the floor. Accompanied by her screams, Laurie backs away, eventually hitting the ground, rolling over, and clutching her leg in pain. The assailant, masked and wielding a gleaming butcher knife, advances from the staircase towards her.

Gathering her strength, Laurie pulls herself off the floor and hobbles into the living room, with the shape swiftly pursuing her down the stairs. She makes her way to the kitchen, crawling inside and slamming the door shut behind her before swiftly locking it. Spotting a window over the sink, Laurie slowly rises and limps towards the back door. Her hand fumbles with the door handle, her desperation palpable as she repeatedly tries to open it, constantly looking over her shoulder.

A loud pounding erupts on the door from the other side. Suddenly, the kitchen door explodes, its middle section shattering. The shape's hand reaches through, fumbling for the lock before successfully unlatching it. He forcefully pushes the door open and leaps into the kitchen. Meanwhile, Laurie manages to open the window halfway, then three-fourths, and drags herself out, landing roughly on the ground outside.

Picking herself up, Laurie, limping heavily, sprints across the backyard as the camera follows her every move. Glancing back in fear, she trips over a fallen lamp and falls to the floor. Undeterred, she scrambles past the driveway and into a neighbor's backyard, making her way to their back door. With urgency, she pounds on the door repeatedly until the back porch light flickers on. Through the glass, an elderly woman in a nightgown approaches the door.
182:
An elderly woman eyes a young girl warily before turning away from the door and leaving. The girl extends her hand and touches an object. Overwhelmed, Tommy bursts into tears and races upstairs. Laurie shifts from the doorway to the phone, lifts the receiver, dials, and waits in silence before gently placing the phone back down and standing motionless. With deliberate steps, Laurie circles around the couch and gradually kneels beside it. Her fingers graze the knitting needles jutting out of her tote bag, prompting her to extract one as a wave of fear washes over her, tears streaming silently down her face.

Abruptly, a menacing figure known as The Shape vaults from behind the couch, lunging at Laurie with a butcher knife. The knife embeds itself into the couch with a heavy thud. Reacting swiftly, Laurie recoils, her arm rising instinctively. Grasping the knitting needle, she plunges it into The Shape's neck. He recoils, clawing desperately at the needle before collapsing in a lifeless heap on the floor. Laurie remains seated, her gaze fixed on the still figure.

Meanwhile, Loomis navigates the street until blinding headlights and a screeching police car halt beside him. Suddenly, The Shape looms before him, butcher knife poised. Nearby, two children's screams pierce the air. Laurie hurriedly ushers them into the bathroom, slamming the door shut, locking it with a decisive click, and leaving herself exposed in the bedroom. She darts around the bed as The Shape advances relentlessly, his knife gleaming ominously.

Seeking refuge, Laurie dashes into a closet, seals the sliding doors, and retreats to the back. The doors shudder under The Shape's relentless pounding and eventually give way as he forces his way in, pushing aside clothes. Inside, Laurie quickly grabs a wire hanger, unwinds its top, and straightens it out. As The Shape looms over her, knife raised, Laurie, in a desperate act of self-defense, thrusts the hanger into his right eye. He staggers back in agony, dropping the butcher knife. Seizing her chance, Laurie grabs the fallen weapon with both hands and drives it deep into The Shape's abdomen, the blade sinking to the hilt.
177:
The camera's perspective shifts from a Jack-O-Lantern to peer through a window into a bedroom where an 18-year-old, very attractive sister enters. Dressed in a Halloween costume and mask, Alan, also 18, bursts into the room, causing the sister to giggle. Her boyfriend, who had been wearing the mask, grabs her and kisses her passionately after removing his disguise, revealing himself as a handsome young man. She responds enthusiastically, and they share another passionate kiss.

Abruptly, the camera's viewpoint, now restless and agitated, pulls away from the window and starts pacing back and forth. It then swiftly moves down the side of the house, passing the Jack-O-Lantern, and approaches a door. The door opens, and the camera glides silently into the house, making its way to the kitchen and stopping at a drawer. The drawer opens, and a large butcher knife is taken out. The viewpoint then turns and heads toward the kitchen door, looking down a hallway to the front door.

The boyfriend emerges from the bedroom, buttoning his shirt. The camera slowly enters the room, focusing on a discarded Halloween mask on the floor, which it picks up. Suddenly, the mask covers the camera's view, and we see through the eye-holes as it moves slowly down the hall to the bedroom door, peering inside. Inside, the sister, still completely nude, sits at her night-table brushing her hair. Sensing a presence, she quickly spins around, staring at the camera while covering her breasts.

Without warning, the camera lunges forward. The sister stares incredulously as, in a rapid blur, the butcher knife is driven into her chest and withdrawn almost instantly. In a wild frenzy, the knife blurs in and out of the frame, mercilessly slashing at the sister. She screams and tries to fend off the blows with her hands before collapsing out of frame onto the floor.

The camera, now viewing the sister's lifeless body, backs away, spins around, and races out of the bedroom. It speeds through the darkened house, out the front door, down the steps, and up the street. The camera continues its frenzied flight along the sidewalk, up a side alley, and through someone's backyard until it abruptly stops in front of a mother and father just exiting a neighbor's house. The father reaches up and removes the Halloween mask, revealing Michael, a calm and quiet six-year-old boy with a bright smile.
184:
In a classroom, the camera focuses on Laurie as a teacher lectures monotonously at the front. Laurie, barely attentive, doodles in her notebook. Her gaze drifts to a window where she dreamily watches the street outside, spotting a station wagon parked by the sidewalk with the shadowy figure of a man standing behind it. Quickly, she turns back to her notebook and resumes doodling, but her curiosity pulls her gaze back to the window. The station wagon and the mysterious figure are no longer there, so she returns her attention to her notebook.

Meanwhile, at a closed gas station beside a highway, a car is parked. The camera slowly shifts focus to a nearby phone booth where Loomis is engaged in a telephone conversation. At the high school, Annie exits the side door and calls out to Laurie and Lynda, who pause to wait for her. Suddenly, Laurie stops and looks back toward the school, then down the street where the station wagon is slowly approaching them. The figure inside isn't visible behind the windshield, but as the vehicle passes, Laurie catches a fleeting glimpse of a strange, pale face staring back at her. The shape, now close to the camera and out of focus, locks eyes with Laurie before accelerating away. The wagon speeds past the girls, stops abruptly up the street, and lingers momentarily before speeding off and disappearing around a corner. The girls resume walking.

They eventually stop in front of Lynda's modest suburban home on a quiet, tree-lined street. Lynda walks up to her house, while Annie and Laurie continue down the street. Along the sidewalk, a series of bushes catches Laurie's attention. The camera closes in on her face as she stares ahead, spotting the shadowy figure of a man, barely visible and almost blending into the dark foliage. The figure vanishes, leaving just the bushes. Annie, frustrated, strides over and kicks the bushes hard, while Laurie stands several feet away on the sidewalk. Gradually, Laurie approaches the bushes and examines them closely.
188:
In the living room, Annie listens to the growling of a dog. She then turns to Lindsey, who is also in the room. Outside, the legs of a mysterious shape are visible just a few feet from the house. Next to it, Lester's legs kick and struggle helplessly in mid-air. Off screen, the shape is seen strangling the dog, which hangs lifelessly moments later, its legs dangling without movement.

Meanwhile, Laurie and Tommy are seated on a couch, engrossed in a Horror-thon playing loudly on the television. Laurie extends her hand to Tommy, and they rise together, walking hand in hand into the kitchen.

Annie, dressed in a nylon robe and carrying her clothes, moves through a passageway to the laundry room. As she walks, the wind causes her robe to flutter open. The door to the laundry room creaks open, and Annie steps into the dark space. Using the light from the main house, she spots the light switch but before she can reach it, a gust of wind slams the door shut. Standing still for a moment, she then resumes her search for the switch. She turns toward the slightly ajar door, behind which the silhouette of the shape is visible. As the wind pushes the door slightly more open, Annie glances outside before stepping back inside and heading to the washing machine. She lifts the lid and tosses her clothes in.

Suddenly, a strong gust of wind bursts through the window above her, causing the door to slam shut again. Annie rushes to the door and struggles to open it, pulling with all her might.

In another part of the house, Lindsey Wallace, an 8-year-old with a pretty face, is absorbed in the Horror Marathon blaring from the TV. She remains seated in front of the screen, letting the phone ring unanswered beside her.

Back in the laundry room, Annie looks up at the window above the washing machine, unaware that the shape is peering in from outside. In a flash, the shape disappears. Determined to escape, Annie hurries to the washing machine, climbs atop it, and tries to squeeze through the window. She gets stuck halfway through and, despite her efforts to squirm back inside, she remains trapped until Lindsey comes to her aid, pulling on her legs until Annie slides back onto the dryer.

As they return to the house, the phone rings again. From inside, Annie hears it and sees Lindsey dash across the room to answer it. After Lindsey sets the receiver down and leaves the kitchen, Annie, giving her a disapproving look, picks up the phone.

Suddenly, the shape is seen walking through the hallway between the living room and the kitchen, right behind Annie as she proceeds into the living room.
190:
Loomis cautiously approaches the front porch and reaches the door with hesitant steps. He casts a glance back towards his friends standing in the street. The young boy turns to unlock the door. His perspective shifts back to Lonnie, who stands frozen at the front door, gripped by sheer terror. Suddenly, Lonnie whirls around, his eyes wide with fear as he fixates on the animated hedge. In a flash, Lonnie dashes off the porch, sprinting back to his friends with the speed of the wind. The group of boys, overwhelmed by fright, dashes down the street.

Hidden behind the hedge, Loomis rises silently, a smirk playing on his lips as he watches the boys flee. Unexpectedly, two hands appear in the frame and seize Loomis by the shoulders, causing him to leap and spin around in shock. Facing him is Brackett, who then turns and walks away towards the street. A car soon arrives, parking in front of the house as its lights extinguish. The sound of laughter emanates from within the vehicle. Inside, the attractive 17-year-old Bob Simms pops open a can of beer, while beside him, Lynda eagerly gulps down her own. The interior lights of the car go out. Bob opens the car door, and the pair tumbles out onto the ground. The beer can tips over, spilling onto the front seat as they embrace. Bob playfully grabs Lynda, eliciting giggles from her. He then lifts her into his arms and carries her towards the front door, where Lynda squirms playfully. As he sets her down, her foot inadvertently strikes the door, causing it to swing open. Both Bob and Lynda pause, then enter the house, finding the living room empty and dark.

Inside, they start flicking on the lights. Bob approaches Lynda, and they embrace once more, sharing a kiss. He guides her to the couch, turning off the light as they settle in. Unbeknownst to them, a shadow looms over them, and a man's silhouette on the stairway watches their every move. The house plunges into complete darkness, only to be pierced by an orange light drifting through the room. As it nears, it's revealed that Laurie is holding a Jack-O-Lantern, its candle casting a glow from within the pumpkin. Behind her, Lindsey and Tommy mimic spooky sounds as they all proceed through the house to the front window. Laurie positions the Jack-O-Lantern on the window sill and peers down the street, spotting Bob's car parked in front of the Wallaces' house. She then takes a seat on the couch, sighing, with Lindsey and Tommy snuggling up beside her.

The phone rings, prompting Laurie to rise and answer it. Meanwhile, Lynda, after hanging up the phone, flashes a grin at Bob, who mirrors her expression. Lynda seizes Bob's hand, pulling him up from the couch, and they briskly ascend the stairs. At the top, Lynda moves to the window and looks out.
195:
In a dimly lit room, Potter lights a large cigar he has just handed to George. A goon, as usual, stands impassively next to Potter's chair. Suddenly, George drops his cigar onto his lap and frantically brushes away the sparks from his clothes. As they shake hands, George is overcome with a physical revulsion; Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. In that moment of contact, George realizes he could never associate with this man. Shuddering, he drops Potter's hand and peers intently into his face. Turning away, George shouts at the goon, who remains emotionless beside Potter's wheelchair. As he exits, George yells at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office, which is modestly furnished with only a cheap bed, a couple of chairs, and a dresser.

Inside, Mary lies asleep on the bed. George enters, his mind swirling with thoughts from his past life. He removes his hat and coat, then moves to the dresser and gazes at his reflection in the mirror. His attention shifts to a picture on the nearby wall—a sketch of George lassoing the moon, first seen in Mary's living room. Mary wakes up and begins to sing their theme song. George crosses to the bed and sits on its edge, and Mary nods her head happily. Meanwhile, the voices of Joseph and Clarence in Heaven are heard over a series of shots.

George crosses the street toward the Building and Loan offices. In another scene, Mary sits on the floor playing with a baby, while a little boy occupies a nearby playpen. Mary is also busy hanging wallpaper and painting their old home. George, appearing tired and discouraged, enters the hall and begins to climb the stairs, only to have the banister knob come off in his hand.

The scene shifts to a group of newly drafted men marching in a camp, and Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms diligently sewing. Mary serves coffee and doughnuts from a portable U.S.O. pushcart to men leaning out of a train. Sam Wainwright displays blueprints to two Army officers. Potter is wheeled to a long table surrounded by several men. Gower and Uncle Billy lead a bond rally from atop an Army tank. Bert, in uniform, cautiously advances with a fixed bayonet, with smoke and gunfire flashing in the background. Overhead, hundreds of planes fly, dropping parachutes. In the foreground, Marty beckons soldiers to follow him. Harry fastens the helmet of his flying clothes, preparing for action.
201:
In the film, Clarence, an angel whose voice we've heard from Heaven, is introduced standing in water. Nearby, George sits before a wood-burning stove, his clothes drying on a line. He wears long winter underwear and sips hot coffee, his gaze fixed on the stove. Cold, gloomy, and slightly drunk, George ignores both Clarence and the tollkeeper, consumed by thoughts of his near suicide and his unresolved issues.

Clarence, on the other side of the stove, dons an undershirt—a ludicrous seventeenth-century garment resembling a baby's nightshirt with embroidered cuffs and collar, gathered at the neck with a drawstring. It falls below his knees, astonishing the tollkeeper, who sits against the wall, eyeing them suspiciously. Clarence, aware of the tollkeeper's amazement, shakes a book, prompting incredulous stares.

George, surprised, looks up, repeatedly attempting to spit but each time stopped by Clarence's amazing actions or words. The tollkeeper, also about to spit, is halted mid-action by Clarence's next statement. Both George and the tollkeeper react, with George casually observing the strange, smiling little man a second time. The tollkeeper grows increasingly nervous as George, leaning against the wall on his chair tipped back on two legs, brings his hand to his mouth.

Suddenly, the tollkeeper's chair slips out from under him with a crash. Rising warily, he exits, his expression suggesting he's about to call the police. George, trying to clear his mind, rubs his head with his hand and looks up at Clarence standing beside him. Clarence, struggling to connect with George, paces thoughtfully across the room.

As Clarence speaks, the snow stops falling outside, and a strong wind blows open the door to the shack. Clarence rushes to close it. Meanwhile, George, more interested in his hearing than in Clarence's words, cocks his head, favoring his deaf ear, and feels it as Clarence continues talking. George then indicates his bad ear and feels his lip, surprised to find no sign of the recent cut from Welch, now thoroughly confused.

George touches the clothes on the line, and both start dressing. Suddenly, George interrupts himself as they find themselves on an empty street—the same one where George's car had swerved into a tree near the sidewalk. Arriving at the spot, they find no car and an undamaged tree, deepening George's bewilderment.
203:
The homeowner, carrying Christmas packages under his arm, walks past. He bends down to inspect the trunk of a tree, then stands up to sniff George's breath before recoiling and continuing toward his house. George stands utterly perplexed. He then wraps his arm around Clarence, and they begin walking up the road.

They arrive at Martini's place, which is barely recognizable. The once cheerful Italian atmosphere has vanished, replaced by a rough, hard-drinking honky-tonk bar. The tables are bare, and the patrons appear tougher and more downcast. George and Clarence enter, approaching the bar, causing two patrons to leave as they draw near. Nick, the bartender, is behind the bar. As they order, Nick leans forward, thrusting his left fist menacingly close to Clarence's eye, leaving Clarence puzzled by this aggressive behavior. Nick then turns to prepare their drinks, but pauses suspiciously as he listens to their conversation, halting mid-pour with the bottle still in hand. George glances up at Nick, who then slams the bottle down onto the counter forcefully.

In the bar, a small, frail man with watery eyes and a broken-down appearance, holding his hat, enters. It's Gower, the druggist, who seems stunned by what he sees. Nick grabs a seltzer bottle and sprays Gower in the face, prompting harsh laughter from the crowd. Gower manages a weak smile as the soda drips from his face. Horrified, George jumps up and rushes to Gower's side, but the bouncers quickly eject Gower from the front door. George then returns to the bar.

Suddenly, George and Clarence are thrown through the door, landing in the snow outside. Inside, Nick is seen at the cash register, ringing the bell briskly. George and Clarence lie in the snow; George wears a strange, puzzled expression. They stay as they fell for a moment, exchanging looks. George catches sight of the neon sign above the door of the building. They rise to their feet, and George points to the sign, looking at Clarence, who hangs his head in a resigned manner. George, intensely curious, approaches Clarence, pokes his arm, confirming it's flesh. Frantically, George searches his pockets for some form of identification but finds none, leaving him completely baffled. He continues to turn his pockets inside out feverishly before setting off. Clarence rises and slowly follows him, occasionally glancing upward toward Heaven.

As George walks, the camera follows him, revealing the drastic transformation of the town. What was once a quiet, orderly small town has now taken on the rough character of a frontier village. George, in surprise, heads toward the main part of town.
211:
Under the glow of a full moon filtering through the trees, George abruptly rises from his chair, concluding his conversation. As another man exits the porch, heading into his house, he forcefully shuts the door behind him. Meanwhile, Mary dashes out of view, but as she does, George inadvertently stands on the belt of her bathrobe, causing it to slip off her as she moves. He then drops his bundle of clothes to retrieve her robe, scanning the surroundings in vain for Mary. From behind the foliage, Mary's face emerges, watching cautiously. George approaches the bush with the robe in hand, poised to toss it to her when a sudden thought halts him. Mary stirs restlessly within the bushes as headlights suddenly sweep the scene, revealing the old Bailey automobile rolling in with Harry driving and Uncle Billy by his side. George quickly drapes the robe over the bush and joins them in the car. As they drive away, Mary, now draped in the robe, emerges from the bush and watches the departing vehicle.

In a boardroom, around a long table sit about twelve directors, key figures of Bedford Falls including Dr. Campbell, a lawyer, an insurance agent, a real estate salesman, and others. Among them are George and Uncle Billy, with Dr. Campbell presiding as Chairman. Each director is provided with individual reports to review, surrounded by folders and papers from their discussions. Notably present is Henry F. Potter, seated prominently with his goon at his side in a wheelchair. Dr. Campbell stands, prompting George and Uncle Billy to gather their documents and prepare to exit. The room watches in astonishment as they move towards the door. At the threshold, George, coat and papers in hand, is poised to leave but pauses, provoked by Potter's remarks about his father. George returns to the table, heated, before storming out with the jubilant Uncle Billy in tow. Potter's expression hardens with animosity as the directors erupt into a noisy debate.

George, clearly agitated, fumbles with his bag and papers, with the ever-talkative Uncle Billy shadowing him, concerned about the potential dissolution of the Building and Loan which could disrupt his plans. The tension breaks when Ernie appears in the doorway, followed by an excited Dr. Campbell rushing out. Cheers erupt from Cousin Eustace, Cousin Tilly, and Uncle Billy. In a moment of relief, Dr. Campbell and George share a handshake.

The night sky, adorned with the same twinkling stars seen at the film's opening, now serves as a backdrop to voices from Heaven. At a bustling train station, typical activity unfolds as people await their trains. Uncle Billy, perched on a baggage wagon and snacking on peanuts, observes as George paces anxiously back and forth before him.
216:
At the foot of the cross, Everett decisively cuts the last guy wire with his pincers, eliciting a sharp BOINK, prompting him and three others to dash away swiftly. As the crowd disperses in a panic, the cross hurtles down towards Big Dan, who remains motionless, his gaze fixed upward. The cross then smashes into Big Dan Teague, erupting into a spectacular cascade of sparks and embers that completely engulfs him.

A vehicle rolls to a stop in front of a town hall, from which the sounds of a party spill out. Pappy O'Daniel steps out, accompanied by his entourage—Eckard, Spivey, and Junior. Amidst this, Delmar appears sullen, and Everett looks utterly shocked. As car headlights sweep by, the men quickly retreat into an alleyway. The car proceeds to the banquet hall, from which Homer Stokes and his midget companion emerge. The midget discards a crumpled white hood into the car and both don their suitcoats, then briskly ascend the stairs, the midget struggling to match Stokes's pace.

Meanwhile, Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy slip in through the back door. Their blackface makeup has been removed, but they are now disguised with hastily applied, long gray beards using spirit gum. Each man clutches a case containing a musical instrument as they push their way through the bustling kitchen staff.

In the banquet hall, Penny and Waldrip sit prominently at the head table, surrounded by the Wharvey gals. Facing the audience with their backs to the stage, they are unaware as Everett, Pete, Delmar, and Tommy, now disguised as a bearded band, take their positions. Pappy O'Daniel stands close to Waldrip, whispering confidentially into his ear with an arm draped over his shoulder. Waldrip listens, sitting rigidly, his frown fixed on some distant point.

Suddenly, Waldrip bursts out, while Penny shakes her head vehemently and looks down at her plate, seemingly unaffected by Everett’s ongoing pleas directed at her back. The band strikes up 'Man of Constant Sorrow,' triggering an immense reaction from the crowd. Everett, still attempting to catch Penny's eye, is taken aback by the thunderous applause. Exchanging puzzled glances, Everett and his bandmates dive deeper into their performance with renewed vigor. Everett then breaks into an impromptu buck-and-wing dance, escalating the crowd's excitement to feverish levels.

Homer Stokes, observing the band, wears a scowl. The audience, in turn, watches him with stony expressions. Undeterred, Stokes continues his speech, but a tomato soon strikes him, followed by a barrage of food. Attempting to shield himself, he roars into the microphone.

Elsewhere, an old couple, hunched over a crystal set, listens intently to the tinny broadcast. They exchange silent glances, then refocus on the device. Back at the event, the band's music nearly drowns out Stokes's words, while his midget companion watches with growing concern. The situation escalates when an audience member pulls out the microphone plug, leaving Stokes to mouth words that no one can hear.
219:
The four men sit around, attentively listening to the sounds emanating from a large box radio. Wash resumes whittling, Everett meticulously applies pomade from a jar to his hair using a comb, Pete picks at his teeth with a toothpick, and Delmar rhythmically waves a hand, lost in the music. Clearing his throat, Everett then carefully screws the lid back onto the pomade jar.

Later, they find themselves sleeping in a hayloft, where Everett sports a hairnet to protect his carefully styled hair. Suddenly, a spotlight sweeps across the hayloft ceiling and a loud voice booms out. Startled awake, the men sit up. From an aerial view, a lawman, bullhorn in hand and surrounded by armed deputies, appears foreshortened. Beside him stands a sheriff, his tin star glinting, watching through mirrored sunglasses with a drooling bloodhound at his side.

Pete shouts down from the hayport. Amidst the sudden sound of gunfire, Everett yanks Pete down as bullets from a tommy gun rip through the hayloft. Infuriated, Pete seizes a flaming faggot and throws it down at the group of deputies below, where it lands harmlessly amidst scattered straw. A drum begins to spin, flames start to crawl up the outside of a van, and bullet holes riddle its body. Men scatter as the vehicle shakes under the barrage of multiple tommy guns. Tires burst and hiss, doors fly open, and glass shatters. Pete, Everett, and Delmar jump into the van, slamming the doors shut. A boy, his feet extended by strapped-on wood blocks to reach the pedals and sitting on a Sears Roebuck catalogue for visibility, shifts into gear. The car accelerates toward a flaming wall and crashes through it.

The Hogwallop boy walks unsteadily down the middle of a deserted road, still wearing the wood blocks. Turning to face the camera, he lets out a shout. In the foreground, Pete enters and tosses a dirt clod at the boy, missing his target and yelling. The camera then pans to show Pete walking over to the shoulder where their car sits, hood up, with Everett and Delmar examining the engine.

In a small gesture, Everett slides a tin across a counter, leaving him momentarily stunned before he picks it up. On a wooded hillside, the men gather around a twig fire, roasting a small animal on a spit. A figure stalks into the scene and drops down by the fire in disgust, shaking his head with grim resignation. Everett scrapes the remaining pomade onto his comb and begins to groom his hair. Reaching into his pocket, Everett pulls out a gold watch and tosses it to Pete, who looks at it with puzzlement before opening it to read the inscription inside.
221:
As Pappy brushes past them, Junior attempts to coax him, only to receive a swift slap from Pappy's hat. Pappy then dramatically waves his hat at the radio building where singers, clad in faux hillbilly outfits and carrying various musical instrument cases, emerge from a second car. In the background, Tommy plays and sings a soulful slow blues.

Meanwhile, three convicts sit by a fire, holding coffee cups and gazing into the flames. One of them, Pete, thoughtfully swishes his coffee while murmuring softly. Suddenly, the three men tense up as Pete begins to shovel dirt onto the fire. Delmar and Everett scramble to peek over a nearby low ridge. From their vantage point, they spot a lone barn with their car parked beside it. Various police vehicles are positioned facing the barn, their armed occupants taking cover behind the cars and aiming their guns at the structure. A man with a bullhorn continues to direct his comments towards the distant barn. The convicts notice the sheriff standing impassively next to the man with the bullhorn, holding a leash to which a straining bloodhound is attached.

The three men then shuffle down a dusty road, their attention broken by the sound of a speeding car approaching. The car comes into view, cornering sharply on two wheels before crashing back onto all four. As it speeds along, dollar bills flutter and snap out of its windows. The car roars up to the three men, and Delmar optimistically sticks out his thumb. The vehicle screeches to a halt, revealing a young driver in a sharp suit with a round, babylike face, who leans over to call through the passenger window.

Delmar plucks a fluttering dollar bill from the air, examining it with wonder. He stretches the bill between his hands, brings the sides together, and gives it an appraising pop. Enchanted by the wafting currency, Delmar looks around and yanks another bill out of the air, reminiscent of a child captivated by soap bubbles.

The three men quickly climb into the car, which then squeals away. The driver glances up at the rearview mirror as the sound of sirens grows louder. He reaches inside his coat but stops short of drawing a gun, instead appraising his new passengers. Delmar, reacting to the paper currency fluttering inside the car, opens his door and steps onto the running board, giving Everett a casual nudge. Startled, Everett slides over.

Outside, George Nelson, now fully out of the car and facing the pursuit vehicles, has one hand clamped on the car roof while waving to Delmar with the other. Nelson then sends a spray of bullets back at the pursuing cars, firing wildly as they gain on him, returning fire.
223:
In a rain-soaked scene, Everett, Pete, and Delmar seek refuge under the dripping eave of a barn, their coats clutched tightly at the neck as they gaze despondently at the downpour. They soon trek along a red dirt road that winds through a bayou before settling around a campfire. There, Everett captivates Pete and Delmar with an animated ghost story, his audience wide-eyed and enthralled from their lower seats.

Continuing their journey, the trio passes a cotton field, the landscape peppered with burst pods. Amidst this, a sad-faced woman in a calico dress, visibly crestfallen, speaks to a clerk.

The narrative shifts as Pete eagerly exits a car before it fully stops, stumbling down a bank toward a river. Everett and Delmar follow at a more leisurely pace, with Everett chuckling lightly. The scene is filled with unearthly singing, emanating full volume from three beautiful yet otherworldly women who are washing clothes in the stream, rhythmically dunking and beating them against rocks. Pete, visibly smitten, awkwardly smiles with deep, intense eyes. Despite his attempts to engage them, the laundresses do not respond verbally, though they smile at him as they keep singing. Pete persists, even reaching into their laundry basket, maintaining his gaze on the women and hissing whispers out of the corner of his mouth, while Everett laughs softly. One of the women, still singing, offers Everett a jug marked with three Xes, but none of them verbally respond.

The scene takes a surreal turn as Delmar, horrified, notices rhythmic movement in a pile of clothes—a spot on a shirt rising and falling. Everett joins him to investigate, and they watch as the movement migrates up the shirt until a large yellow toad emerges from under the collar. Delmar keens in response, and Everett appears bewildered. The toad then hops down the river bank, ending up in Delmar's lap as he whimpers while petting it. The frog croaks, and Delmar's whimpering continues, with Everett squinting and shaking his head in confusion.

In a more formal setting, a table is set with linen, where Delmar and Everett sit deep in conversation, a shoebox between them. Everett points a knife at the shoebox, adding intensity to their discussion.

The perspective shifts to a broad-shouldered man in a cream-colored suit and a shirt with a powder-blue collar, who is deeply engrossed in a large plate of steak and eggs. Sensing something, he looks up, cocks his head, and slowly turns, revealing a cream-colored eyepatch with powder-blue trim. His good eye fixes intently on Everett and Delmar, who are still arguing out of earshot, just as a waitress arrives to take their order.
225:
He enters the car, which then sputters and chugs away down the road. Delmar, struggling to stand, makes his way over to the dead frog, tears streaming down his face. His arms, stretched high and bound to a tree limb, are in full view. His interrogator brandishes a bullwhip. Another strike, another cry of pain. A third man steps into the torchlight, followed by a drooling hound. This man is Cooley, the sheriff we recognize from earlier barn confrontations, wearing his signature mirrored sunglasses. The two men step back from Pete in acknowledgment. The soft patter of rain begins to quicken its pace. Cooley glances up, then down at Pete, shrugs, and looks away. Gazing upward into the darkness, a rope is thrown up, disappearing into the night before dropping back down, a noose swinging at its end. The two henchmen slip the noose over Pete's neck. Delmar, stubbornly, shakes his head.

From a distance, the sound of picks striking and men chanting reaches them. Everett, with hollow eyes, tries to reassure both Delmar and himself, though his voice fades as he watches the road. They pass a group of chained men in prison stripes and duck-billed caps, wielding pickaxes and shovels by the roadside. As Everett attempts to continue his thought, he stares at the line of men, who appear ghostly in the haze of heat and dust. Everett is visibly haunted. The last man in the line swings his pick, then looks up as he grows smaller in the distance. Everett, staring back at him, receives a slack-jawed gaze until the man is obscured by heat waves and the truck's dusty trail. Blinking, Everett shakes his head as if to clear it, and the truck continues rattling on.

On a stage adorned with bunting, a man with round rimless glasses and a slender neck speaks to a crowd of rural folk. Identified on posters as 'Homer Stokes, Friend of the Little Man,' he energetically shakes a broom overhead. A midget in overalls stands beside him, waving a small broom in sync with Stokes' gestures. Amidst the cheers, he smiles broadly as three girls in gingham dresses rush to join him on stage; the eldest is around ten years old. Everett forcefully makes his way through the crowd toward the stage, with a puzzled Delmar following closely. A man wearing a straw boater hat joins them. Everett sniffs the air, squints, and then takes a wild swing at Waldrip, who nimbly dodges it. Adopting a Marquess of Queensbury stance, Waldrip dances around, landing sharp punches on Everett's nose, leaving him stunned and outmatched. Eventually, Everett is thrown out of the establishment, its glass doors swinging open, and he lands face-first in the street dust.
226:
As romantic tunes play softly through a tinny speaker, Everett slumps in his seat, his irritation evident as he hisses angrily, watching alongside Delmar in the dimly lit and quiet theater. The sparse audience, including Everett and Delmar, shifts restlessly in their seats. Suddenly, a man armed with a shotgun strides into the auditorium, halting several rows behind them after walking halfway down the aisle. He surveys the room before raising a whistle to his lips. At the sound of his whistle, the back doors burst open, and a line of chained men marches in briskly, filling one row and then the next with a cacophony of clanking chains. They stand silently until the first guard, accompanied by two others, scans the theater and blows his whistle once more, prompting the men to sit. Another whistle cues the film to resume its speed.

From behind, a hissing whisper catches Everett and Delmar's attention. Everett's jaw drops, his expression frozen in a mix of horror and disbelief, as if he's seen a ghost. Delmar, initially mirroring Everett's shock, gradually accepts the reality of Pete's presence among the convicts. Pete, squinting and tilting his head in confusion, struggles to understand Delmar's slow, exaggeratedly mouthed whisper. Despite Pete's overarticulated response indicating he still didn't catch it, the scene shifts to Pappy O'Daniel on the veranda of the Governor's Mansion. As the sun sets, Pappy sips bourbon and smokes a cigar, his mood turning quizzical upon hearing a whisper. He looks back and forth between the whisperers, his expression one of mild boredom, his cigar drooping in his mouth forming an 'O'.

Later, Everett emerges over the edge of his bed, his face blackened and his stance unsteady as if on a boat. He wields a large, long-armed, short-nosed pincering tool, using it to lock onto Pete's chain and lever it free with a chinking sound. Despite his newly gained freedom, Pete's eyes burn into Everett's, his head shaking in misery before he breaks down in tears. He embraces a stunned Delmar and then an uncomfortable Everett. The scene shifts abruptly as Pete, now stunned himself, and Delmar turn their attention to Everett. Delmar's mood lifts momentarily.

Tension escalates when Pete lunges at Everett, tackling him to the ground and wrapping his hands around Everett's throat. As they roll through some brush, they find themselves halfway into a clearing where they suddenly stop. Their gaze falls upon a great open field where men in bedsheets march in formation before a massive, fiery cross. Realizing the danger, Pete and Everett quickly crabwalk back into the bushes, soon joined by Delmar as they push their way through to safety.
229:
Szpilman meticulously logs the tools each worker borrows at the construction site. A worker briefly peeks into the storage area. Jewish workers begin to gather on the site in disorganized lines as an SS Captain confidently strides in. With a jovial demeanor and an array of jokes, the SS Captain leaps onto the scaffolding, standing tall and beaming as he surveys the workers. A quick, meaningful look passes between Szpilman and Majorek. The SS Captain's broad smile fills the air, yet the workers remain unresponsive. He rubs his thumb and forefinger together, leering at them, but still no reaction; his smile fades away. Snow starts to fall.

Majorek pulls a barrow across the site, guided by a rope attached to its shaft. The barrow carries five sacks. He maneuvers it over to where Szpilman is waiting. Majorek, previously asleep, snaps awake. He accepts a piece of paper from Szpilman but keeps silent. Turning over, Majorek drifts back to sleep. Szpilman heads back to his bunk. He has unloaded the potato sacks into a corner and is kneeling, preparing to untie the string on the smallest sack when a sound catches his attention. He glances around.

An SS Lieutenant enters the storage room, sucking his bleeding finger. Szpilman swiftly moves to a cupboard, retrieves a First Aid tin, and hands a plaster to the SS Lieutenant. He gestures towards the sacks with a nod. Trembling with fear, Szpilman struggles to untie the string and fails. The SS Lieutenant forcefully pushes him aside, draws a dagger from his belt, and slices the string open. He reaches into the sack, pulling out a handful of long yellow beans, then oatmeal, which he flings into Szpilman's face. With a vicious kick, he sends Szpilman reeling and storms off. Gasping for air, Szpilman reaches into the bottom of the sack, uncovering a pistol and ammunition, which he quickly conceals under his clothing. The air turns bitingly cold.

The Jewish workers, clutching bundles of potatoes and bread, trudge back towards the ghetto gates under the watch of two Polish policemen. One of the policemen takes a swig of vodka and locks eyes with Szpilman. With a glassy stare, he confronts Szpilman, who is petrified and desperately tries to shield his concealed package. In a tense moment, Zick-Zack seizes Szpilman by the coat. Both policemen find this amusing, recovering from their laughter as the column resumes its march. A brief silence is broken by a lone voice singing from the back, "Children of Warsaw will go to fight!" Szpilman turns to see Majorek leading the song. A smile crosses Szpilman's face, and Majorek acknowledges it with a nod. Szpilman joins the song, and soon the others follow, their voices growing stronger as they march on, singing with vigor. Later, Szpilman lies in a steaming bath, his eyes closed, seemingly in a trance.
231:
In the quiet apartment, Gebczynski approaches from behind and closes the cupboard. He then heads towards the front door but pauses. Handing over a scrap of paper, he shakes Szpilman's hand and departs hastily. Left alone, Szpilman stands momentarily disoriented before removing his shoe and tucking the piece of paper inside it. As he does this, his gaze falls upon the divan bed. He approaches it, removes his other shoe, and lies down, testing the bed's springiness with his body. A beatific smile graces his face before he closes his eyes and drifts into immediate sleep.

The sound of voices rouses Szpilman from his slumber. He opens his eyes, momentarily uncertain of his surroundings, and hears the voices again from the neighboring apartment. Intrigued, he gets up, moves closer to the wall, presses his ear against it, and listens intently. Szpilman finds himself enjoying the moment until the sound of a piano fills the air, played with deep emotion yet filled with errors. The piano music abruptly halts, followed by the sound of a door slamming.

A woman hands Szpilman a parcel. He takes it to the small kitchen and unpacks it while Janina looks out the window. She turns her gaze back outside. Outside, the building is engulfed in flames, with corpses scattered across the pavement. German soldiers stand around, chatting and laughing. A group of Jewish fighters is lined up and executed. The sun blazes down on the now burned-out shells of the ghetto buildings, the street desolate. Autumn leaves fall and swirl in the wind.

Szpilman gazes out the window as snow falls, and ice forms on the windows. The sound of a key turning in the door catches his attention. He turns as the door opens and Gebczynski enters, visibly distraught. Gebczynski quickly lights a cigarette while speaking in hushed, rapid tones before leaving. Szpilman listens to Gebczynski's footsteps fading down the stairs. He notices the cigarette stub, picks it up, lights it, and smokes awkwardly, coughing as he does so.

The screech of brakes and a car engine alert Szpilman. He tenses up as German voices shout and heavy footsteps ascend the stairs. Szpilman moves to the window, opens it, and places a chair sideways in front of it to use as a step, contemplating the best way to jump. He then leans against the wall near the door, waiting. The sounds of slamming doors, German shouts, and a scream fill the air. Szpilman prepares himself to leap from the window. The footsteps on the stairs begin to descend, and another door slams. Cautiously, Szpilman approaches the window and looks out to see SS men escorting two prisoners and shoving them into a car, which then speeds away, leaving the street empty.

Snow continues to fall, accompanied by howling wind. Szpilman lies on the divan, cold, unshaven, his hair long and dirty. Despite his condition, he manages to rise.
227:
In a bustling crowd, a man turns to find a strikingly beautiful young woman gazing at him with adoration, both caught in the surge of jostling people. His eyes brighten in response. Suddenly, JUREK wedges himself between them, seizing the woman's arm, and forcefully navigates his way down the stairs, dragging her with him. The man, caught in the tide of the crowd, is swept into the lobby where debris is scattered everywhere. Amidst this chaos, Szpilman struggles towards the main door, but another bomb detonates, sending a cloud of dust and debris into the air, momentarily obscuring everyone.

In a state of panic, the Szpilman family rushes through their tastefully decorated bourgeois apartment. They move frantically between rooms, hurriedly packing clothes and belongings into open suitcases and a trunk. The living room, lined with books and paintings, features a boudoir grand piano, silver platters, and candlesticks. Amidst the chaos, one family member sits by the radio, ear pressed to the speaker, trying to find a clear station. The father, clutching a silver-framed photograph, approaches the mother. He then retreats to his room. Overwhelmed, the mother barely holds back tears before rushing into the kitchen just as Szpilman enters the apartment, bewildered by the flurry of activity. She dashes out of the kitchen and begins to search. Meanwhile, the others continue their hurried packing. They gather around as one family member strikes the radio in frustration. The father pours liqueur into glasses. Seated at the dining table, the family has just finished their meal, the table laden with the remnants of their dinner. They clink their glasses and drink together.

The scene shifts to a street where buildings lay in ruins, smoke still rising. Onlookers, including Szpilman, Henryk, and their father who strains to see, stand on the sidewalk. They watch expressionlessly as a column of German soldiers, led by an officer on horseback, marches into view.

Back in the apartment, Regina opens and closes a window, carefully examining the frame with her fingers. At the other end, the father counts a dwindling stack of notes and coins. Henryk is lost in thought while Szpilman fiddles with his father's violin. The apartment now has less furniture, and the silver is gone. All eyes turn to the dining table, now marred with stains and its veneer peeling away at one corner. As they watch, the veneer snaps, revealing the bare wood beneath. Quickly, they begin to hide their possessions.

Szpilman stands at a public telephone, waiting anxiously for his call to be answered. Later, he and Dorota walk along a tree-lined street amidst bombed-out buildings and rubble. Dorota steals admiring, almost loving glances at Szpilman as they converse and stroll. He responds with a smile, visibly touched by her affection, while she becomes embarrassed and starts to laugh. Their laughter grows until they are clinging to each other, almost helpless. Amidst their joyous moment, Szpilman tenderly takes Dorota's hand and kisses it.
