Suddenly, nine Black Riders explode from Minas Morgul, charging directly toward the camera.

A solitary horseman races to the top of a hill along the west road, pausing to gaze toward the jagged mountains of Mordor across the main highway south to Minas Tirith. His expression grave, he spurs his horse onward, descending into the lower depths of the Citadel. Inside, Gandalf is seen frantically flipping through ancient scrolls and books on a high wooden table until his eyes fix on a particular old parchment, which he reads aloud to himself in a hurried murmur.

Elsewhere, Farmer Maggot is busy chopping wood in his garden when the snorting nostrils of a horse are seen, casting a looming shadow over a Hobbit House. Terrified, Farmer Maggot cowers in his doorway while his dog, Fang, whimpers and backs away. The Black Rider then gallops away at speed.

Back at Bag End, Frodo bids farewell to Sam outside the entrance and heads toward the front door. Inside, a creepy point of view shot captures Frodo approaching up the path. Upon entering Bag End, Frodo pauses, immediately sensing that something is amiss.
335:
Saruman gazes into the Palantir, his hands gently cupping the ominous, massive eye that pulses within. Seated, he watches as his ORC OVERSEER approaches him, the overseer's heavy footsteps echoing in the vast chamber. Meanwhile, Gandalf lies unconscious on the cold, unforgiving obsidian floor of Orthanc's summit, where he eventually stands, the camera pulling back to reveal his isolation atop the towering structure. Surrounded by sheer drops of 500 feet on all sides, Gandalf finds himself marooned on the tiny, flat peak. A haunting wail slices through the air, adding to the eerie atmosphere.

Peering anxiously over the edge, Gandalf's eyes catch the distressing sight below: ORCS are viciously uprooting one of the beautiful Isengard trees. He watches in horror as they hack at the trunk with axes, the destruction spreading as more and more trees are felled, leaving Gandalf in helpless despair. Meanwhile, in the rain-drenched night, Saruman stands looking into the darkness, the ORC overseer sidling up to him, axe in hand, his face dripping with sweat from exertion.

Elsewhere, the hobbits, led by Strider, journey through the rugged countryside. Strider halts before a distant hill crowned with an ancient ruin. Frodo, Merry, and Pippin, exhausted and covered in mud, collapse into a small hollow halfway up Weathertop. Strider then drops four small swords at their feet. As Frodo's eyes flicker open, he suddenly sits up, sniffing the air suspiciously. Nearby, Sam, Merry, and Pippin huddle around a small fire, where sausages and bacon sizzle invitingly in a hot frying pan.

Their peace is shattered as five Ringwraiths on foot race up the steep slope with unnatural speed. Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin desperately clamber towards the summit, clutching their newly acquired swords. They race into a ring of broken stones at the top of Weathertop, the remnants of an ancient tower's base. Standing back-to-back at the center of this ring, they brace themselves for the impending attack.

The Ringwraiths emerge one by one, their gleaming swords brandished menacingly as they slowly advance on the hobbits. At the center of the menacing group stands their leader, the Witch King. In a bold move, Sam rushes forward with a cry, swinging his sword at the Witch King. However, the Witch King easily blocks the blow, and Sam's blade shatters upon impact. The Witch King then lashes out with a powerful fist, sending Sam flying backward.

Overcome with terror, Merry and Pippin throw themselves flat on the ground. Amidst the chaos, Frodo, in slow motion, reaches into his pocket and pulls out the ring. The Ringwraiths close in on him, a venomous whisper echoing in his head as they utter a chilling screech of excitement. Unable to resist any longer, Frodo falls to his knees and slips on the ring, disappearing from view.

Transported to a weird twilight world, Frodo looks upon the Ringwraiths now revealed in their true, terrifying form: five ghouls clad in long grey robes, their white hair and pallid, ruthless faces chilling to behold. The Witch King extends a haggard hand towards Frodo, reaching greedily for the ring on his finger.
341:
In a gripping confrontation, Legolas launches an arrow at the King of the Dead, which astonishingly passes straight through him. Unfazed, Aragorn continues his advance, his gaze fixed intently on the spectre. The King of the Dead, with a menacing snarl, raises his deadly sword above Aragorn's head. With a terrifying shriek, he sweeps his sword towards Aragorn, who, in slow motion, counters by raising his sword, Anduril. The blade of Anduril clashes against the spectral sword, creating a sharp metallic ring that echoes through the caverns. The King of the Dead, staring in disbelief, is then grabbed by the neck by Aragorn, who presses the sharp blade against the ghost's throat before releasing him. Ghostly faces with hollow eyes watch Aragorn closely.

Meanwhile, thousands of orcs relentlessly advance towards the walls of Minas Tirith. A guard atop the parapet shouts down as the huge gate swings open, revealing Faramir's badly wounded horse dragging him, both impaled by orc arrows. Iorlas and other soldiers rush to the Citadel with Faramir's unconscious body on a stretcher, followed by a devastated Pippin. Denethor emerges from the Tower Hall, approaching his son's stretcher with a heavy heart, but soon turns away in shock as he reaches the courtyard's edge.

From the top of Minas Tirith, a full view of the orc army sprawls across the Pelennor Fields, resembling a sea of black ants numbering 75,000. Trolls load catapults with rocks, while battering rams and siege towers are pulled forward on chains under the murky twilight of Mordor, illuminated by thousands of flickering torches that give the army the appearance of a moving city. Amidst this, a huge boulder crashes into the walls of Minas Tirith, sending boulders hurtling from catapults across the fields. One boulder strikes a balcony crowded with civilians, causing confusion and panic among the soldiers.

Horror fills the streets of Minas Tirith as the severed heads of Faramir's horsemen land among the soldiers. Pippin, overwhelmed, runs to Faramir, bending over him. As Denethor looks down at his unconscious son, he is suddenly struck from behind by Gandalf's staff. Gandalf, with grim determination, clubs Denethor to the ground before turning to address the soldiers. He then gallops down the winding, labyrinthine streets on Shadowfax against the flow of fleeing soldiers, eventually bounding up stairs onto the level one battlements.
343:
The fate of their quest hinges on Frodo entering the ominous tunnel. As he peers into its engulfing darkness, Frodo is joined by Gollum, whose sparse, greasy hair dangles over his hooded eyes like malevolent weeds. Taking a deep, resolute breath, Frodo follows Gollum deeper into the shadowy passage. They press forward into the dark, with Frodo navigating by the sound of Gollum's scurrying and voice. Overwhelmed by exhaustion, Frodo struggles to keep Gollum in sight amidst the murky gloom. Attempting to follow the voice, Frodo slips, reaching out to steady himself on the tunnel wall. He quickly pulls his hand back, finding strands of white thread stuck to it. Gollum remains out of sight as Frodo, breathing heavily, moves past creatures ensnared in sinister web-like material. The sound of a creaking jointed creature moving purposefully through the darkness adds to the tension. In a moment of blind panic, Frodo starts to run.

Meanwhile, Sam descends the ancient stairs recklessly, his face drained and devastated. His foot slips, and suddenly he finds himself sliding uncontrollably, only halted by a large rock that prevents a fatal plunge over a precipice. Something catches Sam's eye, and he stares, scarcely breathing, at a package of lembas bread. Glancing back up the long, steep stair, Sam sees Frodo running blindly. Frodo falls, entangled in a sticky substance that clings to him. As he lies immobilized on the cold ground, a distant memory in the form of a voice reaches him. In his rising fear, Frodo fumbles in his jacket and pulls out the glass phial, a gift from Galadriel, which he holds aloft. On the other side of the web, Gollum watches. Frodo wildly slashes with Sting, the shining blade cutting through the fibrous strands. The web snaps back into his face as he works to free himself. The tunnel, now lit by the light of Galadriel, reveals the looming shadow of Shelob advancing. As disbelief turns to fear at the sight of the approaching Shelob, Gollum bolts. Frodo hacks at the web and with a desperate lunge, frees himself, though Sting remains caught. Leaving the sword behind, Frodo throws himself through a narrow crevice and stumbles out of Shelob's lair, tumbling onto cold rock. Covered in cobwebs, wild-eyed and drenched in sweat, Frodo looks up just as Gollum lunges at him. They fight, rolling on the ground toward the edge of a precipice. Frodo pins Gollum down, his hands tightening around his throat. Suddenly, a moment of self-realization hits Frodo, and horrified at his own violence, he releases Gollum.
344:
Gollum recoils fearfully. Coughing and spluttering follow. Frodo, shocked, gazes at Smeagol before rising to his feet. Smeagol, in disbelief, fixes his eyes on Frodo. Enraged, Smeagol lunges at Frodo, who falls perilously near the precipice's edge. Gollum stumbles over Frodo and plunges into the ravine below. Exhausted, Frodo stumbles down the steep stairs of Cirith Ungol, filled with remorse over his treatment of Sam. He collapses to his knees.

Frodo lands on soft, green grass. Sun-drenched images of trees appear, followed by a hazy vision of Lothlorien where Galadriel approaches barefoot. She leans down, offering her hand to Frodo, who stares at her for a moment, torn between continuing his journey and succumbing to rest. Understanding his duty, Frodo rises to his feet, soon finding himself back in the dark, fetid tunnels of the Pass of Cirith Ungol. Despite the challenge, he presses on.

Flaming missiles descend upon the city. Grond thumps against the Minas Tirith gate, sending vibrations throughout. Gandalf, mounted on Shadowfax, leads several hundred Gondorian foot soldiers down the streets. Pippin watches as Faramir's unconscious body, carried on a stretcher by Denethor's servants led by Denethor himself, moves with a funeral-like atmosphere. An iron door creaks open, and Faramir's procession enters a wide, vaulted chamber where lantern light casts great shadows on shrouded walls, revealing rows upon rows of marble tombs, each bearing a stone-carved sleeping figure with folded hands. Denethor turns to his servants. The gate shatters under Grond's force; behind it, fearful Gondorian foot soldiers stand. Gandalf rallies the bowmen before the great doors, their courage faltering with each crashing sound. Suddenly, the fearsome head of Grond protrudes into Minas Tirith. Moments later, the gate is demolished, and giant cave trolls invade the first circle under an archway never before breached by an enemy. Rows of archers release a volley of arrows, but the trolls continue to smash the foot soldiers with their giant clubs. Orcs swarm through the opening, igniting a fierce, hand-to-hand battle that spreads into flames and smoldering, blackened buildings. With a roar, Gandalf, on Shadowfax, leads a counterattack followed by several hundred Gondorian foot soldiers. Thousands of Orcs flood through the city gates, breaching the first level.

Frodo, weighed down by the Ring around his neck, staggers through the Pass of Cirith Ungol. Driven by grim resolve, he moves forward, beginning to climb a stone staircase through a narrow pass.
345:
As Frodo Baggins treks through a daunting pass flanked by towering peaks that seem to prop up the sky, he nears the ominous summit of Cirith Ungol. A menacing orc watch tower looms ahead, emitting a faint glow from within its stone structure. The path leading over the summit lies completely exposed to the watchful eyes of the orcs stationed there.

Staying close to the rock wall and shrouded in shadows, Frodo cautiously advances. Unbeknownst to him, the monstrous spider Shelob emerges silently behind him. With stealth and malevolence, she trails Frodo as he ascends the stone stairs, his focus intensely fixed on the orc tower.

Suddenly, Shelob's movement shifts to a horrifying scuttle down the sheer rock face. Frodo senses the lurking menace just in time to spin around, but before he can defend himself, Shelob viciously stabs him in the neck with her stinger. Frodo's body goes limp immediately. As he collapses, Shelob's legs catch him and she swiftly begins to weave cobwebs around him. With incredible dexterity, she rolls Frodo over and over in her legs, encasing him in a web cocoon from head to toe.

Just then, the sharp edge of a sword flashes into view. Samwise Gamgee confronts the giant spider, wielding the sword Sting in one hand and a shining phial in the other. Shelob hisses at Sam, dropping Frodo who then rolls down the stairs within his web prison. With a fierce determination igniting his usually gentle eyes, Sam advances and swings Sting upwards, slashing at Shelob. As she hisses and rears above him, venom dripping from her stinger, Sam ducks beneath her legs and stabs Sting into one of her eye clusters. Shelob screams, her mandibles thrashing wildly as green ooze trickles from her wounded eye.

In retaliation, Shelob uses her hind legs to lift Sam off the ground and hurl him backwards. Sam lands heavily on the ground, and Shelob pounces, raising her massive belly high above him. As she prepares to crush him under her weight, Sam lifts the elven blade above his head with both hands. The blade plunges into Shelob's soft underbelly, causing a shudder to ripple through her body. Writhing and trembling, she pulls away from the pain and crawls towards her hole, leaving a trail of green-yellow slime behind her. She squeezes into the hole and disappears, her sounds of misery fading into silence.

Sam rushes to Frodo's side, tearing away the cobwebs from his head. Frodo's face is deathly pale, his head lolling lifelessly in Sam's arms. Overcome with emotion, Sam lays his face on Frodo's chest, weeping softly. Looking up, Sam notices the orc tower and sees Sting glowing blue—a warning of approaching enemies. A small party of orcs and Uruk-hai, led by Shagrat and Gorbag respectively, begins to descend the stairs from the watch tower. Sam must now make a critical decision as the enemies draw near.
348:
The initial volley of arrows strikes the Rohan soldiers as they continue their charge. Gandalf, atop Shadowfax, swiftly turns around and pulls Pippin onto the horse with him. The Rohan forces are effectively decimating their enemies during this charge.

In a disturbing scene, Denethor stands on a table over Faramir, dousing himself with oil that cascades through his hair, down his face, and onto his robes. Faramir, struggling through his delirium, opens his eyes just as oil splashes onto his chest. Around them, bundles of oil-soaked wood are stacked, and servants stand by, holding flaming torches, waiting for Denethor's signal. With a nod from Denethor, these servants move closer to the pyre, torches in hand.

At that critical moment, Gandalf and Pippin, riding Shadowfax, burst into the Harrows. The servants, intimidated, retreat from the pyre. In a sudden act of madness, Denethor grabs a flaming torch and hurls it onto the pyre, igniting it instantly. Gandalf gallops towards the pyre, knocking Denethor down. Pippin leaps from Shadowfax onto the burning pyre and, with desperate strength, pushes Faramir off, sending them tumbling down the bundles of wood to the floor below. Pippin quickly douses the flames on Faramir's clothing.

Enraged, Denethor leaps across the pyre, attacking Pippin and pulling him away from Faramir. Fire rapidly spreads up Denethor's oil-soaked back. As he struggles with Pippin, Shadowfax rears up, striking Denethor and causing him to fall back onto the pyre. In a fleeting moment of clarity, Denethor looks into his son's eyes before flames engulf him. Suddenly, he leaps off the pyre, now a screaming ball of flame, and dashes out of the chamber, across the White Court of Minas Tirith, and plunges over a 700-foot sheer drop into the flaming city below.

Simultaneously, the Rohirrim gain the upper hand, slaughtering vast numbers of Orcs, many of whom are fleeing. Theoden, proud in his saddle, rallies his troops with a yell, but his expression shifts from joy to horror as he sees massive, elephant-like Mumakil approaching, each carrying a war-tower filled with Haradrim archers. Theoden circles amongst his men on horseback, trying to rally them as the battlefield descends into chaos with the Mumakil decimating the valiant Rohirrim.

Amid the chaos, Gandalf and Pippin share a moment. Gandalf looks at the small hobbit, and Pippin, full of fear, looks up at him questioningly. Gandalf, lost in thought, breaks off their gaze as Pippin continues to stare up at the old wizard's softened, peaceful face. Their moment is interrupted as the wooden doors shudder under another blow.

In the midst of the battle's turmoil, Theoden attempts to rally his men amidst the cries of men and horses. Suddenly, the Witch-king swoops down on his Nazgul, snatching Theoden and his horse into the air.
352:
In the vast expanse of Mordor, the attention of a group is drawn to the plain below, where thousands of orcs are seen marching away from Mount Doom. Meanwhile, 40 miles away, Mount Doom itself emerges dramatically from the plain, its base enveloped in ashen ruin and its towering cone shrouded in cloud.

Simultaneously, Frodo and Sam navigate a nightmarish terrain of volcanic rock and steaming fissures. As they struggle, Aragorn leads a force of 500 towards the imposing Black Gates of Mordor, positioning his troops strategically a half-mile away.

Frodo, weary and dehydrated, leans against a rock and attempts to drink from his water bottle, only to find it empty. Sam, always supportive, offers Frodo a small sip from his own bottle. Their eyes meet, acknowledging the daunting journey ahead. Sam helps Frodo to his feet, and they continue their painful trek across the tortured landscape, no longer wearing their orc armor. Frodo moves with difficulty, half-bowed and stumbling as if blind to the path, his right hand clutching his chest as if supporting a heavy weight, while his left hand occasionally rises to ward off unseen threats. Sam watches his friend with deep concern etched on his face.

As they journey, a malevolent voice torments Frodo's mind. Suddenly, Sam looks back just in time to see a ray of red light slicing through the gloom, sweeping over the barren landscape. Reacting quickly, Sam throws himself to the ground, but Frodo, mesmerized, turns toward the light. The red beam hits Frodo like a searchlight, causing him to crumple to the ground. All falls silent.

Meanwhile, at the Black Gates, Aragorn readies his men for confrontation. Gandalf, ever vigilant, nods at Aragorn, signaling readiness. Together with Legolas, Gimli, Eomer, Merry, and Pippin, they gallop toward the gates, stopping just 50 yards from the towering structure. The sound of chanting and clanging armor from thousands behind the gates fills the air, followed by the torturous noise of the massive gates slowly opening. Legolas, Merry, and Eomer observe with growing trepidation.

As the Eye of Sauron sweeps the plains, Sam rises to his feet. The Black Gates swing open, revealing Sauron's formidable army of 300,000. Aragorn, Gandalf, and their companions retreat to their small army, as the orc masses begin their slow advance. The Eye of Sauron turns its ominous gaze towards them.

Back with Frodo and Sam, Frodo's eyes snap open with a start. Sam crawls to him, and together, they struggle to their feet, continuing their arduous journey. Meanwhile, the massive orc army marches relentlessly towards Aragorn's men, who start to waver as they find themselves encircled by the enemy.
354:
Overwhelmed with relief and joy, Sam can hardly believe his fortune. Suddenly, out of nowhere, Smeagol collides into them, forcefully knocking Sam and Frodo to the ground. Smeagol then pounces on Frodo, his fingers tightly wrapping around Frodo’s throat and violently snapping his neck from side to side. Frodo struggles desperately to pry the bony, white fingers from his neck, but Smeagol's grip remains unyieldingly strong, tightening and squeezing the life out of him. In a swift action, a rock strikes the side of Smeagol's head, and Sam leaps onto a stunned Smeagol.

Amidst this, a fierce battle rages on between men and orcs. From high above Mordor, the Nazgul dive into the fray. The long-standing hatred between Sam and Smeagol erupts as they engage in combat. Sam is forced back, with Smeagol biting at him viciously. Using his feet, Sam manages to push Smeagol away and rolls to his knees just as Smeagol charges at him again. In a desperate move, Sam slashes out with Sting, slicing Smeagol across the stomach, causing him to stagger back in agony and scream in pain. Amidst the chaos, Sam frantically searches for Frodo.

Above, the eagles engage the Nazgul in battle. Gasping for breath, his lungs on the verge of exploding, Sam races up the slopes of Mount Doom in a frantic search for Frodo. Upon reaching the stone doorway of Sammath Naur, he staggers into the mountain, flinching from the fierce heat blasting down the tunnel. Driven by urgency, Sam lurches forward towards an orange glow deep within the heart of the mountain, where the heat is nearly unbearable.

There, Sam spots Frodo standing tense and still at the edge of the Crack of Doom, a deep, lava-filled chasm located in the heart of ancient Sauron’s forges, the most renowned in Middle-earth. The raging orange glare from the chasm casts Frodo as a black silhouette. Holding the Ring in his hand, Frodo raises it over the bubbling lava below, a strange expression on his face. The hum of the Ring grows increasingly louder, and as it pulls him closer to his body, Frodo turns to Sam. The Ring's influence is complete as Frodo, looking at Sam, puts it on and vanishes.

With a storm of wings, the Nazgul wheel around and hurtle towards Mount Doom. In the midst of the ongoing battle, Gandalf realizes that Frodo has been seen. Footprints move across the ash-covered cavern. Suddenly, Gollum smashes a rock down on Sam’s head, knocking him to the ground. Gollum then leaps onto the invisible Frodo, frantically clawing at him while riding on his back. Close by, Aragorn turns and faces an armoured troll wielding an enormous mallet. In a surprising move, Gollum lifts his hands to his face and bites down.
356:
The Nazgul screech in agony as they plummet from the sky, engulfed in flames, causing the earth to tremble so intensely that Frodo and Sam struggle to remain upright. Frodo falters and stumbles, but Sam quickly assists him to his feet. A smile graces Frodo's face, and Sam gazes down at him, observing Frodo's peaceful expression, relieved now that his burden has been destroyed.

As lava surges towards them, Frodo and Sam scramble onto a rock, which rapidly becomes an island amidst a sea of molten lava. Frodo closes his eyes momentarily before glancing at Sam, who is overcome with tears. Frodo wraps an arm around Sam's shoulder, the two tiny hobbits poised to face their end in the midst of a cataclysmic landscape. Lava erupts around them, and fireballs streak down from the sky. The scene gradually fades to black.

Suddenly, Gwaihir, the Great Eagle, soars towards the camera, carrying Gandalf on his back, with two more eagles following closely behind. Amid raining ash and molten rocks, the eagles courageously swoop down to snatch Frodo and Sam from their perilous perch. As Frodo is lifted away from the fiery volcano, the wind tousles his hair, and he slips into unconsciousness.

Frodo's eyes flutter open, slowly scanning his surroundings until they meet Gandalf's smiling face. Laughter fills the air as Merry and Pippin rush in, leaping onto the bed and enveloping Frodo in warm hugs. Gimli and Legolas join them, their joy evident, and Aragorn enters, completing the fellowship. Frodo's gaze eventually settles on a figure standing apart: it is Sam, and their eyes lock in a moment of deep connection.

The scene transitions to a sweeping view over the walls of Minas Tirith, racing towards the top of the city through a blizzard of white flower petals. The city, now restored, gleams brilliantly in white. The camera soars upward to reveal the Court of the Kings, packed with 4000 people and crowded along the wide path leading to the tower. The Crown of Gondor glints in the brilliant sunlight as Gandalf places it upon Aragorn's head. Aragorn smiles up at Gandalf before rising slowly and turning to face the cheering crowd, who clap and cheer deafeningly for their new king.

Aragorn sings for his people before leading a slow procession down the white paved path, the crowd bowing in respect. He passes Eowyn and Faramir, who bow before him, followed by Eomer stepping forward to pay his respects. Trumpets sound, heralding the approach of a procession of Elves, led by Legolas, dressed in shimmering silvers and whites. Legolas gestures behind him, and Aragorn's eyes scan the ranks of Elves, parting to reveal Arwen, her eyes shining with love, now mortal, carrying the standard of Gondor. Aragorn kisses her as Elrond watches with a smile, and they embrace. Together, Aragorn and Arwen walk through the crowd towards four small figures waiting nervously at the end of the path.
361:
In the heart of the great city, Gandalf stands quietly on a balcony, overlooking the sprawling metropolis below. Meanwhile, Pippin gazes in awe at the vast night sky. Gandalf observes the young hobbit, then joins him, their eyes drawn to the distant, jagged mountains of Mordor. Pippin, feeling unnerved, looks up at Gandalf, who responds with a small, self-deprecating smile. Together, they share a silent moment, watching the fiery sky above Mordor.

In a dramatic shift, giant Mumakil, bearing armies on their backs, march forward, while Corsair ships navigate up the river. Gandalf, now speaking almost to himself with a sense of impending doom, stands in the battle-scarred city of Osgiliath—the last stronghold between Minas Tirith and Mordor. Pippin, desperate for reassurance, looks up at Gandalf, who meets his gaze with silence, his eyes staring into the distance as if envisioning an enemy. In another part of the scene, a towering, hooded figure dressed in black is being armored by orc attendants. Gandalf's focus remains intense, as though confronting this enemy directly. Pippin, too afraid to voice his fears, continues to look up at Gandalf.

Elsewhere, Frodo screams as a Morgul blade pierces his shoulder. Pippin, pale at the memory, watches as Frodo and Sam scramble into a small gully beside a rough-hewn road. Gollum cautiously peers over the edge of the gully. The group then faces the sight of Minas Morgul, a massive, dead city perched on a rocky outcrop at the head of the Morgul valley. This corrupt and loathsome place emits a sickly luminous light, reminiscent of a corpse candle. Two huge, bestial stone statues guard the bridge leading to the city. Gollum, Frodo, and Sam hurry from their cover, scampering in the shadows towards Minas Morgul. Gollum glances up at the grotesque statues, while Frodo and Sam, filled with horror, see a narrow, near-vertical staircase cut into the rock-face directly in front of the gates of Minas Morgul.

As they begin to ascend the stairs, climbing higher and higher up the sheer western side of the Morgul valley towards the high peaks of the razor-like mountains of Mordor, Frodo suddenly staggers across the road, as if driven by a force beyond his own will. He lurches toward the bridge, heading towards Minas Morgul. Sam rushes to Frodo, catching him as he stumbles. Together with Gollum, they pull Frodo from the bridge, and he falls to the ground.

At that very moment, the ground quivers beneath them, and a great rumbling noise rolls across the landscape, echoing through the mountains. The once cold and dull Morgul valley erupts into violence and fury as flames surge from Mount Doom. In response, Minas Morgul emits a flare of livid lightning, with forks of blue flame shooting up from the tower into the sullen clouds above. Violent, fiery flashes light up the clouds over Mordor, and sharp thunder rolls across forty miles to Minas Tirith.
362:
In a state of terrified wonder, Pippin observes as Sam and Gollum guide Frodo to the stairs. Above Minas Morgul, the sky brightens intensely as the city erupts. Faces of soldiers and civilians in Minas Tirith peer from the city's parapets, witnessing the spectacle. Frodo and Sam collapse to the ground, their hands pressed to their ears, as a rending screech emanates from the city. The sound shivers, escalating to a piercing pitch beyond human hearing. The horrific cry eventually subsides into a long, sickening wail before falling silent. Frodo, overwhelmed, squeezes his eyes shut and clutches his shirt as if it were aflame.

The cavernous gate of Minas Morgul swings open, and a vast army marches out. Rank upon rank of armor-clad Orcs move swiftly and silently past Frodo and Sam in an endless stream of ragged columns, numbering 75,000, heading to war just below them. Frodo, Sam, and Gollum ascend the stony stairs, high above the marching army.

Meanwhile, Gandalf, deep in thought and calculating, strides purposefully through the back streets of the city. Pippin struggles to keep up, running to match Gandalf's determined pace. Suddenly, Gandalf halts and looks down at Pippin, then kneels and speaks to him earnestly, his hand on Pippin's shoulder. Gandalf watches as Pippin hurries away.

The scene shifts to an ancient stone bridge spanning the ruins of East and West Osgiliath, a once mighty Gondorian city. Ithilien Rangers patrol the bridge; West Osgiliath has fallen into disrepair, while East Osgiliath's desolation is stark, held by the forces of Mordor. Beneath the bridge, the camera tracks to the dark waters, capturing stealthy movements. Many boats carrying menacing Orcs quietly navigate down the river, steered by hunched figures using long oars.

Faramir, Captain of Gondor, gives commands to his soldiers. The Ithilien Rangers, weathered, hardened, and professional, take their positions, watchful and ready. As the boats approach, Faramir and his soldiers lie in ambush. When the boats reach the shore, hundreds of Orcs race onto the land. Faramir steps forward, sword drawn, but despite a fierce battle, he cannot halt the Orcs' advance as they cross the wide bridge into West Osgiliath.

The view shifts dizzyingly to look down on Minas Tirith, a thousand feet below, as Pippin scrambles desperately up the rocky mountainside. He clambers over a rocky ledge and ducks behind a stone wall, panting heavily. Nearby, an ancient stone ledge holds a great pile of firewood, secured in stacked bundles. Below, Gandalf waits tensely.

With stealth, Pippin pours oil over the wood and ignites it. Within seconds, the great pyre bursts into flames. The guards watch in total surprise as the flames erupt into the twilight sky, marking a significant moment in the unfolding drama.
368:
Young Don Price illuminates Edward with his flashlight, initiating a confrontation. Recollections of Edward consistently outperforming Don in football, baseball, and basketball underline their competitive history. Edward stands shocked, overwhelmed by the situation.

Summoning all his strength, Edward turns away, descending the front steps with determination. Lingering in the doorway, a woman feels a profound sense of remorse for the unfolding events before reluctantly retreating back inside. We follow Edward as he walks away, his eyes beginning to well up with tears. He exits the frame, leaving the sorority house looming in the background. Moments later, Edward re-enters the frame, his gaze fixed on the sorority house. As he shouts, we circle around him, intensifying the scene. From inside, Sandra and her sorority sisters watch through the curtains, intrigued by the commotion.

Meanwhile, in a classroom, an economics professor, dressed in tweed, continues his lecture. Sandra, seated among the students, appears disengaged. The professor activates the overhead projector without a glance, triggering a muffled chuckle from the class, which he remains oblivious to. A nudge from a classmate draws Sandra's attention upwards. The professor eventually notices the writing on the projector.

As Sandra walks with her books, she shakes her head in disbelief at the ongoing events. Her gaze lifts to the sky where a massive heart, written in the clouds, floats gently in the wind. Prompted by her sisters, a groggy Sandra peers out of the second-story window to see the lawn transformed into a sea of flowers. Edward stands in the midst of this floral expanse. Sandra, a mix of emotions swirling within her—confusion, joy, and fear—walks out to meet him. Unexpectedly, a tear trickles down her cheek.

From down the street, the adult Don Price approaches, embodying 230 pounds of athletic prowess, a fan of Skynyrd, and proud of his fraternity affiliations. His anger is palpable. Accompanied by a group of his fraternity brothers, Don confronts Edward, knocking him down with a punch. Edward rises but does not retaliate, only to be struck again by Don. Don remains unfazed and continues his assault, brutally beating Edward.

In a stark contrast, Don Price, seated on the toilet, struggles to relieve himself while perusing a new issue of Playboy. His effort intensifies as he strains unsuccessfully. Suddenly, he clutches his chest and collapses forward onto the tile, lifeless. The image of Don's deceased face on the tile is mirrored in The Eye.

Back at the confrontation, the beating of Edward persists. Despite the relentless attack, Edward manages to stand, bracing for more blows. Don, poised to strike again, is interrupted when Sandra removes her engagement ring. The action elicits gasps from her sisters and Don's brothers. Don stands frozen, his thoughts in turmoil. Edward, his eyes nearly swollen shut, remains poised for the next hit. Sandra approaches, handing Edward the ring. After a tense moment, Don storms off, leaving Sandra to tend to Edward's battered body, his head resting amidst the daffodils.

As the music swells to a crescendo, the scene shifts abruptly. Edward, now in a more serene moment, reaches for his glass of water, only to find Josephine has already anticipated his need and holds it out to him.
373:
Young Jenny Hill observes Edward, barefoot, departing from Spectre for the first time. The realization of who this woman is dawns on her. Edward attempts to say something more but is cut short as he closes the door behind him; however, it breaks off in his grasp. Inside, Jenny peers out, her expression a mix of surprise and irritation. Edward tries to reattach the door to its hinges, only for them to snap off. The door frame buckles, causing the entire shack to creak ominously. He then tries to prop the door against the frame, but it continues to slip. After adjusting the door's position, it momentarily holds before collapsing inward, smashing a small table. Karl then exerts pressure against the house's side until the door fits snugly.

With nails held between his lips, Edward installs new windows himself. The exterior features a white picket fence, charming in every detail. Inside, Edward is seen securing a hat rack to the wall in the foyer while Jenny leans against the doorframe, listening to his tale and watching him with profound affection. Once he finishes his work, Edward removes his hat from a chair and hangs it on the newly installed rack. The moment feels perfect, underscored by a meaningful look exchanged between them. As the last job is completed, Edward's purpose for staying diminishes. Jenny, questioning her own intentions, moves closer to him. Edward remains steadfast, and as Jenny takes his hand to hang his hat on the peg, she nears a kiss. However, Edward gently holds her back, leaving her stunned and humiliated. She pulls away as he starts to leave.

Jenny quickly finds a pen and signs the house's deed, handing it to Edward. He thanks her with a look and departs. Edward takes a final glance at the idyllic town before climbing into his car and starting the engine. As the vehicle drives away, the swamp begins to encroach on the house, enveloping it in a dense network of vines and mossy branches. Shoots burst through the planks of the porch, and snakes slither through the emerging marsh as day turns to night.

Meanwhile, Will and Jenny sit at her table with a pitcher of iced tea between them. Will smiles at the mention of a particular term, while Jenny grows more agitated by her silence. Will, sorting through his complex thoughts, turns to see his wife using a payphone. She hangs up after trying to call him. Will half-smiles, realizing the futility of his inquiry about his father's well-being, acknowledging that his father will not be okay. At the hospital, Dr. Bennett smiles while reviewing Edward's chart amid the ambient noises of pagers and doctors. Will half-smiles again as Dr. Bennett pats his shoulder and leaves. The camera lingers on Will and his father for a long time before Will takes out a pen and begins to make a list.
375:
In a captivating introduction, Edward is portrayed not merely as handsome and charming but as a marvel of natural forces, as if the universe conspired to create him. In a sudden motion, Edward plunges his hands into the water, seizing a catfish. He lifts it to his face and stares directly into its eyes. After a moment, the Beast ejects Edward's gold ring from its mouth.

Meanwhile, the sound of rain is interrupted by the ringing of a phone on a chair. The distinct, persistent tone indicates it's not from the U.S., but rather has a European insistence. As the phone continues to ring, a glance around reveals a mostly empty apartment, with only a few half-unpacked boxes scattered about. A cradle remains in its box, unopened. Keys jingle in the lock, and laughter echoes in the hallway before the door swings open, revealing Will, aged 29, struggling with four sacks of groceries, their bottoms disintegrating due to the rain. Josephine, 28, his wife, rushes past him to answer the phone and hands it to him, her face etched with concern. Half-stripped from the wet clothes, Will takes the call, his expression suggesting it won't bring good news. He covers the phone's mouthpiece and looks over at Josephine.

Later, on an airplane, Will occupies a window seat in the coach section with Josephine beside him, applying hand lotion. Hours into the flight, the cabin's lights are dimmed, and most passengers, including Josephine, are asleep. She rests her head on Will's shoulder, her hands nestled under her belly. Will notices a bored boy in the next row, using his hands to cast shadows on the seat back. The child skillfully creates silhouettes of a bird, a monkey, and finally a dog. The camera focuses on these shapes, revealing Edward as the creator of these shadows. Beside him, young Will, aged 6, sits in his pajamas on the floor. Between them is an end table lamp, its shade removed to project large shadows on the wall. Edward glances around to ensure his wife isn't listening, then leans in conspiratorially. Young Will beams, eager to hear the forbidden story. Edward starts recounting, counting names on his fingers as his hand moves through the light.

A flashlight sweeps past them, illuminating the night filled with the sounds of whirring and breathing, alive with energy. The moon hangs low, casting elongated shadows. Five kids walk by in silhouette, four of them holding flashlights, while the fifth stumbles and collides with young Edward, now 10 years old. The camera moves up behind the group to the gates of a mysterious location, finally focusing on the children peering through the gate. Edward turns to look at the eerie house. He hands his flashlight to Zacky and begins to climb the gate. After dropping to the other side, Edward, though scared, continues bravely forward.
377:
Will advances towards the door, his hand gliding along the textured wallpaper. Just before reaching it, he pauses momentarily, catching his breath, before he steps inside. Inside, Edward Bloom, aged 61, rests asleep on the bed. Though not as lively as before, his condition isn't as dire as one might have feared; the illness has progressed rapidly yet left him largely unchanged. The room is starkly devoid of medical equipment—no IVs, no monitors, nothing.

Approaching the bed, Will watches as Edward's eye slowly opens and struggles to focus. Edward attempts to speak but finds no words. His gaze shifts to a pitcher on the nightstand. Will pours water into a glass, assisting Edward in drinking from it, soothing his dry lips. A prolonged, tense moment passes, during which Will nearly speaks but then recalls the can of Ensure. He lifts it up; Edward recoils in response. After a brief pause, Edward rolls his eyes. Will opens the can, locates a straw on the nightstand, and Edward drinks as much as he can tolerate before pushing it away with difficulty swallowing.

Edward chuckles, the laugh quickly turning into a cough that worsens until another sip of water calms it. Taking the partially consumed Ensure, Will rises to leave. At the door, he pauses, smiling at his own jest. Closing the door, Will drinks the remainder of the Ensure, grimacing at the awful taste. As he heads towards the stairs, he passes an open door.

The camera lingers behind, revealing an eight-year-old Will in bed, his face dotted with chicken pox and smeared with pink calamine lotion. His voice, high and thin, strains as he sings, only for it to crack and drop a half-octave unexpectedly. Edward, embarrassed yet determined, continues singing, trying to match the baritone pitch. He tugs at his collar, then again, his face reddening. As he starts to undo the button, it pops off, followed by two more. One button strikes a chubby woman in the neck. Meanwhile, Edward's pant cuffs gradually rise, an indication of his rapid growth.

In another scene, young Edward lies in bed, his body supported by a complex system of pulleys and levers. He is surrounded by a dozen encyclopedias, with more scattered on the floor. He ponders over an article, complete with illustrations. The sound of a bat cracking signals a game-winning home run, followed by the crowd's enthusiastic cheers as the batter circles the bases. This moment marks our first significant encounter with grown-up Edward, whom we will follow from the ages of roughly 18 to 30.
378:
Football hero Edward leads his team to a triumphant victory on the field. Amidst the excitement, a pretty girl on the sidelines confesses the name of her secret love, prompting the other girls to squeal in delighted agreement. Don Price, observing from nearby, glowers disapprovingly.

In a dramatic climax, Edward takes an impossible shot from the other end of the court just as the buzzer sounds. The ball arcs perfectly, securing the win as the crowd erupts in celebration. Amidst the jubilation, Don Price remains aloof, the only teammate not joining the mob around Edward.

Later, Edward heroically rescues a dog from a burning house. The scene shifts abruptly to Don Price, who, frustrated, discards his failed lima bean plants into the trash. Nearby, two farmers shake their heads in disbelief at a massive hole punched through the side of a barn, shaped like a man but too large to be human. A stranger, not fully revealed, is implied to be responsible.

A mob of about 50 people gathers, many armed with shotguns. Among them is Don Price. As agreement ripples through the crowd, attention shifts when a voice speaks up. The crowd parts to reveal Edward Bloom, who stands confidently in the midst. Don Price's expression darkens with a glower.

Edward then ascends a steep hillside, reaching the entrance of a cave. Outside, buzzards fight over the remnants of a giant's feast, including broken barrels and cleaned bones. In a grave tone, Edward calls into the cave, and a thunderous voice responds, the force of which blows Edward's hair back.

As a rumbling grows, reminiscent of an approaching train, the ground trembles. Edward, prepared for a confrontation, picks up a stone, ready to emulate David against Goliath. From the cave emerges Karl the Giant, larger and more feral than any human, his beard reaching his elbow, his skin scratched and blistered, his clothes ragged and muddy. Karl looms over Edward, casting a shadow that blocks the sun.

Edward throws the stone, which harmlessly bounces off Karl. Contemplating his next move, Edward opts for a non-violent approach. Karl appears confused by Edward's change in tactic. Edward, hands at his sides and eyes closed, braces himself for possible consumption. Karl merely stares, unsure of what to do. After a tense moment, Edward cautiously opens his eyes to find Karl not preparing to eat him but sitting down with a resounding boom, appearing dejected.

In a bold move, Edward reaches up and shoves his hand into Karl's mouth, only for the giant to spit it back out. This interaction reveals Karl's sad truth: less a monstrous being and more a misunderstood giant man. Edward, showing empathy, sits beside him, marking a moment of connection and understanding between the two.
385:
The movie opens with a sense of discontent as the characters appear deeply unhappy. A woman, identified as teutonically pale with visible birthmarks on her face and arms, and notably braless, converses with Dieter in German. Her camera-side leg, wrapped in a bandage at the foot, is stained with dried rust-colored blood at the tip.

Transitioning to another scene, Walter drives attentively, his eyes fixed on the road, while listening to the Dude speak. The Dude's dialogue is occasionally interrupted by yaps from a dog in the back seat. As their car slows, Walter and the Dude turn their attention outside, following Walter's gaze.

The vehicle then pulls up the drive, and both Walter and the Dude exit, their eyes fixed on the front lawn in astonishment. They burst through the double doors with a loud bang. Inside, a man in a wheelchair spins around, his wheelchair humming as he moves towards Lebowski. From behind, Walter forcefully lifts the big Lebowski out of his wheelchair by his armpits, shoves him forward, and watches as he collapses to the floor, overcome with tears. Amidst this, the dog continues to yap.

The scene shifts to Quintana, who is loudly protesting at the edge of a bowling lane, being held back by O'Brien. Walter watches him with a feigned innocence. As O'Brien leads Quintana away, he provocatively makes hip-grinding motions. Both Walter and the Dude observe this, with Walter tilting his head and the Dude peering over his sunglasses.

Emerging from a bowling alley, Walter, Donny, and the Dude each carry their leatherette ball satchels. They are confronted by men in black, who are initially taken aback and then start conversing in German. The men briefly stop their discussion, only to resume shortly after. Walter, ignoring the Dude, addresses the Germans directly.

As tension rises, Donny becomes visibly frightened. Walter's intense gaze locks onto Dieter's, filled with hatred. Meanwhile, the Dude begins to search through his pocket, and raises his voice as he looks into his wallet, continuing to address the Germans.

The situation escalates when Dieter, with a metallic ring, draws a gleaming saber. In response, a leatherette satchel is hurled, striking Dieter in the chest and knocking him off his feet. Enraged, Dieter charges forward, but the attacker, caught off guard by Dieter's advance, manages to twist away. Grabbing Dieter's head, he pulls it to his mouth and bites down on Dieter's ear, maintaining his grip as Dieter screams in pain.

Simultaneously, another confrontation unfolds as Franz, wearing squeaky leather pants, unleashes karate kicks at the attacker. The attacker, still biting Dieter's ear, awkwardly circles to evade Franz's attacks. The tension peaks with the sound of tearing as the attacker and Dieter are forcibly separated, the attacker growling and shaking his head with Dieter's ear still in his jaws. Franz continues his aggressive kicks, each accompanied by a loud cry, while the Dude tries to dodge them, arms flailing.

In the aftermath, the Dude, also out of breath, gets up and jogs over to Donny, who is gasping for air. The Dude then dashes into the bowling lanes. Walter, seeking to comfort Donny, places a reassuring hand on his shoulder.
388:
Quintana's gaze meets Walter's, prompting a sad nod from Walter. Meanwhile, Jesus strolls away from the scene. The camera shifts to reveal the Dude lying prone on a rug, his eyes shut, a Walkman headset on his head. Absently, the Dude licks his lips while a faint rumbling sound, reminiscent of a bowling ball rolling down a lane, emanates from his Walkman. In his outstretched hand, he clutches a cassette case marked "VENICE." The moment the bowling ball strikes the pins, the Dude's eyes snap open to see a blonde woman towering above him. Beside her, a young man in paint-spattered jeans swings something at a carrier, and suddenly, a million stars burst across a dark expanse.

The Dude finds himself soaring over the city, arms outstretched, the wind rushing through his hair and billowing his bowling shirt. Ahead, the mysterious blonde woman rides away on the Dude's rug, resembling a sheik on a magic carpet, gradually diminishing in size. Looking up, the Dude lazily performs a few crawl strokes until he notices a bowling ball materializing in his hand. His initial bemusement quickly turns to concern about the ball's aerodynamics, but as its weight suddenly becomes apparent, it jerks his arm down and sends him plummeting.

From above, we watch the Dude hurtle toward the city, pulled down by the bowling ball. A reverse shot shows him zooming toward us out of the dark sky, eyes wide with terror. Led by the ball, he rushes past the camera, plunging us into darkness. Gradually, dull reflections emerge from the gloom, revealing glints on the surface of an approaching bowling ball. Pulling back, we see that the darkness was inside a ball return, and the gleaming ball is now being expelled upward, about to overtake us.

The Dude gazes upward at the looming ball, its mass casting a huge shadow across his face. The gleaming ball, marked by three black finger holes, rolls toward us. The largest hole—the thumb hole—passes directly over us, engulfing us once again in black. As the blackness recedes, we find ourselves spinning down a bowling lane, our perspective trapped within the thumb hole of the rolling ball. We see the bowler—the blonde woman—receding, still in her follow-through motion. The floor, ceiling, and the alley with pins at its end spin dizzyingly around us, approaching and receding repeatedly until we collide with the pins, clattering into darkness. The pins spin, strike each other, and fall, their sound emanating from the Dude's now askew Walkman, with one earpiece hanging off.
397:
As Fergus turns, he spots Dil approaching with a bottle in hand. He rushes toward her, and soon they are grappling in the shadowy park. Seizing her arm, Fergus leads Dil up the stairs to her apartment. His eyes fixed on her, he shakes her, his concern escalating to alarm, culminating in a slap to her cheek. Slowly, Dil opens her eyes.

Carrying her inside, Fergus positions Dil against a wall before checking the street through the window. In a gulp, Dil takes a hefty swig from a whiskey bottle, then weakly gestures toward a cabinet visible through the bathroom door. Fergus fetches the pills for her. Dil continues drinking from the bottle, wandering around the room before settling down, her gaze shifting to Fergus. Clutching the bottle between her knees, she stares blankly ahead. As Fergus moves toward the door, Dil rises to her feet, her eyes locked on him. There's an undeniable allure about her that draws Fergus back to her side, where he kisses her gently on the lips.

A photograph with a soldier's smiling face is visible as Dil seems enveloped in a sweet, narcotic haze. Sitting on the bed beside her, Fergus watches as Dil, lying back, strokes his hand. Her voice, dreamy and slurred, accompanies a woozy smile. In her intoxicated state, she attempts a playful slap at Fergus, then raises a shaky hand, pointing at him. Fergus tenderly strokes her cheek as Dil speaks in a slow, sleepy manner before her eyes shut and she drifts into a deep sleep. Fergus gazes down at her almost affectionately, and they rest together on the bed, fully clothed.

Upon waking, Dil quietly moves to Fergus's coat on a chair, searching the pockets until she finds his gun. Meanwhile, Jude is in bed when an alarm sounds, prompting her to turn it off. Dil, now at a drawer, pulls out several silk stockings and meticulously ties them to the corners of the brass bed. Gently, she secures Fergus's feet with the stockings, careful not to disturb his sleep. As she ties the final stocking, Fergus awakens; Dil quickly tightens the silk to secure it, speaking in an unusually quiet tone.

Fully dressed, Jude prepares in front of a mirror before retrieving a gun from under her bed and slipping it into her handbag. Back with Fergus, Dil is crouched beside him, his gun in her hand, while he stares at her and struggles against the bindings. Standing, Dil keeps the gun aimed at Fergus. On the street, Jude swiftly enters Maguire's waiting car.

Fergus continues to tug at the bindings as the figure of a judge appears in a window.
398:
A silhouette of a woman is visible. Jude and Maguire sit in a parked car across the street, their gaze fixed on a paper seller. Meanwhile, Fergus, bound, struggles fiercely against his restraints. Suddenly, he breaks free and speeds away in a car. Exhausted, Fergus collapses onto a bed. As Maguire's car circles the area once more, Fergus, still on the bed, strains and roars in frustration.

From Maguire's perspective, the door of a brothel swings open, and an elderly judge emerges. A car filled with his security men quickly accelerates toward him. In a swift move, someone snatches an item from the woman's pocket. The door is thrown open, and the person dashes across the street. Fergus continues his struggle against the bindings.

The judge approaches a car where a goon holds the door open for him. Maguire, rushing forward with a gun drawn, is spotted by the goon. As he runs, Maguire fires his weapon. The judge collapses, struck by a bullet. The goon, wounded in the arm, retaliates with an Uzi. Despite being hit, Maguire keeps shooting until he falls dead. Chaos erupts with screams filling the air. Jude, driving the car, hits the accelerator and speeds away.

Elsewhere, Dil, dressed in a soldier's cricket attire, resembles a sweet little boy. She approaches Fergus on the bed, pointing a gun at his head. Overwhelmed, she starts to cry and gently places the gun on his chest. She then works to free him from his bindings. Sirens wail as police cars approach. As Dil nearly frees Fergus, their faces close, he strokes her hair while she weeps, the sound of a song playing softly in the background.

Jude enters through an open door, her arms extended and holding a gun. Dil, rising from the bed, aims her gun at Jude and fires, hitting her. Jude falls to the floor, writhing in pain. Dil advances, still aiming at Jude, who manages to reach for her gun. Dil fires again, striking Jude in the shoulder, causing her to spin and her gun to fly away. Fergus screams from the bed. As Jude attempts to raise her gun, Dil shoots her multiple times until she collapses, fatally wounded, with blood covering her.

Dil then turns her gun on Fergus, squeezing the trigger. However, she halts her action. She looks at a photograph, walks over to it, and sits down in front of it. She then raises the gun to her mouth. Gently, Fergus removes the gun from her mouth and places it on a table. He helps Dil to her feet and leads her out the door. Returning to the room, Fergus passes Jude's body and looks out the window to see Dil staggering down the street, navigating through the gathered crowds.
404:
Returning to the room, she begins to gather her belongings, angrily throwing items onto the floor below: men's clothing, leather trousers, a suitcase, and even a teddy bear. Outside, Fergus observes a man on the street, comically clutching his possessions, a clear image of rejection. Dil, in a fit of rage, grabs a large goldfish bowl and hurls it down, shattering it into pieces on the pavement. The goldfish inside thrash helplessly in the street as, upstairs, Dil forcefully closes the window.

Back inside, Dil hands Fergus a glass, and he moves past a photograph to take a seat, glancing from Dil to the picture before nodding towards it. Dil averts her gaze into her drink, and suddenly, they are locked in an embrace. She stretches her entire body over him, and their passion escalates rapidly and intensely. Above them, the photograph appears to smile. Fergus lifts her dress with his hands, but Dil abruptly pulls away, only to approach him again. She unbuttons his shirt, her lips tracing a path down his chest. Despite Fergus's attempts to pull her closer, Dil's hand presses his head back while she undoes his pants. Her kisses travel down his body to his stomach. Fergus's eyes fix on the picture of Jody, whose gaze seems to pierce through him. Dil then lifts her head to kiss Fergus on the mouth, tears welling in his eyes.

In a quieter moment, Dil sits in front of the mirror, and Fergus stands behind her, gently brushing the hair from her face. They share a tender embrace before she returns to her seat at the mirror. Fergus leaves, and Dil reapplies her lipstick.

Later, at a bar, a singer in a blue dress performs as Dil and Fergus sit together, sipping cocktails adorned with umbrellas. Dave, wearing a neck brace, approaches them from behind and stands for a moment before stepping back. Fergus takes Dil's arm while the woman sings. Dil presses her cheek close to his, eyeing him sideways, then pulls back to look at him directly before dancing closer. The bar is filled with people singing along to the music, and Col performs on stage. Dave, sitting at the bar, sulks and then angrily slams his drink down before getting up to leave. As the act on stage concludes, Dil pulls Fergus back to the bar. Col, the barman, pours her a drink, smiling as he does so. Fergus takes a sip and grimaces while Dil throws hers back in one gulp. She then takes the bottle, refilling their glasses, and slams back another drink. Fergus sips his, but Dil tilts his glass back, forcing him to swallow it in one.

Finally, as they enter another room, Fergus moves slowly, his eyes drifting from the cricket whites hanging behind a curtain to the photographs displayed around.
406:
Fergus peers through a missing window and spots Dil in the elevator. As Dil passes a gap in the wall, she playfully blows a kiss towards him. Fergus then exits the room and navigates around the scaffolding. Upon seeing Fergus, Dil waves, takes a seat on some nearby bricks, and opens a hamper. Despite himself, Fergus can't help but smile. Dil pours him tea from a thermos she retrieves from the hamper. She then lowers her gaze, prompting Fergus to gently remove her glasses and observe her tear-filled eyes. Suddenly, Fergus rises to his feet. Deveroux, witnessing this, feels an unexpected chill. Fergus looks down at Dil and extends his arm towards her. She gathers her belongings and accepts his gesture, her face blooming into a broad smile. Fergus guides her down the scaffolding ramp, and together they descend from the construction site in the elevator. The lift comes to a jarring stop. Dil leans in and kisses Fergus, who then hears mocking catcalls behind him. As the elevator ascends, taking Fergus back to the site, he watches Dil depart.

Outside a hair salon, Fergus stands as Dil, inside, discards her smock and strides toward him. The other girls in the salon smile warmly. Fergus's gaze shifts between Dil and the approaching girls. Dil takes his arm, and they walk away together. Fergus becomes aware of a car tailing them and turns to check. They arrive at her door just as the car halts. Fergus kisses her, staring at her parted lips as if astonished at his own action. Dil then enters her home.

Inside a dimly lit room, Fergus switches on a small desk lamp. A voice breaks the silence, and he spots Jude seated in a shadowy corner, her hair now a deep brown. Fergus, speechless, watches as Jude circles the room. She reclines on the bed next to him, removes a black leather glove, and places her hand on his crotch. Fergus firmly moves her hand away. Jude locks eyes with him intensely. In a swift move, Fergus leaps off the bed. Jude moves her lips close to his, barely touching. In a sudden action, Fergus grabs her hair and pulls her head back. Jude, in response, draws a gun and presses it between his teeth. Fergus locks eyes with her. Quietly, he speaks, and Jude kisses him briefly, the gun still at his temple. After this tense moment, she leaves. Fergus remains standing in the darkness.

Later, Fergus approaches the hair salon, flowers hidden behind his back. He observes from outside. Suddenly, the chair swivels around, revealing Jude instead of Dil. Fergus freezes in place. He sees Jude, her smile radiant, conversing with someone behind him, turning out to be Dil. Jude turns in her chair, her smile directed at something or someone behind Fergus. He turns around to find Jude standing there. Abruptly, Fergus stands, throws some money on the table, seizes Dil's arm, and forcefully escorts her out of the salon.
419:
The game concludes, and Bert is already positioned in the front room, seated at a table with a drink in hand. He observes Eddie as he passes by on his way to the bar. Eddie glances at Bert, who, amused by the interaction, rises from his seat and joins Eddie at the bar. Bert chuckles and gestures to the bartender for another round before starting to leave. Eddie then exits, and the sound of a ship's horn echoes in the distance.

Eddie proceeds past the piers and warehouses, making his way to a small waterfront bar named Arthur's Pool Hall. The atmosphere inside Arthur's is oppressive and stifling. A handful of lonely drinkers, likely dock workers, hunch over their beer bottles at the bar. In the back, a pool table stands ready. As Eddie steps inside, he notices two burly men, each holding cue sticks, observing a pale, skinny young man as he aligns himself for a shot. The men exchange assessing glances before the young man successfully makes his shot.

Eddie approaches the rack, selecting a cue for himself as one of the other players begins to put away his. The young man then executes his break shot, forcefully sinking the nine ball into the pocket. He looks up at Eddie with a snide grin. The other two men, having lost, stand around silently watching the game. Eddie tosses a coin onto the table and later retrieves it while the young man prepares for another game by racking the balls.

With his cue chalked and ready, Eddie forcefully breaks, sending the cue ball crashing into the pack. The nine ball drops into the pocket, leaving everyone, especially the young man, in a state of shock. Eddie, now out of control, shoots with the precision and control he had displayed at Ames, completely oblivious to the increasingly hostile stares from the men gathering around the table. He successfully makes a series of challenging shots, including tricky combinations, and concludes with yet another impressive combination shot.

The young man, visibly nervous, fumbles in his jacket for money. All attention shifts to Eddie. Sensing the imminent outcome, the young man pays up, places his cue on the table, drops the cash, and hastily exits. Another man, Turk, a thick-fleshed individual with an obscene appearance and a mocking smile, steps forward. As Eddie surveys the silent, glaring men surrounding him, his initial fury transforms into fear. He wipes his mouth with his sleeve and attempts to retreat but finds no escape route, prompting a casual move toward the table.

Turk then takes the bills from the table and forcefully stuffs them into Eddie's breast pocket. The situation escalates as the men drag Eddie into the men's room and forcefully push him against the ground-glass partition.
420:
A man's cheek is pressed against the glass, with foggy silhouettes visible behind him. Suddenly, Eddie, his mouth gaping, lets out a blood-curdling scream. He screams once more. Released, his arms go limp, and he collapses to the floor. Meanwhile, the bartender, having turned away from the scene, walks back to the bar in the front room. The ship's horn resounds again, followed by a knock at the door.

In a darkened room, Sarah, clad in her robe and slip, sits alone, caught in a drunken stupor. She rises to answer the knock, her eyes puffy and her face slick with sweat. Opening the door, she finds him leaning against the wall, his arms folded across his chest, one hand covering the other. Stunned, Sarah moves toward him, enveloping him in a comforting embrace. He begins to cry, and she holds him tightly.

Later, Sarah observes Eddie, his hands now immobilized in plaster casts, struggling to find sleep. He attempts to move his arms, as if to ward off an unseen threat. Sarah approaches him, gently stroking his head.

At the breakfast table, Sarah pours coffee for Eddie, who tries unsuccessfully to lift the cup to his lips. Frustrated, he drops the cup, the coffee spilling to the floor, and rises from the table. Sarah quietly kneels and meticulously cleans up the mess. Their apartment is now orderly and tidy, and Sarah has regained her sobriety.

Seated at her table, Sarah types while Eddie, standing by the window, awkwardly tries to scratch his back. He moves to the table, using his mouth to extract a cigarette from the pack. His eyes briefly meet hers, a silent request for a match. She lights it for him, and as she does, he steals a glance at the sheet of paper in her typewriter.

Eddie begins to struggle with the buttons of his shirt. Sarah quickly rises to assist, but he gently rebuffs her help. She watches him wrestle with the button before he throws his arms up in a gesture of defeat. As Sarah helps him with his shirt, he tenderly takes her face in his hands and kisses her.

Emerging from the apartment doorway, Sarah and Eddie step into a warm and beautiful day. Sarah carries a basket, and Eddie seems genuinely happy to be out with her, momentarily forgetting his casts. They choose a spot overlooking the river, spread out a blanket, and settle down. Eddie reclines on the grass, his gaze fixed on Sarah. Together, they bask in the sunshine, their bodies relaxed and at ease. Eddie's eyes lower as he leans back, simply staring at her.

Finally, Eddie approaches the door to Sarah's apartment, poised to knock.
424:
Bert settles into a chair, beginning his evening in the dimly lit room. Nearby, Findley, with a gleam of mischief in his eyes, dramatically empties a cloth bag onto the table, revealing three billiard balls. Eddie, feeling the pressure, takes his shot. The red ball he strikes bounces off the table's shoulder and delicately nudges the third ball.

As the game progresses, Findley steps away from the table to the bar, leaving Bert and Eddie to themselves. He gestures towards a statue positioned on a table behind the couch—a figure of Pan, complete with horns piercing through its curly hair and goat legs protruding from its waist. After making his shot, Findley carefully lays his cue on the table and joins the bar.

Eddie, now without his coat, nervously rubs his hands together. Feeling the tension, Bert turns away from Eddie, joining Findley at the bar. Eddie stands momentarily helpless before deciding to approach Findley, who is pouring himself a drink. As Eddie reaches into his pocket, he suddenly recalls giving all his money to Sarah. Determined, he rushes up the stairs, bursts into the room, and swiftly bypasses Sarah, who lies on the bed facing away yet awake. He retrieves the money from her purse and leaves, closing the door forcefully behind him. He then leaps down the stairs, taking two steps at a time.

Bert watches Eddie with a simmering rage as they prepare to continue their game. As the previous game concludes, Sarah quietly descends the stairs and stands at the rail, listening intently. Bert, casual yet dominant, has his feet propped up on the couch. Eddie turns and spots her, his eyes squeezed shut and fists pressed to his temples in frustration. He moves to the billiard table, visibly shaken. Sarah, feeling defeated, turns and ascends the stairs once more.

The men return to their game, undeterred. Bert, now deeply satisfied, dons his coat and settles down to observe the ongoing match. Nearby, a visibly shaken Findley sinks into a leather swivel chair. A bucket of iced champagne stands ready on the desk, awaiting consumption. Findley takes a drag from his cigarette, eyeing Bert, who slouches impatiently across from him. Eddie, leaning against a nearby wall, remains silent and morose before eventually moving to leave. Findley and Bert watch him depart.

Eddie waits at the bottom of the stairs for Bert, then suddenly exits the house. Bert watches him for a moment before following. Upon entering his suite, Bert removes his overcoat and pauses at the door connecting his room to Sarah's, a hint of hesitation in his movements. He pours a drink, quickly downs it, walks to the door, listens carefully, and then opens it without knocking. There, Sarah sits on the bed, composed and expectant.
425:
In her suite, a drink is clutched in her hand and a suitcase rests beside her on the bed. Bert bursts into the room and confronts her. Sarah's voice remains subdued and controlled throughout their encounter. Towering over her, Bert menacingly pulls a wad of bills from his pocket. He then seizes her, attempting a kiss, but she remains cold and unresponsive in his arms. Frustrated, he releases her, and she slumps back onto the bed. Without a word, he turns and retreats to his room. She pauses briefly before extracting a cigarette from a pack, rising, and following him.

In the reflection of the bathroom mirror, Bert is seen asleep on his bed, surrounded by disheveled and tossed sheets. Sarah, clad in her slip, enters the bathroom and closes the door behind her.

Meanwhile, Eddie returns, striding through the lobby without acknowledging the nearby uniformed policeman, and stops at the reception desk. The concierge, seemingly dazed, eventually hands him an item. Eddie then hastens toward the elevators.

Upon entering the suite, Eddie notices money scattered on Sarah's bed. He places his cue case down and turns to see a crowd gathered in the next room. Bert, still in bed, is being interrogated by a plainclothesman taking notes. A photographer, positioned by the bathroom, readies his flash camera. Bert's attention shifts when he spots Eddie through the open doorway, but a uniformed policeman prevents Eddie from entering further.

Eddie eventually manages to enter and surveys the detectives around Bert's bed. The photographer's flashbulb illuminates the scene as he captures an image of the bathroom. Pushing past the photographer, Eddie is struck by the sight of Sarah's lifeless body laid out on the tiled floor. He kneels beside her, reaching out only to retract his hand in anguish. From behind, Bert appears at the bathroom door. Eddie, eyes tightly shut, writhes in pain as he listens to Bert's words. Abruptly, he launches himself at Bert, clutching his throat and pushing him backward. A policeman intervenes, separating them, though Eddie momentarily breaks free.

In another scene, Minnesota Fats sits absorbed in his afternoon newspaper. Nearby, Big John practices shots at a pool table. Bert, donning dark glasses, stands by the cashier's cage, rolling dice into a leather shaker. The sound of the dice reverberates through the quiet, dim atmosphere of Ames. Spotting Eddie pushing through the glass doors, Bert tenses and signals his men for protection with a fearful glance. Eddie, with his cue case under his arm, marches directly toward Bert. After a tense moment of staring, Eddie shifts his attention to Minnesota Fats, who stands ready to play. Eddie begins assembling his cue and moves to join Fats at the pool table.
426:
In the bustling pool hall of Ames, the atmosphere is tense as the balls are already set up and ready on the table. Willie efficiently gathers the betting money from the players and flips a coin to decide the first move. Preacher and Big John pull up chairs to join the onlookers around the table, while Bert chooses a seat further away, close to the coat rack. Willie taps Fats on the lapel, signaling it's his turn to break. With a swift motion, Sausage sends the cue ball rolling down the table, initiating the game instantly.

Fats executes an impressive break, positioning the cue ball precariously near the far corner pocket. Eddie surveys the arrangement of the balls on the table before setting his cue aside and heading to the washroom. As he sprinkles powder on his hands, he catches a glance from Bert. Quickly returning, Eddie grabs his cue and forcefully banks a shot into the pack of balls. The one ball sinks into a pocket as the others scatter across the table, drawing applause from the gathered crowd.

Eddie moves with agility to his next shot, engaging in conversation with Bert as he plays. Meanwhile, Bert and Fats exchange meaningful looks. Eddie continues his game with focus while Fats, waiting for his turn, puffs steadily on his cigarette. Bert shifts uncomfortably in his seat as the sound of pool balls colliding and rolling along the table's track fills the air. Eddie's shot finds its mark, and he casts a significant glance at Fats, who lowers his eyes and continues smoking.

The balls are re-racked, and Eddie dominates the table, sinking shots effortlessly, some challenging, others straightforward. Bert and Fats share uneasy glances as Eddie moves around the table with the precision of a hawk. Fats, now with his jacket off and tie loosened, takes his turn, chalks his cue, and attempts a difficult shot but misses. Eddie, ignoring Fats, steps up to take his shot under Bert's watchful eye. Eddie's skill is on full display as he quickly and accurately makes all his shots, leaving Fats to watch in a state of despair.

The clock above the door shows six o'clock as Fats remains seated, a drink in hand. Eddie, with assistance from Preacher, slips into his jacket and thoughtfully unscrews his cue. Bert's bodyguards stand by, ready for action, while Fats listens, his head bowed. Bert halts his men with a simple hand gesture and attempts a friendly smile. Eddie, after storing his cue, locks eyes with Bert before turning his attention to the visibly disheartened Minnesota Fats. Fats looks up at Eddie, who then picks up his cue case and heads towards the door. He pauses momentarily to take in the sight of the now-empty tables before exiting.

As normalcy returns to Ames, Fats dons his coat while Henry begins sweeping the floor. Bert, resuming his authoritative position, settles back into his chair overlooking the pool hall, sipping his glass of milk.
429:
As the crowd's applause intensifies, the billiard balls roll steadily towards the pockets during a thrilling game at Ames. Eddie, basking in the glory, proudly accepts the cheers from the gathered pool sharks, his face alight with excitement. After a triumphant moment, he slaps the chalk onto the table and settles back into his seat, his spirits high.

Meanwhile, Fats slowly rises from his chair and hands a sum of money over to Charlie. It's nearly four in the morning as Fats, after a brief hesitation, reaches into his pocket to pull out more bills. The anticipation builds as both Fats and Eddie stand, shedding their jackets in preparation for another intense round of play.

In the back room, Preacher enters, clutching a paper bag filled with bottles to his chest. He approaches a poker table where six men are deeply engaged in their game. He leans in to whisper urgently into the ear of one of the players, Bert Gordon. Bert, appearing as a conservative businessman perhaps out for a casual evening with friends, only distinguished by his dark glasses and his choice of milk over alcohol for his ulcer, nods to Preacher, who then departs. Bert pauses, lost in thought, before standing and taking a sip of his milk.

Around Charlie's seat, a sea of cigarette butts litters the floor. Charlie stubs out yet another cigarette and reaches for a fresh one almost immediately. Nearby, Eddie finishes off his bottle of bourbon and throws a jaunty glance at Bert, who is quietly observing from his chair.

Eager to continue, Eddie wriggles out of his seat, driven by the thrill of winning. However, his next shot misses the mark. Bert sighs as another player successfully pots their ball. Fats, meanwhile, opens a new bottle of whiskey as the game relentlessly continues. Shots keep being made, and the hands of the clock on the wall race towards eight in the morning.

The voice of Sausage breaks the tension, marking the end of a game. Ames, now empty except for the players and the staff, feels quieter, more intense. As Fats leans over to take his shot, Henry pulls down the Venetian blinds, casting the room into a dimmer light. Bert, visibly unnerved by Fats' unsettling demeanor, presses a hand to his temple.

A momentary lull in the game allows Fats and Eddie to exchange cold, hard stares—Fats clutching his glass, Eddie his bottle. Eddie takes another swig of his drink and returns to the game, while Bert hands more money to Charlie. Bert then tucks his billfold back into his coat pocket.

Eddie, now visibly tired, rests his hands on the table and looks up at Bert's cool, impassive face. Bert slightly adjusts his position by moving his chair a few inches and sitting back down. Eddie, watching a shot sink into the pocket, heads to the water cooler for a drink. Meanwhile, Fats begins distributing his losses across the table.

Eddie then stands in front of Fats and Bert, awaiting a response. The two share a glance but remain silent. There is still no answer, no sign of yielding. Eddie starts to return to his seat but suddenly turns back, his face breaking into a weary, clowning smile.
436:
As Don wipes his hands with the towel extended by the attendant, the latter gazes at Don's lapel with a puzzled expression. Don then tips the attendant with a fifty-cent piece. Although the attendant doesn't understand the jest, he laughs out of habit and opens the door to the bar. Don proceeds slowly from the washroom towards his table but suddenly halts, looking around. He becomes acutely aware that everyone in the room, including the waiter, the head waiter, the piano player, and a couple near the piano, are fixated on him.

M.M.'s escort approaches Don aggressively, grabbing his coat. Don retrieves a bag from beneath his coat and hands it to a woman, only for M.M.'s escort to snatch it away abruptly. In a swift motion, Don presents a bill and pulls out the remaining money from his pocket, which the waiter quickly grabs. By this time, they have maneuvered Don to the door.
