Jack, seeking balance, leans on a railing and gazes out to sea, his hair tousled by the wind. Rose approaches him across the deck, and Jack turns to face her with a smile. As Rose walks closer and reaches out, they clasp hands, and Jack gently draws her closer. Rose closes her eyes, and Jack, still holding her hand, assists her onto the bow's rail platform. Together, they step onto the lowest rung of the railing, and Rose spreads her arms out like wings, her shawl fluttering backward in the wind. Jack wraps his hands around her waist as she opens her eyes, with black smoke rising from the ship's funnels as they stand high above the water. Jack tenderly takes Rose's hands, leaning close to her, and then folds her arms around her waist. She turns his face toward hers, and they share a kiss, with Rose gently placing her hand on the back of Jack's neck.

The scene shifts to the sunken Titanic resting at the ocean's bottom. Elderly Rose, on a salvage vessel, turns away from a monitor to speak to the crew. She gazes back at the monitor displaying the underwater image of the fireplace in her former suite, which then transforms back to its past state as young Rose and Jack enter. Jack hurries to a painting, while Rose opens a safe and hands him the Heart of the Ocean necklace. Jack, examining the faceted blue diamond, shakes his head and then faces Rose. Later, Rose removes a butterfly cone from her hair and shakes it out to her shoulders. Jack moves a settee to the room's center, piling one pillow atop another. Sitting near it, Jack opens a canvas bag and takes out a knife and a thin stick of charcoal, which he sharpens. As Rose enters the room, holding a kimono closed with one hand and playfully twirling a sash, Jack smiles. Rose approaches him; he leans back, and she tosses him a dime. Stepping back, Rose lets the kimono slip from her shoulders to the floor, then, naked, runs her fingertips over her thigh.
716:
As water floods the cargo hold, it forcefully knocks down two stewards. Simultaneously, in the front well deck, Jack forcefully pushes Rose back as chunks of ice break off from the ship, landing on the deck and causing two men to be knocked down. The ship continues its path alongside the iceberg. In the engine room, water rushes in as a man scrambles past furnace stokers who are swept across the floor. Jack races to the starboard railing, watching as the back of the ship moves alongside the iceberg.

Murdoch sprints to the bridge and operates a lever, triggering the closure of the hydraulic watertight doors in the engine room. A man gestures to the stokers, prompting workers to run through the rising water and crawl under the descending doors. One man follows others through a doorway, but the door shuts, trapping several stokers behind. As the rest escape past the closing doors, the last remaining stoker makes a desperate dive under the final door and tumbles out just as its steel hatch slams shut. On the bridge, a row of lights on the watertight door indicator panel illuminates. Murdoch, after staring at the panel, turns away.

On the passenger deck, a man and a woman lean over the starboard rail, peering at the iceberg. In the crow's nest, Fleet turns to Lee. Jack, Rose, and the two men observe the iceberg from over the railing, now positioned behind the ship. On the bridge, Murdoch speaks to Moody, who glances at a wall clock as he leaves. Hichens turns toward the bridge door as Captain Smith enters. Murdoch follows Smith onto the bridge deck, where Smith looks down from the bridge deck shelter before standing at the bridge railing, overlooking the front well deck. Murdoch quickly departs.

In his cabin, Fabrizio leaps from his bunk into inch-deep water and switches on the overhead light. His roommates follow as he opens the door. Tommy approaches. The countess emerges from her stateroom and halts a mustached steward. Andrews rushes past, clutching blueprints. Smoke billows from the ship's massive funnels as people congregate on the decks. Tommy, Fabrizio, and others chase running rats down a hallway. Cal and Lovejoy exit the sitting room and detain a dark-haired steward in the hallway, who then hurries off. On the upper deck, a dark-haired man tosses a chunk of ice to a blond man, who tosses it back.

Smith, Moody, Andrews, and Murdoch walk past Jack and Rose. The master-at-arms examines Jack's drawings, which Cal abruptly snatches away. Jack and Rose, holding hands, approach Lovejoy, who stands in the hallway. Lovejoy walks beside Jack and discreetly slips the heart of the ocean into Jack's coat pocket. Lovejoy then follows Rose and Jack into the sitting room, where Cal steps forward and exchanges a glance with Lovejoy, who responds with a raised eyebrow.
719:
As the elevator ascends, Rose surveys her surroundings while wading through the water. She notices a sign above a doorway before proceeding down a short corridor and then turning into a longer hallway. Meanwhile, in an office, Jack, still handcuffed to a pipe, climbs onto a desk as the water level rises around him. Rose pauses at a staircase, then turns left and walks down another corridor, navigating through floating furniture. The lights in the hallway flicker intermittently.

Jack turns his attention toward the closed office door. Rose, after turning around, quickly approaches the same door and steps inside. Overwhelmed by relief and urgency, she kisses Jack. She then begins a frantic search through a cabinet filled with keys and pulls out a desk drawer, turning to Jack with a hopeful look; they share smiles amidst their dire situation. Despite her efforts, Rose finds nothing in the drawer. As the bow of the ship begins to sink, she scans the office, now feeling the pressure of time. She moves a desk chair out of her way to reach Jack again, kissing him before leaving the office.

Rose moves down a long, dimly lit corridor, the water now reaching her waist. She ascends to the D deck, running through the hallways until a mustached man approaches her but then quickly retreats. Left alone, she gazes down the now-empty corridor. As she takes a few steps forward, the lights suddenly go out, leaving her breathless and leaning against the wall for support. When the lights return, she stands up only to encounter a dark-haired steward who rounds the corner and grabs her. In a swift reaction, she punches him, causing him to stumble back and touch his bloody nose before he hurries away. Overwhelmed, Rose leans back against the wall, blinking and staring ahead.

Regaining her resolve, Rose moves forward, unwraps a fire hose, and uses it to shatter the glass of a case, retrieving an axe. With the axe in hand, she runs toward the E deck stairs. On the ship's bridge, Captain Smith leans over the railing, observing the flooding bow and the front well deck. Meanwhile, Rose carefully descends the E deck stairs, stopping just above the water that has risen over several steps. She steps into the water, grabs an overhead frame, and ducks her head to peek into the hallway. She looks both ways down the flooded corridor before stepping back and hanging the axe on the frame. Removing her long sweater and letting it drop, she grabs the axe with one hand and wades into the water. Using a long pipe along the ceiling to propel herself forward, she navigates through the chest-deep water back into the office, the axe held high.

Inside the office, Rose holds out the axe toward Jack, who stretches the chain of his handcuffs along the water pipe. With determination, Rose lifts the axe and moves to a wooden cabinet. With a powerful swing, she strikes the cabinet door, attempting to free Jack from his restraints.
723:
As the movie unfolds, Lovejoy, with a scowl on his face, follows Cal across the bridge. They brush past an officer as they move. Simultaneously, Ismay stands near a collapsible lifeboat, observing a crowd of passengers on the lower side of the bridge before turning his attention back to the collapsible. Seizing the moment as Murdoch turns away, Ismay discreetly takes a seat on the collapsible. Murdoch, upon facing the collapsible, finds himself locked in a gaze with his mate, who looks ahead. With a stern expression, Murdoch motions downward with both arms, signaling the seamen who then lower the collapsible. As it descends below the deck, Ismay looks up.

Elsewhere, Lightoller quickly lifts a young girl into a lifeboat. Rose turns to Jack, and Cal, observing the interaction, shifts his gaze between them. In a swift move, Cal yanks the blanket off Rose and thrusts it towards Jack, then gently drapes his own coat over Rose's shoulders. As Cal reaches to stroke Rose's hair, she recoils, stepping away. Jack moves closer to her side. A crewman then takes hold of Rose, guiding her towards the lifeboat, with Jack and another crew member assisting her into it. As Rose clings to Jack's outstretched hand, a crewman intervenes, pushing Jack back. The lifeboat jolts, beginning its descent towards the water, with Cal and Jack watching from the rail as Rose gazes back at Jack. Jack's eyes move from Cal to the lowering boat.

Rose, now in the lifeboat, looks around, her eyes trailing up to the ropes threading through the pulleys. She looks back at Jack, then to her right, where a young girl waves at her father while her sister cries. On the deck above, a crew member, arms raised and voice loud, shouts orders. Rose's gaze returns to Jack, who remains beside Cal. In the night sky above, a flare bursts and fades, momentarily lighting up Rose's face. More flares streak across the sky above Jack.

Suddenly, Rose moves to the edge of the lifeboat and leaps out, clinging to the ship's rail several decks below where Jack stands. Two crew members quickly pull her back on board. Rose then dashes along the lower deck while Jack, after turning, sprints down the main deck, weaving past passengers and crew, then rushes inside to race down the grand staircase. At the base of the stairs, Rose rushes into Jack's arms, and they embrace, sharing a kiss that leads to another hug.

From an upper landing, Cal watches them. Lovejoy approaches, grabbing Cal's shoulder and pulling him away from the railing. As they move, Cal swiftly grabs Lovejoy's gun and dashes towards the stairs, pulling Rose away from Jack. Rose and Jack flee, with Cal tearing down the stairs in pursuit.
725:
In the gripping tale of a ship's final moments, a woman expertly swims across a water-filled corridor that almost touches the ceiling. Upon reaching the stairs, she pauses, turns around, and watches as a man joins her. Together, they climb the stairs to safety. Meanwhile, Tommy and Fabrizio, at the forefront of a surging crowd, leap over a barrier with agility. On the deck, crew members meticulously lift a lifeboat using long oars configured as a ramp.

Murdoch, upon reaching the deck, rushes to a stairwell, his eyes fixed on the turbulent water below. Simultaneously, Cal dashes through a doorway, only to be knocked into the flow of a running crowd by a man. Cal recovers, joins the throng, but soon halts, then scales a nearby platform to survey the crowd. His gaze falls on a young girl crying; he briefly observes her before walking away. Inside the ship, Rose and Jack sprint up a staircase, desperate to reach safety. In another scene, one man plunges into the water, while another hangs perilously from a rope.

Cal reappears, approaching the scene just as Murdoch, with a quick motion, extracts money from his pocket and tosses it at Cal. In a swift reaction, Murdoch shoves Cal aside. Elsewhere, a man makes a daring leap towards a lifeboat, only to be met with a gunshot from Murdoch. Amidst the chaos, another man shoves Tommy forward, leading to Murdoch shooting Tommy. Fabrizio, grief-stricken, kneels beside his fallen friend.

Murdoch, reflecting on his actions, steps back towards the ship's edge, glancing to his right and then at the crowd of passengers. Cal, filled with rage, glares at Murdoch. In a solemn moment, Murdoch stands at attention, salutes, then tragically turns the gun on himself, firing and falling into the ocean.

Cal, undeterred, rejoins the crowd. On the opposite side of the ship, crew members tip another lifeboat onto the deck below. Cal, spotting a crying girl, picks her up and moves towards the crowd of passengers. He quickens his pace, hands the girl to a woman, and then climbs into the lifeboat, settling down. The woman, in turn, hands the girl back to Cal.

Jack and Rose, still fighting for survival, dash towards the smoking room. Inside, Andrews stands near the fireplace, his eyes locked on a painting. He hands Rose his lifebelt, and she embraces him in gratitude before rushing through a revolving door. Jack, taking a moment to look back and nod, follows Rose.

Elsewhere, a steward, carrying two lifebelts, hurries towards the Grand Staircase. Outside, a sailor operates a winch as others assist in turning over the top of a lifeboat. Captain Smith observes this, then turns to see a man wading through shallow water on the deck. A woman holding a baby approaches the captain, who briefly stares at her before stepping away. Another man with a lifebelt runs up to the captain, who stops to glance at the lifebelt before walking off.

Knee-deep in water, Captain Smith steps onto the bridge, his gaze lingering on the ship's wheel and various instruments before he enters the wheelhouse and closes the door. The ship's string quartet concludes their performance, with three members packing up their instruments and walking away as people rush past. However, Hartley, the violinist, presses his instrument against his neck and begins to play once more, offering a poignant soundtrack to the unfolding tragedy.
727:
As the ship begins its tragic descent, passengers tumble onto the lower deck. Within the ship's interior, furniture like tables and chairs violently collide with people trying to swim to safety. Rising water forces some individuals upward along the staircase, while others find themselves trapped against the ceiling of the lower deck. At the top of the staircase, an intricately carved wall clock succumbs to the rising flood and disappears beneath the turbulent water.

Seawater forcefully enters through the ship's openings, pushing passengers back inside the sinking vessel. Amidst the chaos, Fabrizio, equipped with a life vest, swims past a shattered window. He struggles against the suction that slams him against the ship's side but manages to brace himself on the window frame. Attempting to reach safety, he stretches for a railing but loses his grip and slips. Determined, he turns and swims towards open water. Meanwhile, Rose falls onto a lower deck and is helped up by the ship's baker.

Jack and Rose find each other again amidst the throng of people. In a nearby lifeboat, Cal aggressively fends off desperate passengers with an oar. The tension escalates as several cables holding a funnel break, causing it to whip wildly against the water. Cal watches in horror as the massive funnel begins to topple. In the water, Fabrizio, along with others, looks up just in time to see the funnel crash down upon him, generating a wave that sweeps away numerous people.

In another lifeboat, a man tries to climb aboard, but Cal cruelly pushes him back into the sea. Jack and Rose struggle through the dense crowd, slowly ascending another staircase. Inside the ship, passengers desperately cling to columns at the top of the grand staircase. A surge of water races down an empty corridor, demolishing furniture and ripping doors from their frames.

Behind the Titanic, occupants of a lifeboat row with all their might as the ship's giant propellers emerge from the water. Desperate passengers jump from the back of the Titanic, which is now dramatically tilted several stories above the ocean surface. Jack, holding Rose's hand, leaps through the crowd to reach a railing where they witness others plunging into the sea below. They continue their journey, navigating past a group of people gathered around a priest.

Near the propeller, dozens tread water for survival. Jack pulls Rose towards a deck now slanting at a forty-five-degree angle. They reach the exact spot where they first met and grasp the railing. The propellers continue to tilt upward as water cascades down them. Nearby, kneeling individuals hold onto a priest who grips a cab stand or rotating shaft.

Beside Jack and Rose, a woman tightly embraces a young boy. Shivering, Rose clings to Jack, her breath visible in the cold air, as they gaze down at the sinking ship. A soft smile graces Rose's face. Jack envelops her in a tight embrace and gently kisses her forehead.

In a now submerged section of the ship, a woman's lifeless body floats under a large chandelier, her gauzy dress softly billowing in the water, marking the grim finality of the disaster.
730:
As ice crystals glisten in Jack's hair, he tenderly grasps Rose's hand, planting a gentle kiss on its back. Smiling briefly, Jack winces and closes his eyes, while Rose, her eyes shut, rests her head against their entwined hands.

Meanwhile, a lifeboat navigates back to the wreckage site, its dark-haired crewman sweeping a flashlight across the debris-littered water. The beam reveals frozen bodies scattered among furniture, barrels, and other remnants of the disaster. The crewman uses an oar to probe several of these stiff corpses, while another sailor, leaning over the boat's bow, pushes bodies aside to clear their slow path forward. The flashlight illuminates the tragic sight of a dead woman and infant floating amidst the wreckage.

Elsewhere in the debris field, Rose lies on a floating wooden panel, singing softly to herself under the starry night sky. Jack, his head and arms kept above water beside her, remains motionless, his eyes closed. As ice encrusts her hair and eyebrows, Rose turns her head, a distant light casting a glow on her face. A lifeboat passes by a few yards away, unnoticed by her. She shakes Jack's hand, then rubs his arm and sits up, her smile fading as she realizes he is unresponsive. Desperately, she shakes him harder, glancing toward the departing lifeboat. Between them, a dead crewman floats, a whistle still in his mouth. As tears trickle down her nose, Rose, her brow furrowed, chokes back sobs while stroking Jack's hand.

The lifeboat rows further away, and Rose trembles watching it recede. She lies back down and closes her eyes, the rescuers' flashlight beams dimming in the distance. Suddenly, her eyes snap open, and she sits up, prying her hand from Jack's grip. She kisses his hand and releases him, watching as he sinks into the icy depths and disappears. Sliding to the edge of her platform and rolling into the water, Rose's breath forms clouds in the cold air. She swims to the frozen crewman, retrieves the whistle from his lips, and starts blowing it, attracting the rescuers' lights to her position.

Years later, on a research ship, an elderly Rose opens her eyes, tears streaming down the face of her companion, Lizzy. As dawn breaks over the ocean, Ismay sits silently in a lifeboat among other survivors. In another boat, a man drinks from a flask and passes it to Cal. Elsewhere, Ruth huddles against Molly, who steers out to sea, her expression blank. Wrapped in a blanket, her face pale and dazed by the green light of dawn, Ruth looks up, lost in thought.
733:
The movie opens with Jack joyfully kissing the tickets and embracing Fabrizio, while Olaf throttles Sven. Fabrizio swiftly gathers the winnings into Jack's cap. Soon after, the two young men dash along the dock and sprint up the gangplank, entering the ship with sacks over their shoulders. They race onto an upper deck, waving enthusiastically from a railing towards arm lockers.

As they settle in, black smoke erupts from one of the Titanic's four stacks. The ship pulls away from the shore, propelled by tugboats, as hundreds of passengers wave to the crowd on the dock. Amidst this, a bearded man cranks a movie camera on the dock, stirring up clouds of silt as the Titanic glides forward. The vastness of the ship is highlighted by white seagulls, appearing as mere insects, fluttering past the massive crowd on board. The ocean liner, with its four rows of portholes, sails past a small two-manned sailboat.

Inside the Titanic, a brown-haired woman guides a young boy and girl up a corridor. Jack and Fabrizio pass by in the opposite direction. Jack then enters a berth where his roommates exchange puzzled glances. Meanwhile, in her cabin, Rose carefully unpacks a painting. A porter brings in a pair of suitcases just as Cal enters from the adjoining promenade deck. Another porter wheels in a safe on a dolly, and Cal forcefully shoves a bottle of champagne into an ice bucket.

As the Titanic cruises through open water, the white-bearded captain joins the first officer on deck. Murdoch confidently strides into the wheelhouse, where Moody pulls a telegraph lever to full speed; a corresponding needle on an identical machine in the engine room moves to match. Men dash along catwalks as large gears drive huge pistons up and down. In the smoky boiler room, covered in coal, the mustached foreman turns a wheel connected to several steam pipes. A needle on a steam pressure gauge rises, and the pistons accelerate, slicing through the ocean.

On deck, Jack and Fabrizio lean against the railing, captivated by the sea. Behind them, Captain Smith stands on the uppermost deck outside the pilot hub, joined by First Officer Murdoch. The captain glances at him and grins. Jack points excitedly at something below—a dolphin swimming ahead of the ship. More dolphins join it, zooming through the clear water like zigzagging torpedoes. One dolphin leaps gracefully out of the water. Jack smiles, enchanted by the sight, as a crew member hands a teacup to Captain Smith. The captain sips his drink, gazing out to sea.

Back in the boiler room, men dump wheelbarrows of coal beside stokers who shovel the fuel into the large furnaces. An engineer leans over a railing, observing the massive pistons pumping vigorously on either side.
734:
Jack balances on the ship's prow, gripping a cable. He stretches his arms high above his head, then leans back, closing his eyes as the vast ship cuts through the ocean waves. Meanwhile, Ruth, Rose, and Cal dine with guests, including Molly Brown and a mustached, brown-haired man. Tension rises as Rose lights a cigarette, prompting Ruth to stiffen. Rose defiantly blows smoke towards her mother, only for Cal to quickly grab and extinguish the cigarette. Rose smiles faintly at Cal before rising and exiting the table.

Elsewhere, a brunette girl stands on a railing, secured by her father's grip from behind. Nearby, Jack, a few feet away, captures the scene with charcoal sketches. Crewmen stroll by, leading dogs on leashes. The brown-haired Irishman offers a handshake to Jack, who then surveys the ship around him. On an upper deck, Rose positions herself behind Tommy at the railing. Tommy turns, spots her, and exchanges a grin with Jack, who stares up at Rose. She briefly meets his gaze before looking away, then peeks at him again from the corner of her eye. Fabrizio waves his hand in front of Jack's face to get his attention.

Cal approaches Rose from behind, seizing her arm; they exchange heated words before Rose strides away, with Cal rolling his eyes and following her. Dressed in a striking ruby-colored evening gown, Rose forcefully moves past other passengers as she rushes down a deck, opens a gate, and dashes along the lower deck towards the ship's rear. Meanwhile, Jack lounges on a bench, smoking and gazing at the starry sky. He sits up as Rose dashes by him.

Tears streaming down her cheeks, Rose reaches the poop deck at the ship's rear. She looks back over her shoulder and then down at the turbulent water below. She grips the railing, climbs onto the first rung, and then, holding onto a flag pole, swings her legs over the railing, lowering herself onto a gun wheel. Facing the water, with the wind tossing her curly, auburn hair around her face, she leans forward over the ocean. Jack quietly approaches her from behind, takes a final puff of his cigarette, and discards it over the ship's side. He pockets his hands, turns to Rose, removes his coat, unlaces his boots, and pulls them off. As Rose gazes between the water and Jack, he removes his vest and extends his hand to her. Rose takes it, turning on the narrow ledge to face him directly, looking into his eyes as he smiles at her. Suddenly, she steps on her dress's hem, causing her to slip.
741:
In her recollection, she envisions Constantine tenderly braiding Skeeter's hair as a young girl on the front steps. A smile graces her face as she recalls this memory. On a dreary street corner, Miss Stein arranges two stacks of slender hardbacks with light blue covers in a bookshop's window display. Minnie, while frying chicken, opens an envelope containing money. She quickly tucks the envelope into her dress's front and dashes out, leaving the chicken to burn.

At a retirement home, Mrs. Walters reads aloud from the book to some residents, turning the page with a glib smile. Later, she converses with her daughter over the phone. Aibileen and Minnie navigate their shopping carts through a supermarket. Aibileen courteously steps aside for a white woman to pass. As they reach the end of an aisle, Aibileen's eyes widen in alarm, and she quickly steps back. Minnie also notices and presses herself against the aisle. Both brace themselves to move past, but the robust woman remains deeply engrossed.

At Skeeter's residence, Stuart storms out onto the porch with a thunderous expression, then abruptly turns and strides towards his Jeep, leaving Skeeter visibly puzzled and teary-eyed. Skeeter takes two copies of the book. At home, Charlotte, seated upright in bed beside her slumbering husband, reads the book. She sinks into her pillow and removes her glasses, a look of horror on her face. Elizabeth, in a rocking chair, reads the book while bottle-feeding her baby. Yule Mae reads it aloud to fellow inmates. Hilly reads it in bed. Later, she sorts through her mail, opens an envelope to find a note and a check from Celia Foote. With a smirk, Hilly tears the check into tiny pieces and storms out of the house.

Driving a Ford Fairlane station wagon down a straight dirt road between lush green fields, Hilly kicks up clouds of dust. Her lips curl as she drinks beer, spilling some on her blouse and swerving the car. She finishes the beer and lights a cigarette, tossing the empty bottle into the backseat. Skeeter receives a letter from Elain Stein offering her a job as a junior editor at Harper & Row Publishers. Hilly, enveloped in a storm of dust, arrives in front of Skeeter's house and marches to the front door with the determination of an angry chicken. She throws a pebble at Skeeter, who suffers from a cold sore. Charlotte, looking elegant in a tightly fitting turban, smiles loftily at Hilly, barely managing to keep a straight face with Skeeter. Charlotte reaches for Skeeter's hand, and they enter the spacious hall with its parquet floor. Charlotte suddenly appears very fatigued.
739:
In the tranquil night, a crescent moon, partially obscured by clouds, is mirrored in the serene water. A fisherman's float disrupts the stillness as it lands on the surface, creating concentric rings. Perched on the moon's curve, a boy casually lounges, his fishing rod in hand.

The scene shifts to a somber-looking black woman in her 40s who turns to face the camera. She sets aside a cooking pot and, with a smile and a long, penetrating gaze, nods. However, her smile quickly fades. Her eyes sweep the room and rest on a framed photo on the opposite wall, capturing the image of a young black graduate student. After a moment, she looks away.

With gentle care, she lifts a baby from her cot and wraps her arms around the little girl. Dressed in a wig and a pale, blue and white uniform, she heads to the bus stop, patting the child's tummy. The hem of her uniform appears uneven.

The camera then focuses on a young redhead driving a 1962 blue convertible Cadillac along a dirt track that cuts through a broad field, leaving clouds of dust in her wake. Ring lettered Skeeter, at the wheel, wears a look of determined optimism. She stops at a gas station, where a black attendant cleans her windshield. Nearby, a flag flutters atop the substantial offices of the Jackson Journal. Skeeter parks outside the main entrance and strides confidently through the glass fronted door. A cigarette-smoking receptionist guides her through the sprawling open-plan office to the editor's office, where a short, middle-aged man, seemingly overwhelmed by his large desk, points at Skeeter. Eugenia Phelan, known as Skeeter, hands over her resume. The editor reaches for a folder. Later, Skeeter, clutching a basket of readers' letters, exits Blackly's office with a happy smile.

At her home, a well-groomed brunette in a flowery, sleeveless '60s-style dress marks dots on a length of toilet paper. Minnie, a stout, well-cushioned maid, hurries to the foot of the stairs and calls upward. Carrying a pie, she follows the ladies to their car.

Aibileen Clark, the narrator, is seen garnishing a dish with grapes. Elizabeth Leefolt peeks through her front curtains and nods to Aibileen, who carefully slides a chicken dish over a crack in the dining table's veneer. In the bathroom, Elizabeth squats in front of moon-faced Mae Mobley, who sits on a child's toilet seat, before scooping her daughter up.

Hilly enters the sitting room with a sashay and beams at her girlfriends. In the kitchen, Minnie joins Aibileen and heads straight for a dish of deviled eggs, biting into one. She then picks up a tray and a TV set, carrying them towards the lounge. Aibileen tidies up by picking up the cord that Minnie trails behind her.
747:
In the morning, Aibileen prepares a hearty breakfast in her kitchen. Meanwhile, Minnie sips her tea, enjoying the quiet moment. Over at her house, Skeeter's excitement is palpable as she suddenly looks up. Her mother, Charlotte, calls out loudly from the bottom of the stairs. Skeeter, still in her pajamas, rushes out of her room, nearly losing her footing on the stairs in her haste. She swings open the kitchen's fly screen door, her eyes scanning the room with anticipation. Her hair is set in rollers, and later, she examines her smooth hair with a contemplative gaze. Charlotte watches from the doorway as Skeeter drives away in a pickup truck, towing a trailer filled with belongings, heading towards a leafy suburb over a bridge.

At the Holbrooks', Hilly glances impatiently at her watch. Skeeter arrives, her appearance somewhat unkempt. William and Stuart stand up to greet her. The men take humorous swigs of their Coke. During dinner, Stuart, sharply dressed and ambitious, quickly drinks his bourbon and commands a waiter's attention with a pointed finger. His expression shifts to one of confusion. Hilly subtly steers her husband away from the table, leaving Skeeter alone with Stuart. Stuart lets out a burp, prompting Skeeter to roll her eyes in annoyance. She abruptly leaves the table, her exit amusing the bourbon-drinking Stuart, who tipsily winks at William, who responds with a despairing shake of his head.

In her yard, Celia approaches a log with a lively chicken, ready to use the waiting ax. Minnie, watching from a window, flinches at the scene. Nearby, a tin of Crisco lard sits on a shelf. Celia offers a warm smile. Minnie carefully folds the top of a brown paper bag and passes it to Celia. Later, Minnie takes a seat at an attractively set table by the kitchen window for lunch. She places a napkin on her lap and lifts a fried chicken wing to her mouth. Across from her, Celia's face shows determination, causing Minnie to pause and then sit back down. Celia bites into a chicken leg, a contented smile spreading across her face. Minnie casts a knowing look her way.

In Aibileen's dimly lit house, she and Minnie listen intently to a phone conversation. Aibileen gently pushes Minnie's hand away, her face contorting with pain as memories resurface. She stands up and exits the room, leaving Minnie behind.

At the Holbrook swimming pool, Hilly speaks to the local ladies with authority. Elizabeth responds with a simpering smile. Elain notices a pamphlet sticking out of Skeeter's briefcase. Dramatically, she shields her eyes from the sun, waiting for Aibileen's response. Aibileen's eyes meet Yule Mae's across the space. Later, Skeeter enters the Holbrooks' kitchen and discovers Yule Mae at the sink. Yule Mae cautiously checks that no one is nearby. Hilly enters, carrying her young son Billy. She kisses him on the head before handing him to Yule Mae. Hilly's expression hardens, and with a sneer, she menacingly points her finger.

After dark, Skeeter works diligently in her room, smoking a cigarette as she ponders over Hilly's written words. Her gaze drifts to a shelf where a photograph of her younger self with Hilly sits, evoking a bitter memory.
748:
In the opening scene, she extinguishes her cigarette and removes a photo from a frame that seemed to evoke guilt, setting it aside. With a defiant tilt of her chin, she then conceals the black and white photo in a drawer. The next morning, she lies asleep, still dressed, on her bed when Charlotte, wearing a skull cap and dressing gown, bursts into the room and begins rifling through the wardrobe, pulling out clothes.

Later, on the porch, Charlotte, elegantly attired, attempts to listen in on a conversation between Stuart and Skeeter while she tends to her plants. Stuart then walks away, prompting Skeeter to glance back at the house with a speculative frown. She confidently strides past her smiling date.

Inside a bustling diner, he, with his shirt sleeves rolled up, has ordered oysters. They celebrate by clinking their oysters and crackers together. He reaches across the table to take her hand, and she responds with a smile. Outside the diner, Stuart takes her hand again, steps closer, and kisses her on the lips.

In a different scene, Mae Mobley sits on Aibileen's knee, engaged with a picture book. Hilly emerges from her house with a grimace, aggressively pushing past a press photographer. Her yard is littered with toilets, amidst which she retrieves her Yard of the Month sign, cradling it as she carries it inside, much to the amusement of onlookers. Mae Mobley, with her knickers down, proudly occupies one of the scattered toilets on the lawn. Elizabeth hastily removes her daughter from the scene. Aibileen, tenderly holding Mae Mobley, sets her down amidst about a dozen toilets on the lawn, kneels in front of her, grasps her hands, and gazes intently into her moonlit face. They embrace warmly. Elizabeth, observing coldly from the front door, retreats inside.

At the Phelans', Skeeter, along with Josefo and Pascagoula, watches civil rights activist Medgar Evers on TV until Charlotte abruptly turns it off. The servants quickly disperse. Charlotte then takes Skeeter's hand, but Skeeter pulls away and leaves.

On her bus ride home, Aibileen naps. Nearby, Henry looks up from his book. The bus halts, and the driver activates the interior lights to address the passengers. Aibileen and Henry, previously seated at the back, rush off the bus and walk down the dark street. Henry departs, and upon seeing him vanish around the corner, Aibileen breaks into a run. She trips and falls during her sprint. Civil rights activist Roy Wilkins provides commentary on the events.

Elsewhere, Minnie's children exit the kitchen, the three younger ones crowding into a single bed. The two friends comfort each other with a shared embrace. Skeeter, with a somber expression, flips through a LIFE magazine, pausing at the front cover depicting a distraught widow comforting her young son.

At the foot mansion, Minnie is vacuuming around a stuffed standing grizzly bear positioned on a corner dice. She gazes towards the fad, steps off the platform, and walks through the spacious rooms, directly heading to the bedroom and then to the bathroom door.
749:
In the film, a woman calmly steps away from a door. She then bursts into a bathroom to discover Celia sitting amidst a pool of blood. Reacting quickly, she picks up a fallen towel rack and assesses the scene with a composed demeanor. She then covers Celia, who is lying in bed, with a counterpane and applies a wet cloth to her neck. As she does this, her encouraging expression fades. Celia, lying in the bed, her face contorts into a tearful grimace.

Later, in her garden, Celia has dug a hole in the lawn. She positions a small cardboard box in the hole and begins to fill it with earth. Nearby, two rose bushes stand in their own brick-lined flower beds. As she nearly fills the hole, she reaches for a third rose bush and places it into the makeshift planter.

The scene shifts to a street where a yellow and green bus opens its doors, and a group of maids disembarks. Among the last to leave the bus are Yule Mae and Aibileen. A police officer handcuffs Yule Mae, and as she is led away, Aibileen is pushed back against the side of the bus. Yule Mae's face is forcefully pressed down onto the hood of a police car, and one of the officers issues her a warning. Aibileen observes white mothers and their children being turned away with cold indifference. Meanwhile, Hilly sits in her car with her son, her expression impassive.

At a diner, Skeeter sits at the counter as Hilly enters and seats her son in one of the booths. Henry, who is behind the counter, leans in close to Skeeter, his wise, dark eyes peering at her through his owl-like glasses. Skeeter then hurries over to Aibileen's house, finding the living room filled with maids, their somber, smooth-skinned faces turning to look at her. Aibileen beckons her forward, and with tears welling up in her eyes, Skeeter steps into the center of the room. An elderly white-haired woman begins to share her story.

Elsewhere, Miss Tine, dining in a swanky restaurant with two male colleagues, speaks to Skeeter on the phone. An orange cruiser arrives at Elizabeth's drive where a bridge game is in full swing. Mary Beth takes Skeeter's seat at Hilly's table.

Celia, dressed in a low-cut fitted plum top and a tight pink skirt, approaches the garden path with a pie in hand. Inside, Elizabeth glances toward the door, while Hilly's jaw drops in surprise. Hilly quickly takes control and ducks out of sight. At the front of the house, Celia spots a gap in the curtains and offers a cheery smile, which Hilly notices. Celia's smile fades, and she retreats with her pie. Aibileen watches Celia's humiliation from the kitchen doorway. On her way back to her car, Celia struggles to hold back tears. Once home, Minnie looks at her with the compassion of a mother consoling a child who has been bullied.
750:
At the beginning, Minnie, sporting a cut above her eye, sighs and sits on a chair provided by Celia. Celia then gently uses a cloth to dab at the cut while Minnie quietly listens to her advice. Meanwhile, at the Phelan's, the household gathers around their black and white television, engrossed in a broadcast by Walter Cronkite. In another scene, Stuart tenderly kisses Skeeter on the forehead, both dressed in black. Skeeter, with tears in her eyes, turns her attention back to the TV.

A color photograph of John F. Kennedy is displayed alongside a photo of Aibileen's son. Minnie's gaze shifts, leading to a flashback of her visit to Hilly's home. There, Hilly, seated at a polished mahogany dining table, savors a forkful of Minnie's pie with delight. Minnie watches, her expression one of satisfied amusement, as Hilly takes another bite. The scene escalates when Mrs. Walters enters with an empty glass, pours herself a whiskey, and then bursts into giggles at the unfolding drama. Hilly, after shoving the plate back at Minnie and dismissing her, continues eating. Minnie forcefully places the plate down and fixes Hilly with a barely-disguised amused look, her eyes darting towards the chocolate-colored pie. As Hilly takes her final bite, she rises, squares her shoulders, and then retches. Minnie, seizing the remaining pie, flees the scene.

Skeeter, witnessing this, shakes her head in disbelief. Minnie, now wrapping her cardigan tightly around herself, storms out. Later, a "whites only" Jackson City cab drops Mrs. Walters off at the Junior League benefit dinner. Mrs. Walters joins other elegantly dressed attendees ascending the steps to the beautifully lit venue. The Footes arrive, linked arm-in-arm, and quickly grab champagne from a waiter's tray. Meanwhile, Sugar, Minnie, and Aibileen serve in their black uniforms with white collars and aprons. Minnie discreetly nudges Aibileen to observe Celia's body-hugging pink dress as Celia finishes her drink and waves at Hilly, whose automatic smile stiffens before she slaps her husband for staring.

On the dance floor, Charlotte and her husband dance on the black and white checkered tiles, while Skeeter and Stuart dance closely nearby. Celia, by the buffet, scribbles something down while sipping another glass of champagne. The atmosphere lightens when Mr. Blackly entertains with a jig and cartwheel, prompting the maids to laugh heartily. Celia, slightly unsteady, makes her way to the powder room, where she leans to reapply her lipstick, inadvertently turning her perfectly formed behind towards a group of women—Elizabeth, Jolene, and Mary Beth—who stand in a confrontational stance by the mantle piece.

Back in the ballroom, Hilly takes the microphone and gestures towards the staff lined up, causing Skeeter's expression to harden.
752:
A high door swings open, revealing a caped figure standing at the entrance of a warehouse. He surveys the surroundings, where silver-grey light from numerous small windows illuminates an array of peculiar objects. To his left, past a set of stairs, two large shapes emerge, gradually recognizable as the ends of two train carriages, each slightly bent and twisted. He approaches the less damaged one, examining it from the back. Upon looking up along its length, he notices the sides are severely smashed open, with the remaining glass cracked and shattered. Inside, seats are askew, torn from their mountings with their upholstery charred and blackened. The man's face is illuminated by the light as he gazes at the wrecked carriage, standing motionless and grim-faced for a long time, seemingly oblivious to the drops of water falling from his hood.

In another scene, set in the dark, a man is crouching. He rises to his knees, and as his head lifts, light reveals the face of David, who appears to be about 20 years old. He scans his surroundings, noticing the light emanating from a burning car flipped over behind him. David staggers toward the vehicle, stumbling and crawling on his knees. Inside the burning wreckage, a young woman, Audrey, lies unconscious and still. David grabs the car door with both hands and pulls, then checks the door catch, which remains unmoved. Audrey's arm dangles out of the window. David grips the door edge again and heaves with all his strength. As flames leap into the night sky behind him, he manages to rip the door off its hinges. He bends down to release Audrey's seat belt, then drags her from the car, cradles her in his arms, and gently lays her down a short distance away. Glancing over his shoulder, David spots the lights of a pickup truck slowly rounding a bend. He waves frantically to catch the driver's attention. Turning back, he sees Audrey's eyes are now open. Tenderly, he holds her head as the truck driver rushes over to them. David looks into the concerned face of the driver, then back at Audrey. Very slowly, he lifts his head, the flames still flickering behind him, his expression thoughtful and avoiding the man's eyes.

In a different setting, Elijah rolls his wheelchair along a darkened corridor, his right leg extended straight out with two rows of shiny bolts protruding from the metal frame around it. He reaches for the phone. As he looks straight ahead, past rows of shelving showcasing a vast collection of comics, David is seen standing at the top of the stairs overlooking the concourse of Philadelphia Train Station, flanked by tall classical stone pillars on either side.
753:
In the vast expanse of the station, the luminous disk of the clock dominates the view. High above, cold silver beams from ceiling lamps illuminate the concourse, where people hurriedly cross paths. David, blending into the grey surroundings, descends a stone staircase. At its base, dressed in a baseball cap and rain cape, he observes the crowd's fluid motion.

He begins to stroll leisurely through the throng when a young blonde woman in a vibrant red jacket collides with him. From an elevated vantage point, David later spots her again, now adorned in a different, gleaming jacket, inside a jewelry store. She gestures towards an elderly assistant, and as his attention diverts, she stealthily reaches over the counter, grabs a bracelet, and slips it into her bag. David watches as she merges back into the crowd, and he continues his slow journey.

As he moves, others occasionally brush against him. Mid-concourse, he pauses, surrounded by a whirl of people, and subtly extends his left hand with fingers spread. A man in a checked shirt, his shirt untucked, bumps into David’s outstretched hand.

From above once more, David observes this same man in a checked shirt, leaning out of a pickup truck, brutally smashing a bottle over a black woman's head as she walks a city street at night. Back in the station, David, his brow furrowed, watches the man finish a beer and discard the can.

Elsewhere, a young man in a green shirt kneels beside a bed where a young woman in a very short party dress lies motionless. She rolls, unaware, exposing her thighs, and as the boy watches briefly before standing, her leg slides off the bed. She remains still, her blonde hair scattered over a pile of coats, as the boy exits and gently closes the door.

David shifts his focus, scanning the station. A procession of college students wearing maroon baseball caps passes him. Beyond them, he sees the young man now in a green jacket hugging his mother and beaming at his father. Emotionally stirred, David starts to walk backwards, swallowing hard and observing others as they move past. He inadvertently backs into a maintenance man in orange overalls, who is maneuvering a wheeled trash bin.

This same maintenance man, now in an orange T-shirt, stands before a house's front door, which another man opens. They lock eyes through the screen door. The maintenance man forcefully grabs and holds the door open. In a sudden vision, David sees the homeowner lying motionless on the basement stairs. Shocked, David lifts his gaze to the ceiling momentarily, his eyes wide. Still reeling from the shock, he surveys the concourse and spots the maintenance man emptying a trash can on the opposite side.
754:
David trails a man maneuvering a wheelie bin around a corner and down a corridor dimly illuminated by sparse lighting. As he proceeds, a few individuals slump lazily against a wall, seemingly indifferent to their surroundings. David pauses before a door, his gaze fixed on the shadows of people moving behind its frosted glass panels.

Suddenly, the door swings open, revealing the maintenance man once again, now donned in a cap and with a bag draped across his shoulder. The man continues his journey at a brisk pace along a street shrouded in darkness, flanked by parked cars, and ascends a long stairway illuminated sporadically by towering lamps. David, his hood drawn tightly against the relentless rain, shadows him.

At the summit of the stairs, David halts, observing as the man advances up a gently sloping street bordered by expansive homes set back from the road. The man turns onto a path leading to a detached house, fronted by a mature tree. He pauses under the porch, scans the street cautiously, retrieves an item from beside the porch, and then vanishes into the shadows beside the house.

David, overcome by a moment of desolation, lowers his head, his face barely visible beneath the shadow of his hood, save for a small triangle from his nose to his mouth. He then lifts his gaze toward the house just as two thin beams of light gradually widen with the opening of a door. The expanding light reveals mail strewn across a tiled floor and clothing scattered further inside. Water drips from David’s cape onto a pair of shoes as he stands silhouetted in the doorway, the interior of the house illuminated.

From his position, David can see beyond three open doorways to a staircase. He lingers in the doorway, then slowly turns back, stepping into a dimly lit lobby. Glancing to his left, he reaches out to open another door, flicks on a light, and surveys the room. The house owner lies face down on the basement steps, and David is struck again by the memory of the maintenance man's forceful entry into the house.

David closes the door and cautiously moves into the next room, featuring half-paneled walls, passing a chair at the end of a table, indicating it's the dining room. He then enters another room with easy chairs, marking it as the sitting room, where the flicker of a television catches his eye and he pauses briefly.

David hesitates before proceeding into the hallway. His shadow looms larger on the wall as he ascends the stairs. He peeks through the gap of a partly open door, frowning. With a step forward, he pushes the door wider and switches on the light, entering a child's bedroom adorned with pop posters on the walls.
761:
In a quiet moment, a man opens the door to his walk-in wardrobe, illuminating the space with a bare bulb. He reaches up to a shelf, feeling under some folded jeans, and pulls out a piece of gray cloth from which the butt of a gun protrudes. Carefully, he lays the cloth on his newspaper, unwraps a stubby, black revolver, examines it briefly, then re-wraps and returns it to its hiding place. Again, he feels under the jeans, this time extracting a battered folder. Inside, he discovers old newspaper clippings about American football. Among the articles, a photo of a young David, decked out in football gear, catches his eye. As he turns the pages, more clippings and photos of football matches emerge, the players' identities obscured by helmets and face guards. His search pauses on a stark image of an overturned car, photographed at night on a tree-lined road, upside down in a ditch with its roof crushed. Frowning, he studies this photo intently before quickly closing the folder and concealing it once more under the jeans. Just then, he notices Audrey outside his door, her face crumpling as she pushes her fists to her mouth. He watches her descend the stairs before he quietly closes the door.

Later, at a vast football stadium, David, now on duty, communicates with his walkie-talkie under the white canopy of a walkway. He and Elijah stroll near the crowds waiting to enter. As they move, David brushes past a tall, slim man in a pale, sandy green and gray camouflage jacket. A few steps later, David looks back, eyes narrowed. Elijah, wearing a long black leather coat and black gloves, supported by his stick, also glances back as they continue. At the head of the queue, David speaks to another security guard who begins frisking the fans. They watch a man with thinning hair and a black beard, who seems to scan his surroundings. This suspect eventually steps out of the line at a break in the metal barriers, hand covering his mouth, and walks away against the flow of fans. David exchanges a look with Elijah, grinning and nodding before raising his walkie-talkie.

David then proceeds alone down a dark corridor. Meanwhile, Elijah's glass walking stick taps down onto the seat of his car as a man in a camouflage jacket walks by. Elijah hobbles through the arched colonnade surrounding the stadium, moving through patches of light and shadow, but the man ahead moves swiftly enough to disappear around the curve of the building.
762:
In the bustling city, Elijah anxiously scans his surroundings and spots a man across the road near a dark brick stadium. The man briskly makes his way into the subway. Elijah, impatient and nervous, waits for a passing car before jaywalking against the traffic signals. His coat's skirt flaps open, displaying a vibrant purple lining as he almost skips across the street, driven by his anxious state.

Upon reaching the other side, Elijah grabs the handrail to steady himself. Silhouetted against the daylight, he peers down the long, steep staircase into the tiled station, watching the man stride confidently below. As the man disappears into the station, Elijah, with a determined look, launches himself down the stairs. Using his stick and gripping the rail tightly, he struggles to maintain his balance, but his feet falter. He slips, his glass stick flying down the stairs ahead of him. Elijah finds himself sprawled on the stairs, lying on his back with his head pointing downward. From this upside-down perspective, he sees the man glance back just before vaulting over the ticket barrier. As the man's jacket flips up, Elijah catches a glimpse of a silver gun with a black grip tucked underneath. Overwhelmed, Elijah's eyes flicker and close.

The scene shifts to a sunny afternoon where a white bus stops on a hill in a suburban street. David, still clad in his security uniform of a green jacket and maroon cap, steps off the bus, carrying a holdall. With a smile on his face, he walks slowly towards a small green park where a group of boys are energetically playing American football on the grass. Joseph excitedly runs up some steps to join his father. Meanwhile, the other children gather around a young man with a crew cut, admiring his muscles. Together, David and Joseph turn and walk away, with Joseph's hand resting affectionately on his father's back.

Later, in the dim light of a basement, David, now wearing a light grey sweatshirt, lies flat on a narrow bench, pushing up a weight's bar. He straightens his arms, carefully lowering the bar onto supports on either side of the bench, and then sits up. Joseph, his fringe hanging down to his eyebrows, watches his father intently. David looks around at the weights on the ends of the bar, then walks behind Joseph to the weights. Sitting back on the bench, David looks down as Joseph moves from one end of the bar to the other. David lies back, grips the bar, lifts it off the supports with a frown, and lowers it to his chest. As he begins to push it up, his mouth contorts with effort and a prominent vein bulges from his forehead up into his scalp. His arms quiver and his head trembles with the strain as he lowers the bar to his chest and pushes it back up. Reaching full arm extension, he drops the bar back onto the supports, his effort palpable in the quiet basement.
764:
David slowly turns and watches her depart. Meanwhile, Elijah continues his conversation with Audrey. At the stadium, David stands still in the middle of the walkway, turning slowly with a frown, barely noticing the surrounding crowds. A young man wearing a vibrant blue anorak accidentally bumps into him.

In the restroom, another young man, dressed in a red and blue anorak draped over his shoulders, washes his hands at the sink. He glances towards the door, confirming he's alone, then reaches into a waist bin, retrieves a small package, and tucks it into his trouser pocket. Adjusting his anorak, he exits the restroom at a leisurely pace.

Back in the stadium walkway, David observes as the man in the bright blue anorak joins a queue for tickets. Approaching him, David receives a weary look from the man, who slowly turns to face him. The man raises his arms, allowing David to pat down his clothes and search one of the anorak's pockets, though he finds nothing. After stepping back, David nods and swallows, watching as the man turns away. With a sigh, David moves in the opposite direction, pulling out his walkie-talkie. He frowns and glances back at the man in the anorak, who quickly averts his gaze.

In another scene, David sits across from a white-haired woman at a table, under the watchful eyes of Joseph. Nearby, a boy sits with a thermometer in his mouth. Joseph nods and gives a pitying look to another boy. David, repeatedly shaking his head, keeps his gaze fixed on the woman, staring intently.

Outside, David and Joseph navigate through a playground, moving over the colorful hopscotch markings. Joseph shakes his head again as dusk begins to settle over the street near their home.

Inside the kitchen, David is at the sink washing dishes. He pauses, setting down a pan, and stares at Joseph, who is seated at a table with David's gun lying in front of him. Joseph picks up the gun, gripping it with both hands and pointing it at David. The gun then falls onto the table. David quickly grabs it, removes the bullets, while Audrey, overwhelmed, collapses onto the table with her head in her hands. David forcefully places the now-empty gun on the cooker, slides down the wall, and sits slumped against it. Audrey, unable to bear the tension, collapses onto the floor.

In a limited edition gallery, David stares at the carpet in a room decorated in shades of silver and grey. Outside, the street and shop lights pierce the grey evening as people wait to cross a busy junction. Inside a shop, Elijah sits motionless in his wheelchair, his face glowering and sullen, surrounded by walls lined with comics encased in reflective plastic covers.
765:
In a dimly lit shop, a stock keeper with thick, curly hair, dressed in black jeans and a Motorhead T-shirt, glances up from behind his counter. He notices Elijah and after stowing an item away, he steps out and starts walking down the aisle toward him. Halfway, he pauses. Nearby, Joseph is engrossed in play with a caped superhero and a green reptilian villain toy. Audrey, standing with David, who has been leaning against the wall behind their son, watches Joseph. David shifts, unfolding his arms and sliding his hands into his pockets, then looks at Audrey.

The shop assistant's gaze shifts down to Elijah, his head swaying as he seeks a response. Eventually, he moves to the back of Elijah's wheelchair, grips the handles, and begins to push him down the aisle, carefully navigating around the crammed shelves and displays. Abruptly, Elijah jerks a wheel, causing the chair to veer into a display, scattering magazines across the floor. The assistant, hands moving weakly, looks at Elijah as if about to say something, but Elijah, slumped and unresponsive, pays him no heed. The assistant tries again to push the wheelchair, but Elijah jerks the other wheel. The assistant steps back, raising his hands in a gesture of surrender, and looks down at the sullen-faced Elijah before they continue on between the racks of comics and toys. The assistant eventually leaves Elijah at the display he had collided with. Elijah, wearing a padded black mitten, picks up a comic from the wreckage. The cover features a muscular hero in blue charging at shadowy demonic figures. He holds it out toward the assistant, who is now back at the counter, engaged in a telephone conversation.

Meanwhile, David and Audrey sit at a bar, facing each other in a quiet, intense gaze. A babysitter arrives, and David hands her some money. As she prepares to leave, she notices the heavy rain outside, hastily covering her hair with a small brown jacket before stepping out. David runs his hand over his head, a gesture of contemplation. Audrey, leaning against a pillar at the base of the stairs, looks at him, her hand clutching his coat while the other rests in his pocket. With a nod, she turns and departs. David casually tosses his coat over the back of a sofa.

In a darkened room, the green light on the answering machine blinks insistently. David enters from the unlit landing and presses the button to listen to the messages. Outside, through the relentless downpour, headlights cut through the night. A car comes to a halt before a chain-link fence. The driver's door swings open, and a figure, cloaked and hooded, emerges and approaches the fence. He pauses, a silhouette against the glaring headlights, then reaches up, grasps the fence, and begins to climb.
770:
The ocean completely engulfs the mountains, followed by a massive wave that demolishes a monastery. As the catastrophe unfolds, more people frantically board the ark. A boarding officer notices Uri struggling and rushes to assist him. From the platform, Uri has managed to lift Alec onto a rising structure, but Alec is unable to reach back. Summoning all his strength, Uri grabs Alec's legs and hurls him to safety, only to plunge into a pit himself and fall.

Two boarding officers forcefully bring a protesting boy onto the ark. The coms officer identifies a hydraulic malfunction that is stopping the gate from closing. Meanwhile, Adriane observes Lily and Noah on a monitor. Dark, raging floodwaters sweep away the air field and the mountains. On the ark's bridge, the Ark office guides Adrian and Laura through a crowded hallway. The crew, awestruck, watches as floodwaters clear the surrounding mountains. A clock begins a countdown from ten seconds as water approaches. The water strikes the ark forcefully from a high angle. Anheuser glares intensely as the countdown tower reaches zero. Lights go out as crashing water envelops the ark, causing the crew on the bridge to be knocked over. Boarding officers and Uri's boys rush away as water crashes around them. A torrent of water surges through a corridor, knocking people down. The crew regains their positions at the controls, and an individual finds himself in a flooded corridor.

Nina attends to Tenzen, who has injured his leg. A door abruptly shuts, trapping Lily and Tamara. Tamara manages to free Lily and Caesar but becomes trapped herself in a flooding corridor. On the bridge, Anheuser notices a wrecked plane hovering through the crashing waves. A huge jet forcefully barges through the water, leading to a collision that cracks the anchor away. The ark rises as massive waves curl up and over it. A computer graphic displays the angle of collision between the two arks. The dramatic descent of the arks causes crowds in the hallway to lose their footing. The ark dives headlong, causing chaos as items crash around in the corridor. Adrian and Laura reunite with Lily.

On the bridge, atop a flat rooftop, the crew observes a computer image of Mount Everest. In the geological bay connecting corridor, Jackson, Kate, Noah, and Tibetans listen to the unfolding events over the speaker. Waist-deep in water, Jackson moves away from the group. Noah fixes a long, steady gaze on his father. Jackson kisses Noah, and before Kate leads the boy away, Jackson kisses her as well. In the flickering light, he turns around and takes a deep breath. Nina, flashing a torchlight, screams for help alongside Tamara in the anti-chamber. Tamara's face presses against a grate as the rising water engulfs her. Jackson swims into the hydraulic chamber and surfaces in an air pocket. Kate attempts to treat the injured Tenzen.
771:
As Noah seizes the moment to swim away while she is distracted, Jackson navigates underwater, his path lit by a torch. Spotting something intriguing, he continues his exploration. Meanwhile, Kate attentively cares for Tenzen. Turning around, she suddenly realizes Noah is missing. Upon finding his jacket, she plunges into the water, soon emerging from the surface. Elsewhere, the ark begins its journey towards Mount Everest.

Adriane activates a monitor, revealing Jackson in a chamber, struggling to liberate Tenzen's power drill. As Jackson looks up, he sees a light and Noah. After surfacing, he dives back into the water. Kate, in another part of the ark, gazes into the darkness while Tenzen communicates with his family, shaking his head in response to their concerns.

With the water level rising, Nina catches a glimpse of a giraffe through the grill in the ceiling. The ark, scraping against the mountain, challenges Jackson's efforts to free the drill. Laura and Lily are shaken by the turbulence. As the ark nears Everest, the hydraulic chamber's fumes dissipate.

Noah joins his father underwater, where the torchlight reveals the drill entangled in gears. Father and son briefly surface before Jackson is back underwater as the ark collides with a glacier. With a forceful tug, Jackson frees the cable, setting the gears in motion and initiating the closure of the gate. He releases the drill amidst the escalating tension.

As part of the mountain disintegrates and the ark edges closer to impact, it finally strikes Everest, triggering an avalanche visible to those on the bridge. The ark then begins to distance itself from the mountain.

Noah surfaces in the hydraulics chamber before Kate, leading to a heartfelt embrace between mother and son, as they briefly submerge and then resurface together. Meanwhile, individuals on the bridge and in the zoological bay, hanging onto pipes, peer into the darkness. A beam of torchlight pierces the water as Jackson surfaces once more.

Amidst the celebration, Anheuser surveys the people on the bridge, who are now hugging and cheering. Scotty and Professor West share an embrace. As Kate and Noah continue their hug, Jackson looks over at Nina and Tenzen, receiving a thumbs-up and responding with a nod. The group remains in the water as the ark sails on, leaving Everest behind.

In his quarters, Adriane works on a laptop, with Laura seated behind him, absorbed in a book. Adriane removes his glasses and smiles, prompting Laura to close her book and return the smile. Rising to their feet, Adriane approaches Laura. They near each other for a kiss, but he hesitates. Laura, determined, wraps her arms around his neck, intensifying their embrace.

Elsewhere, Lily notices little Caesar and receives the dog from Alec Karpov. Jackson then approaches Kate. As the massive door of the ark opens, daylight floods the interior, revealing hundreds of people gazing outward. Lily, holding Caesar, and Noah, gripping his mother's hand, stand beside Kate, with Jackson right behind her.
775:
Gordon anxiously monitors the aircraft's controls as a menacing fissure advances toward them. Jackson swiftly guides Gordon's hands to the throttle, prompting Gordon to yank the controls upward. The plane ascends just as the runway crumbles beneath it. Noah watches in awe, eyes wide with shock, as a canyon suddenly yawns beneath them, swallowing buildings as they collapse into the abyss.

Skillfully, Gordon maneuvers the plane through the chaos of tumbling freeway sections, executing a sharp right roll. Below, people desperately flee across fractured and upheaved roads. The plane skims perilously low over the devastated city center. As the streets themselves begin to rise, Gordon battles to gain altitude, while Lilly, sobbing, witnesses people and vehicles plunging into the ominous depths below.

The aircraft momentarily dips into the rising canyon, narrowly avoiding a train that arcs overhead, crashes into a wall, and erupts in an explosion. The plane successfully clears the canyon, only to face another peril ahead: two high-rise towers collapsing to form an upside-down V. Gordon steers the plane directly through the narrow gap as debris from the shattering buildings surrounds them.

As the light plane ascends, debris fills the sky, and they narrowly escape the falling tower behind them. Jackson, stunned, observes as the plane leaves behind a city bisected by the colossal fissure. They gaze down at the widespread devastation below. Amidst the chaos, Noah offers a tearful Lilly a comforting embrace. Jackson and Kate turn to follow Gordon's gaze out the windscreen, while behind them, the children press their faces against a side window, staring at the unfolding disaster.

The Californian coastline gradually rises and then slides into the sea, punctuated by explosions erupting in the streets. Buildings crumble as the entire state fragments and sinks beneath the water.

On board the Genesis, Harry is handed a drink. He steps off the stage and moves to the galley to take a phone call. Meanwhile, Scotty taps on Adrian's office window. Adrian, asking for a moment, stands up and begins to pace. A sad frown creases Adrian's face as Harry concludes his call. Harry rises again, flags down a passing waiter named Kevin, who pours him a double. Tony, watching from the dressing room, sees Harry drinking.

In a shift of scene, a biplane flies over the Yellowstone Park research facility. A grazing doe observes as Gordon executes a cautious landing. Jackson quickly exits the plane and inspects a petrol pump before starting their RV. Noah, nearby, answers his phone. Lilly, spotting Charlie on a ridge, alerts the others. As Jackson drives near the ridge, both he and Gordon survey their surroundings skeptically as a vast flock of birds suddenly takes flight.

Lilly joins the men on the ridge, and they scan the landscape once more. The mountain range beneath them undulates and rises ominously, with the land itself appearing to sink and then lift upwards. Lilly, feeling the imminent danger, backs away slowly as a funnel of steam bursts through a crack in the ground below. Charlie, watching the spectacle, beams with excitement. The group, spurred into action, dashes past Charlie's motorbike.

Gordon steps onto the runway and checks his watch, moments before the Yellowstone mountains are engulfed in a blinding flash, leaving a stunned Charlie on the ridge.
776:
As a catastrophic event unfolds, Kate and Gordon shield their eyes from the initial impact. Simultaneously, Jackson monitors the unfolding disaster through the RV's mirror, witnessing a blinding flash and a subsequent energy wave that flattens the remaining trees and sends Charlie hurtling backwards. A towering inferno and dense black smoke dominate the sky, painting a grim scene.

Amidst the chaos, Kate finds solace in hugging Noah close to her. Charlie, struggling to regain his footing, is bombarded by fireballs descending from a massive eruption, only to be struck by a large debris chunk while standing in a defiant pose. The park becomes a target for relentless fireballs, turning it into a fiery battlefield.

Jackson maneuvers the RV through the mayhem, skillfully swerving to dodge falling rocks before aligning the vehicle back on course. Disaster strikes again as a fireball pierces the RV, leaving a flaming hole in its wake. On the runway, Noah anxiously observes from the plane's window, while Kate stands nearby, her anxiety palpable.

The research center suffers as molten rocks pummel the area, creating havoc. A fissure suddenly splits the ground between the RV and the runway, forcing Jackson to accelerate, causing the RV to leap and narrowly land between the widening canyon. He quickly parks behind the plane, and Kate rushes to meet him as he emerges. She then hurries back to the plane with Lilly in tow.

As the tarmac cracks ominously, Jackson, still inside the RV, spots a London tube map. His discovery is overshadowed by the emergence of another massive fissure that causes the RV to tip backwards into the abyss. Jackson tumbles down the center aisle but manages to grab a handle in a desperate bid for safety.

From the plane's cockpit, Gordon glances back amidst the chaos, setting the plane in motion as fireballs continue to strike the ground near the runway. Amidst this turmoil, a hand clutching a map appears on the edge of the new fissure, followed by another hand, signaling Jackson's narrow escape.

Thick smoke envelops the sky as Jackson sprints toward the departing plane. Kate swiftly pulls him aboard just as fireballs continue to rain down, creating thick columns of smoke. As the plane lifts off, it narrowly dodges more fiery projectiles and clears a hilltop, outrunning a volcanic eruption. Dark clouds cast shadows over the plane as it rockets away from the swirling inferno.

Inside the plane, Noah gives a reassuring thumbs-up. Kate turns to Jackson, who, catching his breath, unfolds the map he retrieved—a large map of China—prompting dubious looks from everyone onboard. Gordon, from the pilot's seat, surveys the situation.

In a different part of the world, Adrian hurries into Anheuser's office and follows him into a bustling corridor. Their journey continues into a darkened chapel where Anheuser expresses surprise before turning and exiting. The chapel doors are shut by two agents, leaving Adrian and Wilson in the dimly lit space. Meanwhile, the iconic Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio crumbles, its remains scattering across the city streets, marking another chapter in the widespread catastrophe.
777:
In Las Vegas, smoke fills the sky as buildings burn beside a deep chasm cutting through the town. A light plane approaches McAllen airport, its runway crumbling into the chasm, and lands amidst chaos. Nearby, twins Alec and Oleg stand with Yuri and Tamara by the grounded plane. A mechanic flees the scene, and a fireman compels Yuri to move. A limo arrives at Air Force One, and Adrian emerges and boards the aircraft.

Inside the bustling control room of Air Force One, Anheuser hangs up his cell phone amidst rows of computer equipment and terminals. Adrian enters and stands before Anheuser, who tries to decipher his expression. The onboard staff momentarily halts their activities. Adrian watches forlornly as Anheuser exits. Air Force One taxis along the runway. On board, Laura steps out of the president's cabin, greeted by a steward. She re-enters the cabin, picks up the phone, and leans against the wall, sobbing as a light goes out behind Wilson. His secretary, Sally, stands in the doorway as Wilson lowers the phone from his ear. Air Force One then takes off.

Back in the office, Wilson sits in front of a TV camera, and the broadcast fades. Everyone turns to see the fireman's face fall as he closes the glass door, which reflects a rapidly approaching ash cloud.

Elsewhere, Sasha guides Jackson and others to a cargo plane, an Antonov, which they board. The cargo hold lights up, revealing a collection of gleaming sports cars. As the Antonov taxis into position, an ash cloud billows across the airport and engulfs the control tower. The plane loses a tire and approaches the damaged end of the runway. It drops and slides into the chasm. Onboard, Yuri holds his sons securely to their seats, and Tamara touches Caesar. Two buildings loom ahead, and Gordon pilots the plane between them, the wingtips narrowly scraping through. They ascend, shaking hands in relief as they clear another building. Gordon stares in disbelief as they fly towards a tall tower, the plane's underside shearing off the tip.

Inside the plane, Jackson comforts Noah by patting his hand, while Kate embraces Lilly.

In Tibet, Nima and Lama Rinpoche sit on the balcony of a small monastery, overlooking a snow-covered mountain range. Lama Rinpoche calmly gazes at Nema and pours tea for both, filling Nema's cup until it overflows. Nema reaches out to stop the pouring, and Rinpoche complies. A breeze sweeps across the balcony, causing the prayer flags to billow. Rinpoche holds up an object and tosses it to Nema, who catches it—it's a truck key. Nema grins at the key and then at Rinpoche.
781:
In a bustling apartment, a photo of a couple kissing adorns the wall. The city sees a flurry of weddings each week. A man closes his book, gazing into the distance. Jane, in her apartment, forcefully attempts to fit the evening's array of vibrant dresses into an already overflowing closet. She manages to compress the rebellious fabrics, pushing hard against the doors to shut them, but they spring open again. Frustrated, she collects some papers and sinks into the comfort of her couch.

As the sun sets, its warm rays cast dramatic silhouettes over the city skyline and bathe the buildings along Central Park in golden light, marking the start of rush hour. Kevin, juggling coffee cups, makes his way to the New York Journal offices. Meanwhile, Jane encounters Casey, who steps out of a taxi sporting a stylish white men's shirt. They proceed into their office, where Jane, with a grin, navigates her way to her cluttered desk. Casey shows her a filofax, met with a glare from Jane. Later, they examine photo layouts together. As Gina departs, Jane's expression turns to one of exasperation, and Casey makes a face. Jane's look of pain is evident as the charismatic George strides away, leaving her to deal with a mess of adhesive notes. Casey offers Gina a deceitful smile before flouncing off.

At the airport, a jumbo jet lands, and Jane beams as her cute blonde sister, Tess, arrives. They reach Jane's apartment, where Jane struggles with the luggage. Later that night, in one of the many city taxis, Kevin peruses Jane's filofax.

At a lively, dimly lit club hosting Gina's party, Jane and Casey mingle. George suavely approaches them. Breathless, Jane makes her way over to where George is enjoying a beer and conversing with friends. From another direction, Tess, in a dazzling dress, advances. George notices Tess and grins, but then he also spots Jane. As Jane nears, her expression sours upon realizing George and Tess are drawn to each other. They exchange smiles while Jane feigns happiness when George looks her way. As Tess and George exit, Kevin approaches a stunned Jane, who hands him her drink before storming out through a side door. Kevin watches, bewildered, as Jane vents her frustration on a wall with her handbag, all in plain sight of a calm dinner party. Composing herself, Jane returns to Kevin in the club, who waits with raised eyebrows. Her gaze lingers on Tess and George as they leave.

Later, a car passes by Jane's building. Rushing to the front door, she peers through the peephole before yanking it open, only to stomp back inside in agitation. In the living room, she turns on the light, revealing an empty space. Anxious, she paces, eventually picking up a magazine from the couch, settling into a chair, and flipping through it distractedly. Her eyes occasionally dart towards the front door.
785:
A smartly dressed older lady confronts a woman, leaving her puzzled and unsure of what she heard. Meanwhile, Jane, after downing Casey's drink, confidently approaches Tess and George. She stares challengingly at Tess, then stuffs an entire sausage roll into her mouth in one go. As Jane strides away, Tess looks worried but then turns and grins at her, only for her face to freeze as Jane locks eyes with her, picks up a folder from the table behind, and leaves. Casey appears bored during this encounter, and Tess smiles at George.

The screen then shifts to display cute baby pictures of Tess and George, followed by scenes of their past: young George petting a goat, Tess dangling a cat by its hind legs, George in academic robes, Tess as a cheerleader flirting with footballers, George volunteering at a soup kitchen, Tess in a bikini getting soaked at a car wash, George at the United Nations, Tess in Europe with two guys, George helping with an animal charity, and Tess eating ribs. A slideshow then shows George looking unhappy with his proud parents, juxtaposed with scenes of Tess in a fight, grimacing at a baby, and showing fear of George's dog.

Behind the couple, who are no longer as happy, Casey stands up. Jane looks miserable as Tess runs up to her. Jane tries to speak but no sound comes out; she stands awkwardly, biting her lip, tears welling in her eyes.
