Audrey, sitting on a bench seat, hugs her knees and shivers as blood drips from the ceiling onto her head. She notices two stains above her.

Percy and Kyle then haul Howard to an SUV, his toes dragging on the ground. They load him into the back with Sandra and Audrey. The SUV reverses and then drives back onto the road, heading toward a dark cloud in the distance that Audrey spots. The cloud resembles spreading smoke. As they drive, a fly enters through a grill, followed by others splattering onto the windscreen, and then thousands storm in through the grill.

Back at the diner, in the men's room, Jeep vomits into a cubicle. Bob, standing by a nearby sink, drinks from a can and sees Jeep's reflection in the mirror. Bob pats Jeep's shoulder comfortingly before turning at the sound of a car, indicating the others' return. He grabs Percy, and they both rush inside as Bob looks up to see a giant storm of flies looming overhead, darkening the sky. Bob quickly retreats inside.

The gruesome face of old Gladys is uncovered from under a plastic sheet. Bob and Jeep carry her out, accompanied by Kyle, as they watch an approaching police squad car. Kyle then turns to Jeep and Bob, signaling a moment of reflection amidst the chaos.
857:
A tall, gaunt man dressed in a light shirt, dark floppy bow tie, and light trousers steps in front of his van, headlights still illuminating the area. He advances, his movement drawing the attention of Bob, who watches as the ice cream man sniffs the air before opening his mouth. The man's arms stretch out from his sleeves; he then bends and bounds forward like a stick insect. As he leaps, Michael shoots him, continuing to fire until the man hits the ground and stops twitching.

Inside the diner, tension is palpable as the women and Jeep appear anxious. From their vantage point on the roof, they turn their heads to spot lights approaching along the road. Two columns of cars, their drivers convulsing and heads shaking violently, bear down on the diner as if on tracks. Bullets strike the lead vehicles, causing them to spin on the road while shells cascade at the feet of the shooters. One car collides with another, flipping over and erupting in flames. The bursts of gunfire briefly light up the faces of those on the roof.

Michael, moving along the walkway, notices more lights from the opposite direction, led by a villain car followed by a truck. He launches a grenade, destroying the lead vehicle, then opens fire on the truck, which spills its load of pipes and crashes into other cars. The surviving vehicles come to a halt, their doors opening to release drivers and passengers who walk calmly towards the diner. From above, the group observes the approaching crowd, their faces impassive. Among them, Kyle spots a young girl in a white party dress holding a balloon, her gaze seemingly fixed on him. There are men, women, and children in the group.

Michael initiates firing again, causing people to fall. Shells drop from the rifles as, inside the diner, Jeep nervously moves a torch around. His father continues to shoot several of the advancing individuals. Michael separates from the other three, while Sandra and Audrey stand near Howard, who lies on the floor. Charlie's attention is drawn to the window above the office desk where someone bursts through, though the intruder remains unseen initially.

Charlie rises from behind the counter as Howard yells, being dragged by the legs by a young-faced female intruder towards the shattered window. The others struggle to hold onto Howard as the woman leaps out, still pulling him. In the chaos, her arm is grabbed, and as she cuts Charlie, a knife slices through his wrist, severing his hand. Michael, now inside, witnesses Howard being pulled out. With an assault rifle in each hand, Michael shoots out of the window.
860:
A man sits quietly, while a woman gazes downward. Jeep's expression shifts from a frown to a hardened look before he turns and walks away. Overwhelmed, Charlie's face contorts as she breaks into sobs. As wisps of clouds drift past the moon, Kyle and Audrey stand on the roof; Audrey, with an assault rifle in hand, eventually sets it down. Kyle looks away, lost in thought, as Audrey shakes her head before breaking into a broad grin. Both then look down contemplatively from their vantage point.

Inside the building, additional lights flicker on, and the jukebox begins to hum to life. Back on the roof, Kyle and Audrey survey the dark landscape until their attention is caught by a vehicle speeding along the freeway. Bob emerges from the kitchen, joining Jeep and Charlie at the window to peer through the blinds at the van maneuvering through the cluttered cars in front of the diner.

On the roof, Kyle gives Audrey a dark look before they both aim their weapons—Kyle with his assault rifle and Audrey with her pistol—as the van stops at the gas pumps. A man exits the vehicle, gesturing to its occupants, while a child inside watches him grab the gas nozzle. The little boy, pressing his hands against the window, looks up at Kyle and Audrey.

Suddenly, Audrey dashes to the edge of the roof for a better view, with Kyle following her gaze. Several cars emerge from the darkness, heading towards the diner. Kyle's focus sharpens on the man at the van, while inside, the boy starts banging on the window. The vehicles converge as the man drops the gas nozzle and attempts to return to the driver's side, but a car swerves into him, sending him flying. The vehicle comes to a halt, and a punky-looking individual steps out, followed by a van from which a chaotic group spills out.

They surround the van, force it open, and seize the boy. Kyle, shooting at the encroaching group, leaps over the diner's wall and rushes toward the chaos, his gun blazing. Meanwhile, inside, Bob starts tearing away planks from the windows, only to turn and find Michael pointing a gun at him. Amid the turmoil, Kyle reaches the boy, lifting him up and fending off the attackers.

Clutching the child close, Kyle faces the advancing crowd, only to meet the boy's gaze and see his black eyes moments before the boy bites him in the neck. Kyle collapses, and inside, Bob kicks over a chair in frustration. Audrey descends from the roof, charging into the fray with her gun firing. She targets the boy but finds herself out of ammunition. Staring at the boy, whose mouth is smeared with blood, Audrey quickly gets into the van and shuts the door as the possessed begin to climb onto the vehicle.

In the tense aftermath, Charlie turns to face Michael, who simply stares back at her, his expression unreadable.
861:
A French tricolor flag lies submerged beneath the waves. A wooden galleon, tilting heavily to its starboard side, is being dragged through turbulent seas into a dry dock. Lines of men, tugging on thick ropes connected to the ship, stand within the dock. The sea surges into the dock, engulfing the men in the center up to their waists, while others occupy higher positions within the structure. These men, scruffy and unshaven, are prisoners who grunt as they pull the ropes in unison, the rough, chained ropes passing through their hands.

Overseeing them from high above on the quay side stands Javert, a grave-looking man dressed in a blue uniform. His gaze is fixed intently on one particular prisoner, who deliberately avoids eye contact. Once the ship is secured in the dock, the prisoners begin to file out. Javert stops one, the very prisoner he had been watching closely. This tall prisoner, sporting a beard and closely-cropped hair with a slight stoop, turns back to pick up a long, thick flagpole from the ground. He heaves it onto his shoulder after squatting and struggling to his feet. Grimacing under the weight, he lumbers forward while Javert watches with a cold stare. The flag, still attached to the pole, trails through the water until the prisoner reaches Javert and drops the pole. Javert's eyes remain fixed on the prisoner, Valjean, who staggers away from the dry dock.

Valjean, using a stout staff, plods across the rocky terrain of a mountain top towards a cross on the summit. As he passes the cross, the sun begins to rise, casting light on the path ahead. He continues his journey up a snow-covered hillside, a solitary figure silhouetted against the skyline. With a satchel over his shoulder, he steps onto a ledge and takes a moment to glance at the mountains ahead. Spotting men at work, he approaches a farmer and removes his woolen hat as the farmer reads some documents. As Valjean departs, a fleshy-jowled town hall officer turns to a guard.

On the street, children pelt Valjean with stones. Seeking warmth, he holds his hands over a fire inside an inn. Suddenly, Valjean is attacked outside, enduring punches and kicks. He wanders into a churchyard and lies down near the church, where he is startled awake by a cleric, a bishop, holding a lamp. Frowning, Valjean finds himself crouching by a blazing fire, then seated at a table where he ravenously shovels down food. He pauses to look at the bishop and two women standing nearby. Rising, he watches as one of the women places silverware into a cupboard. Lying in a bed later, he stares at an ornate ceiling before getting up to approach the cupboard. As the bishop sleeps, Valjean stealthily stuffs silverware into his satchel.
863:
In the grim atmosphere of a slum at night, a smartly-dressed man approaches Fantine, removing his hat before forcefully grabbing her dress and pressing himself against her. Fantine resists, scratching his face, but he shoves her away as Javert, the inspector, arrives on the scene. Recognizing Valjean nearby, Fantine turns her back to him, breathing rapidly in distress before spitting in his face, causing him to recoil. Javert signals to one of his men to hold back, then lifts Fantine into his arms as they depart, with Javert observing their exit.

Later, Javert is handed a letter which he opens and reads while standing in the snow. After a brief glance upward, he crumples the letter. Facing Valjean, whose brow is furrowed as he rises from his seat, Javert appears puzzled. He then gives a curt bow and leaves, with Valjean watching him go before leaning on his desk. In a subsequent scene, Valjean kneels at an altar in church, packs money and papers into a case, and takes a carriage to court where he is escorted out by a court usher under the watchful eyes of onlookers.

At the hospital, a nurse attends to Fantine, who lies semiconscious on her back. The nurse uses a cloth to dab Fantine's forehead before exiting the room. Valjean enters, and as he does, an image of a nine-year-old blonde girl appears and then vanishes. Fantine's condition deteriorates; she becomes still, her head lolling to one side. Valjean gently closes her lifeless eyes and bends forward to kiss her on the temple.

The tension escalates when Javert draws his sword. Valjean, having fended off Javert with a baton torn from the wall, is disarmed but quickly turns, rushes out of the door, and dives into the river below. Javert runs out in pursuit but finds no trace of Valjean. Meanwhile, Fantine lies peacefully in her hospital bed.

Elsewhere, at an inn, young and grubby Cosette gazes enviously at children playing in the snow, her glare intense. The innkeeper, Thenardier, rises and moves among his discreet patrons, offering a drink to a staggering man and taking his reading glasses. His wife, mingling with the clientele, musses a soldier's jacket and gazes admiringly at a handsome man. The scene shifts to outside where a silver-haired gentleman sits alone on a crate by a mule.
864:
In a dark forest, young Cosette, resembling an urchin, carries a bucket when she spots Valjean approaching. Startled, she drops the bucket and rushes to conceal herself behind a tree, observing him with fear. The moonlight softly illuminates her youthful face. Her expression brightens upon recognizing him; she then takes his arm as he picks up the bucket filled with water and they walk through the town. Madame Thenardier intercepts them, taking the bucket away. Thenardier, with open arms, gestures to Cosette, who shakes her head in refusal and stays put despite his beckoning. Madame Thenardier reacts with a gasp. Valjean retrieves his hat, previously snatched by Thenardier, and takes Cosette away, presenting her with a doll before carrying her off.

Inside an inn, the scene shifts as Javert arrives on horseback and then departs. Madame Thenardier forcefully shoves her husband, who attempts a kiss only to be pushed away. Meanwhile, Valjean and Cosette travel through the night in a carriage, with Cosette asleep, her head on Valjean's lap. He gently strokes her hair as moonlight filters through the trees. Valjean fondly gazes at the sleeping girl until he spots Javert. Quickly, he hides the doll inside his coat. They exit the carriage and escape hand in hand along the city wall. Javert, on horseback, sees them and gives chase along a colonnade. Valjean climbs over a stone balustrade, lifting Cosette to safety, leaving Javert unable to follow, forcing him to turn back.

Valjean then uses a rope hanging from a building to descend, while Javert, now on foot, searches through dark alleyways. Valjean climbs atop a wall with Cosette watching fearfully as he struggles. Using the rope, he pulls her up beside him, and they remain still on the wall top as Javert passes below and eventually leaves. Valjean then lowers Cosette down the other side of the wall with the rope and follows her down, carrying her onward. They come across a chapel, its interior bathed in the warm glow of candlelight, where nuns are singing. As Valjean, holding Cosette, turns, he notices a stout, scruffy balding man who discards his spade and removes his hat. They depart with this man, Fauchelevant.

High on a tower, Javert stands before an ornate cross, closes a Bible, and steps out onto a ledge overlooking Paris, a huge stone eagle beside him and the tower soaring to a spire topped with a cross. In the wasteland where the Bastille once stood, a giant elephant, originally a model for Napoleon's planned monument, now stands neglected and decaying. A scruffy, ratty-haired urchin emerges from a hole in the elephant's head.
865:
In the heart of Paris, a group of mischievous urchins emerges from an elephant statue, skillfully sliding down ropes. They dash across a desolate wasteland and burst into a bustling restaurant, snatching food amidst the chaos. Nearby, beggars extend their hands in silent plea towards affluent Parisians. Amidst the crowd, the first urchin approaches a well-dressed couple seated in a carriage.

Gavroche, agile and daring, leaps from carriage top to carriage top before disappearing into the crowd. Soon, he is seen perched on the back of a moving carriage, traversing the city streets. Young students begin to mingle with the beggars and urchins, some taking a stand on a platform. As police on horseback approach, the students distribute leaflets to the gathered crowd.

An elderly gentleman, identified as the white-headed man, heads towards his carriage. Nearby, his grandson Marius, along with others, raises his fist defiantly into the air. Later, in the solitude of his attic room, Marius removes a gold ring from his finger and retrieves a pistol from a case. A beautiful young woman, Eponine, the daughter of the Thenardiers, stands at the doorway, watching him thoughtfully as he steps out onto the street.

Marius pauses to allow a carriage to pass but is soon distracted by a scene across the street where Valjean is handing money to a beggar. Accompanying him is Cosette, a stunning young woman with flowing blonde hair. She notices Marius watching her, visibly captivated. Cosette also gives a coin to the beggar and, catching Marius's eye, offers a smile as she departs with Valjean. Eponine, witnessing the exchange, looks on with a tinge of sadness.

Thenardier, lurking near a dilapidated hovel, spots Valjean and Cosette and approaches them. But before he can reach them, they flee. Thenardier, undeterred, grovels and dusts off Javert's jacket, who in turn scrutinizes him carefully. As this unfolds, Marius approaches and, spotting Cosette as she walks away, he grabs her arm and smiles.

Inside a dimly lit tavern, the students gather for a meeting. Marius sits, lost in his thoughts, drawing a frown from Enjolras. Spotting Eponine, Marius rushes over to her, but she leaves. He exchanges a glance with Enjolras and follows her out.

Meanwhile, in her cozy bedroom, Cosette is joined by Valjean who enters carrying a candle. Noticing a scar on his wrist, Cosette looks visibly affected and soon walks out of the front door, leaving Valjean knitting his fingers together in reflection.

Under the cover of night, Marius finds himself on a dark street, pursued by Eponine. From the shadows, he peers through the railings into Valjean's garden. Cosette approaches him, walking past branches heavy with blossom, her gaze fixed on him. After a moment, she heads back to the house, and Marius, after lingering, departs. Inside, Cosette follows Valjean. As Marius walks away, he spots Cosette's handkerchief on the ground, picks it up, and continues on his path. Eponine, her spirits low, melts into the shadows.

Thenardier, accompanied by his accomplice Babet, walks down the street. He confronts Eponine and delivers a harsh slap. Meanwhile, Cosette, appearing desperate, receives a candlestick from Valjean which she places in her bag. She then seals a letter with wax, rushes to the garden, and slips it through the railings. Eponine, ever watchful, emerges from the shadows and retrieves the letter.
866:
Eponine receives a letter directed to Marius, which she opens and reads, her expression turning distressed. Amidst heavy rainfall that drenches the cobbled streets, she walks slowly, completely soaked, through the darkness. Meanwhile, the Place de la Bastille is lined with student protesters and townspeople. Inside the elephant, Gavroche and other urchins gather. A procession of soldiers marches down the street, followed by cavalry, with a large black hearse for General Lamarque trailing behind them.

Enjolras, waving a red flag, climbs onto the street, soon joined by Marius and others. Javert observes from within the crowd. Tensions rise as the cavalry confront the protesters amassed around the hearse; Enjolras and Marius ready their pistols, while soldiers raise swords and aim muskets. A shot rings out from a soldier, striking a woman who collapses. The cavalry charge forward, initiating a fierce exchange of gunfire between the men and the soldiers. Enjolras fires his weapon, and amid the chaos, one student, Courfeyrac, is knocked down. Javert, disguised in civilian clothing, assists him back to his feet.

Marius rides down the street as the construction of a barricade begins; a cart is overturned and furniture is hurled from windows. A cannon is maneuvered into position, and students start shooting from behind the newly formed barricade. The cavalry is pursued down the street by armed citizens as protesters scatter through the streets. Amid the turmoil, Marius encounters a couple in an intimate moment, his face lighting up with excitement. Courfeyrac's voice rings out, adding to the chaos, as more tables and even pianos are thrown from windows.

Inside a cafe, Javert covertly takes a rosette, pinning it onto his dark jacket. Additional items like a couch and another cart are added to the barricade, further blocking the street. An old woman is kissed, her chair taken for the cause. Javert also acquires a pistol, and a red flag is tossed to Marius. Climbing atop the barricade, Enjolras waves the flag vigorously, while people from the surrounding buildings wave tricolors in solidarity.

Javert makes a return, prompting everyone to raise their weapons. In a burst of action, he manages to throw off the men restraining him and lands several punches, though the students eventually overpower him. Enjolras decisively knocks him out with a club. Both Enjolras and Marius, showing concern, scan their surroundings, then grab their weapons and lead their group back to the barricade. A woman nearby closes her shutters, as the students take their positions at the barricade, aiming their weapons.

A platoon of soldiers advances up the street to confront them. The light flickers across Enjolras's determined face, and the street is illuminated by sparking gunpowder. The students return fire as soldiers attempt to scale the barricade, with more shots being fired through it. A soldier lies dead atop the barricade. Marius, seizing a barrel of gunpowder that suddenly ignites, is called out to by Gavroche. Behind the barricade, Eponine steps into view just as a soldier aims at Marius. She grabs the musket, sacrificing herself as she is shot. Marius, holding a torch, begins to lower it towards the flaming gunpowder. An officer, noticing the imminent danger, turns to his men, who quickly retreat. Enjolras, breathless, takes the torch from Marius's hand, ready to continue the fight.
867:
Eponine, wounded from a gunshot, sits hunched over, clutching her chest. Marius squats beside her, wrapping an arm around her comfortingly. Raindrops glisten on her pale face as her eyes close. With her last bit of strength, she reaches out to touch Marius's face, gazing at him, before her hand drops lifelessly to her side. Young Gavroche, tearfully watching nearby, is moved by the scene. Marius tenderly kisses Eponine's brow, while Enjolras, grave-faced, also observes. Enjolras then squats down to help Marius carry Eponine away from the scene.

Overwhelmed with emotion, Marius stares at a letter from Cosette, his eyes filled with tears. Clutching the letter, he approaches Gavroche, who quickly ascends a dark stairway to deliver it to Valjean and Cosette's lodgings. Gavroche hesitates for a moment before continuing his journey. Valjean, upon receiving the letter, reads it with a deepening frown. He then gazes up at the sky, lost in thought, and surveys his surroundings.

Outside, Valjean stealthily takes a dead soldier's jacket, a peaked cap, and a musket, disguising himself as a soldier. He makes his way to a barricade manned by watchful students. Upon removing his cap, he is permitted entry, though met with guns pointed at him. Inside, Javert stands with a noose around his neck. Valjean looks up, then shoots a soldier off a nearby rooftop. Gavroche hands Valjean a pistol. Beaten and bloodied, Javert, with his hands tied and the noose still around his neck, stares blankly at Valjean. Valjean pulls Javert's head up to meet his gaze, and they lock eyes for a moment. Then, Valjean drags Javert to his feet and leads him to a dark corner, where he holds up a dagger. Facing each other, Valjean cuts the ropes binding Javert's wrists. Javert, incredulous, walks away, turns back briefly, and then continues off into the darkness. Valjean aims his pistol at Javert, walks towards him, and then fires into a wall, prompting Javert to stop, look back, and then leave.

Returning to the group, Valjean is met with serious expressions. He nods as Enjolras addresses everyone. Marius, who had been adjusting the barricade, sits with the others as wine is passed around. Frowning, Valjean listens to Marius, who is clutching Cosette's handkerchief. Standing nearby, Valjean wears a fraught and serious expression as he leans in a doorway and watches Marius. Later, Valjean stands beside the sleeping Marius, who looks fearfully at Enjolras as everyone around them appears thoughtful.

Tragedy strikes as a soldier shoots at Gavroche, who had climbed through the barricade. Gavroche is hit, shot again, and falls dead on his back. One of the students retrieves Gavroche's body and carries it back behind the barricade, with Marius providing cover with his musket. An army officer observes the scene. Behind the barricade, Gavroche's body is laid on the ground as Enjolras, looking heavy-hearted, surveys the situation. As cannons are rolled forward, the students manage to shoot down a few soldiers.
870:
In the early morning, a beam of light emanating from a lighthouse sweeps gracefully across the shimmering blue expanse of the ocean. Nearby, Kate Armstrong, a woman in her late 30s with striking brunette hair, raises her eyebrows thoughtfully. She then ties a dazzling white chef's apron around her waist in the tidy kitchen of her restaurant, preparing for the day ahead. She checks the orders pinned to a shelf before stepping into the walk-in fridge, where she leans wearily against a rack.

In the restaurant, Kate engages in a warm conversation with a middle-aged couple, Mr. and Mrs. Peterson, who soon depart. She then shakes hands with another couple, Ken and his wife, before making her way back through the bustling restaurant. In the kitchen, she addresses her busy chefs, who continue their tasks diligently. Holding two plates of food, Kate turns, her lips pursed in contemplation of their response.

As night falls, snow gently descends on Kate as she walks along a New York street. Her long hair, which had been neatly tied up in a bun, now flows freely under a black beret. She enters her modest apartment, dropping her keys into a bowl on a cabinet and placing some mail beside it. She checks her phone messages before drifting off to sleep. The next morning at half past four, she blearily reaches out to silence her alarm clock.

Later, Kate visits a fish market, and back at home, she dons a blue apron over her black top and jeans to cook. Her cooking is interrupted by the phone, which she hurries to answer. Leaving her apartment, she descends a flight of stairs, briefly turns back upon seeing a neighbor, Sean, and then continues downstairs as he enters his apartment. She then retraces her steps up the curving staircase, unlocks her door, pauses briefly beside it, and then closes it again.

At her therapist's office, Kate garnishes a plate of food and watches as he begins to eat. She turns away, seemingly lost in thought. Back at the restaurant, the atmosphere is lively but chaotic as a waitress, Bernadette, collides with a colleague, causing a bottle to be handed to pregnant Leah. Kate, hearing the phone, reluctantly approaches it and turns away from the kitchen's noise as she listens, her eyes filling with tears.

Overcome with emotion, Kate rushes down a hospital corridor and stops at the reception desk to speak with a nurse, who directs her to a room opposite. Entering the room, she finds her young niece, Zoe, lying in bed with her eyes closed, bearing grazes above and below her right eye. Kate circles the bed, her gaze filled with sadness. A balding doctor in his 40s, Dr. Barton, stands in the doorway, offers a comforting pat on Kate's shoulder, and then leaves. Kate stares out the window at the sleeping Zoe, later falling asleep herself in a chair beside her niece's bed.
874:
Kate gradually awakens, absorbing her surroundings before her gaze shifts to Zoe, who stares back at her intently. Aunt and niece share a prolonged, silent exchange. Eventually, Kate sits up, her eyes fixed unwaveringly on the young girl. Tears begin to stream down Zoe's cheeks as Kate nods with a heavy heart. Zoe's face, contorted in anguish, reflects her deep sorrow, while a single tear trickles down Kate's face. Exhausted, Kate enters her apartment, removes her long, red scarf, and approaches the answer machine. Standing transfixed in the hallway, she clutches her coat before turning and moving back toward the door.

At the restaurant, all eyes turn to watch Kate as she walks in and past them. Paula sets her wineglass down. In the empty kitchen, Kate ties her apron around her waist and then walks away, ignoring Paula. Leah, concerned, observes Kate, who appears distracted and teary-eyed. Inside the walk-in fridge, Kate crouches on the floor, reading Christine's letter. Through a window in the door, Paula watches her. Distraught, Kate looks up as Paula enters, nods with a quivering chin, and Paula gently takes hold of Kate's hands.

In Zoe's hospital room, Kate enters and walks to the end of Zoe's bed, placing her bag on the over-bed table. She then moves the bag to a chair by the window, sets her handbag beside it, and removes her coat and scarf while speaking to Zoe. Zoe, turning away, resumes watching a Bugs Bunny cartoon. Kate sits in the chair beside the bed. Zoe gives a faint nod and refocuses on the TV.

A yellow taxicab travels along a New York street, with Zoe in the back seat, her gaze lost through the rain-splashed window. The cab stops, and Zoe and Kate exit. Zoe, with a red rucksack slung over her shoulder, looks up at Kate's apartment building, a smart brownstone with a broad set of steps leading to an arched entranceway. Inside, Kate gives Zoe a tour of the apartment, walking down a hallway. Zoe slowly enters her new bedroom, which is light and airy, featuring a large bay window with a seat and a spacious double bed.

At a cemetery high on a hill overlooking the city, Zoe stares morosely at her mother's casket by the graveside. As other mourners start to leave, Zoe turns to Kate, and the two walk away together slowly. A large, lifelike cuddly toy giraffe is carried up the steps of Kate's brownstone, followed by more toys and a bike being brought inside. Zoe carries a stuffed elephant, and a collection of cuddly toys is arranged around her new room.
876:
A photograph album opens to reveal a snapshot of Christine holding baby Zoe. Another page shows Christine beaming beside a birthday cake. Further on, there's a picture of Zoe clutching a teddy bear, followed by an image of Christine and Kate, arms entwined, smiling broadly for the camera. The album concludes with recent shots of Zoe. Kate gently closes the album and sets it atop the chest of drawers, then dims the lamp and moves slowly around the bed to sit on its edge, her gaze drifting downward in wistful reflection.

The following morning, Zoe stands by the bed, watching her mother Kate sleep. As Kate's eyes flutter open, she glances at the clock, still groggy. Meanwhile, Zoe is in her room, fixating on Kate with a steady stare. Kate, exhaling a resigned sigh, begins to rummage through a cardboard box in Zoe's room. She pulls out a scarf, which Zoe dismisses with a headshake. Kate searches further, unearthing another, met with the same gesture from Zoe. Returning the pink, stripy scarf to the box, Kate moves on to sift through a second container. Zoe follows her into the hallway where Kate grabs her keys and coat. As Kate heads to the door, Zoe lingers, staring at it. Kate returns to her, noting Zoe's nod and subsequent averted gaze.

With Zoe now adorned in a red woolen hat and a multicolored scarf, they leave the house. Kate returns momentarily with coffee. They walk down the street and pause by a yellow school bus parked outside a large, brown brick building. Inside the school, they navigate a corridor adorned with children's artwork. Ellen takes Zoe's hand and leads her away as Kate, elsewhere, lies incredulously on her therapist's couch.

As the school day ends, a group of children rush down the steps of Zoe's school. Kate, waiting with other parents and guardians, breaks into a smile upon seeing Zoe emerge independently. Together, they stroll down the street and back home where Zoe sits at the table, and Kate brings over her plate.

Suddenly, Kate hurries to answer the front door, where she encounters a teenager sporting a nose piercing and a goth style. Kate sizes her up before turning to see Zoe pass by, then back to the visitor, Charlotte, whom she greets with an awkward smile. Charlotte steps into the apartment, and Kate closes the door, then proceeds toward Zoe's room, where they exchange a meaningful glance.

Later, at a restaurant, in the kitchen, Leah and Nick are busy as Kate walks by and turns off the CD player. Nick glances up, slightly taken aback, as Kate shows a hint of irritation. The restaurant staff gather around a table where Nick serves spaghetti, and a plate is passed to Kate. Nick, with his handsome, shaggy hair, looks at her, a little disconcerted by the earlier interaction.
877:
At a dinner gathering, Nick exchanges a meaningful glance with Paula before carrying a plate of spaghetti to Kate, who is engrossed in a crossword puzzle at the table's far end. As he sets the dish in front of her, Kate tucks her pencil into her neat bun and begins to eat. Meanwhile, Leah and Bernadette observe the interaction while enjoying their own meal. Kate looks up at Nick with a petulant expression, then glares at him as he returns to Paula. Frustrated, Kate stands abruptly and storms out of the room.

In her office, Kate vents her anger by slicing a menu in half before returning to her paperwork. Later, in the bustling kitchen, Kate approaches Nick, who offers her a taste of his cooking from a pan. Using her own spoon, Kate samples the dish but quickly walks away. Nick tastes the sauce himself and seems pleased, then stirs another pan and smiles while chatting with Leah. Kate notices their conversation and disapprovingly looks over at them. Leah throws her head back and laughs.

Nick catches Kate's eye and offers her another taste from a different pan, but she dismissively shakes her head and leaves. The kitchen showcases an array of desserts on pristine white plates, including a chocolate pudding garnished with raspberries, a chocolate teardrop topped with cream, and a flawless fruit tart. Kate uses a blowtorch to caramelize a fourth dessert, then nearly collides with Nick as she turns from her workspace. Nick places a plate on the worktop and picks up a bottle of dessert sauce, while Kate grabs another bottle and begins decorating her plate. She briefly glances at him before delicately placing a spun-sugar cage over a white chocolate mousse on a bed of strawberries. Nick watches closely, making Kate uneasy, and she accidentally breaks the cage. She then picks up the dessert plate along with another sugar cage and moves to the other side of the worktop. Nick contemplates her as she walks away.

In the walk-in fridge, Bernadette hurries out, leaving Kate leaning wearily against a shelving unit. As Nick enters and approaches her, Kate looks away. Nick removes his apron, and they exit the fridge together. Kate then turns to Leah, who looks at her pleadingly. With a cool gaze at Nick, Kate activates her blowtorch. As Nick walks past her, Kate, distracted, holds the blowtorch at her side. A tea towel tucked into her apron catches fire, but she quickly throws it to the floor and extinguishes the flames by stamping on them.
880:
In a quiet moment, Zoe lies on her bed, facing away from her aunt Kate. Suddenly, Zoe turns and sits up slightly, prompting a silent exchange of stares between the aunt and niece. Kate's gaze drops to the floor, and she turns to exit the room, offering a faint smile as she does so.

The scene shifts to a bustling restaurant where Zoe meticulously peels asparagus spears. Nearby on her chopping board, three black truffles await their use. Kate approaches, setting down a plate beside Zoe, and delicately grates a small portion of one truffle over a roast quail before handing the dish off to a colleague. Zoe, meanwhile, discards the asparagus trimmings into a bin. She then picks up a truffle, sniffs it with disdain, and tosses it, along with the others, into the bin. Upon her return with another plate, Kate notices the missing truffles in the bin, retrieves them, and places them into a yellow lockbox containing additional truffles, all under Zoe's bemused watch. Nearby, Nick, smiling to himself, chats with Zoe while chopping onions. Zoe, equipped with a large stainless steel bowl, kneels before a box of potatoes, as Nick selects a couple to show her. As Zoe fills the bowls with potatoes and carries them away, Nick continues his conversation on the phone in the office. Later, Nick extends a spoonful of sauce to Zoe, who tastes it and nods in approval.

The mood lightens as Zoe teaches Nick some dance moves, both energetically punching the air and pointing. Back in the restaurant, Nick serves pasta to the eagerly awaiting staff. In another instance, Zoe hands a plate to Kate, who attempts to pass it on but is rebuffed by her already occupied colleague, prompting Kate to reluctantly accept the plate back from Zoe. Zoe's gaze fixes on Kate before she taps her shoulder and extends the plate again. Kate, somewhat hesitantly, takes it and starts eating, eventually nodding and smiling warmly at Nick.

In a serene park, Zoe, who had been walking along the benches beside Kate, halts and leans in to whisper something in Kate's ear. Zoe then jumps down and walks ahead. The restaurant setting resumes as Nick enters the kitchen, tying on his white apron. Later, Kate pulls back a curtain to observe Zoe pacing on the wintry street below their apartment. Smiling, Kate heads downstairs. Back inside, Zoe stands on a stool in the bathroom, braiding her hair, before rushing to the apartment door, swinging it open, and dashing downstairs. Nick, meanwhile, inspects Kate's cupboards, and Kate retrieves a box from his bag. In the kitchen, Zoe ushers Kate out as Nick demonstrates to Zoe the art of crafting a pizza base.
882:
In the opening scene, a lady's hand meticulously crafts a piece of floral embroidery. Transitioning to the outdoors, two horses gallop energetically across the picturesque English countryside. Their riders, pausing at a vantage point, gaze upon a spacious mansion nestled amidst distant trees. With a beaming smile, Mr. Bingley spurs his horse onward towards his new estate, closely followed by a more reserved Mr. Darcy.

Observing from a distance, the thundering horses catch the eye of a young woman, Elizabeth Bennet. Up on a hillside, Elizabeth turns away from the scene, a playful smile gracing her lips. Dressed in a straw bonnet and a simple day dress, she then sets off down a country lane, absorbing the verdant surroundings before accelerating into a canter. Having gathered a bouquet of wildflowers from the woods, she traverses a small field where a chestnut mare and her foal graze leisurely under the sun. Continuing her journey, Elizabeth heads towards the nearby village.

As she nears her home, Longbourn, the sound of her sisters arguing inside causes her to bypass the entrance. Peering into her father's study, Elizabeth shares a knowing smile and eye roll with her father. In another part of the house, Lydia playfully dons Kitty's bonnet, prompting Kitty to dash out of the room in tears, passing Jane in the hallway. Outside the local church, Mrs. Bennet engages in a deep conversation with a neighbor. Her five daughters begin to trail behind their father, prompting Mrs. Bennet to hastily join them.

Back at Longbourn, Mr. Bennet strides into the house, placing his hat and cane aside, while a maid rushes to attend to Mrs. Bennet. Elizabeth and Jane exchange amused smiles, and Lydia rolls her eyes at the commotion. Later that evening, Jane sits at her dressing table, brushing her long, flaxen hair by candlelight, with a wistful Elizabeth seated behind her. Elizabeth affectionately kisses Jane on the head before leaving the room and closing her bedroom door.

Downstairs, Mr. Bennet works late into the night in his study, meticulously reviewing household accounts. After marking entries in a book and replacing his quill, he shakes his head wearily and leans back in his chair. With a mischievous glance, he reaches for a decanter of liquor. Meanwhile, upstairs, Elizabeth leans on her dressing table, examining her reflection and practicing various facial expressions before extinguishing her candle and retiring for the night.

The scene shifts to the bustling main street where a grand carriage, escorted by torch-bearing men, pulls up outside The Assembly Rooms. A servant opens the door and extends the steps. Mr. Bingley steps out first, his smile wide as he surveys his surroundings and dons a large Napoleonic-style hat. A more somber Mr. Darcy follows, with Miss Bingley, adorned in a grand ball gown and feather hat, stepping out last.
885:
As the evening unfolds at the dance, Mr. Hurst arrives, adding to the gathering. Inside the hall, Fitzwilliam Darcy surveys the building with a noticeable detachment. The atmosphere inside is vibrant; men and women clad in pastel gowns, smiles on their faces, hold hands and twirl in a joyous circle. From the sidelines, an older man, Sir William Lucas, enthusiastically claps along to the music.

Amidst the crowd, Lizzie and Lydia, adorned in their empire-line dresses, revel in the festivities. They gracefully perform the dance steps, setting to their partners with dainty movements, executing a do-si-do before rejoining the circle. The dancers then shift into a two-line formation facing the chamber musicians, where the ladies and gentlemen engage with their partners before gliding across the floor in a spectacular display of color and feathers.

The arrival of the Bingley party is announced by an awestruck silence that sweeps over the room. The new guests appear visibly uncomfortable until Sir William Lucas hastens to greet them warmly. As dancing resumes, Lizzie joins her sisters Jane and Mary, who are conversing with Sir William's daughter, Charlotte. The two younger Bennet sisters then move to stand by their mother, and the ladies offer a respectful curtsy. However, Darcy, with a brusque bow, departs the scene, much to Mrs. Bennet's chagrin.

Jane exchanges a quick look with her mother before focusing her attention back on Bingley. Later, she is seen dancing with him, their hands clasped as they share warm smiles. Meanwhile, Darcy watches from the side, his disdain unmistakable. His gaze then shifts to Mrs. Bennet, who is presiding over a group enjoying tea and cake, openly expressing her contempt for him. Continuing his survey of the room, Darcy notices Kitty and Lydia causing a ruckus as they dash through the hall.

Outside, the local men, in high spirits, mimic the dancing inside on the dark street. One man, caught up in the fervor, trips and tumbles into a water trough. Back inside, as Jane and Bingley conclude their dance, Bingley gently takes Jane's hand to introduce her to his sisters. Mrs. Bennet watches with a satisfied smile. The couple soon takes to the dance floor again, Bingley looking dashing in a dark tailcoat and pale satin breeches, while Jane is elegant in her creamy gold dress with puff sleeves and long white evening gloves. Bingley, with his noble features and fair, curly hair, moves with practiced ease and grace on the dance floor.

Darcy continues his somber patrol through the hall, his expression one of grim forbearance. Sir William approaches him but then decides against speaking. Nearby, Lizzie sits with the more serious Mary. Bingley, showing a touch of nervousness, allows Jane to lead him over to meet Charlotte Lucas. As another dance commences, Lizzie overhears Bingley's conversation and feels a surge of irritation. Bingley then departs, and Lizzie, having caught the exchange, casts a sidelong glance at Darcy. With a mischievous smile playing on her lips, she rises and deliberately crosses the room in front of him.
887:
Lizzie sits attentively by Jane's bedside, tenderly caressing her sleeping sister's face. As Jane's eyes flutter open, she weakly gazes at Lizzie, who responds with an encouraging smile. The scene shifts to the dining room where Miss Bingley's cheerfulness wanes, and she strides across the room. Lizzie is then ushered into the room amidst the chaos of two spaniels startling pheasants from a bush outside. From Jane's bedroom window, Lizzie observes the ongoing shooting party, then turns her attention back to her sister, who manages a weak smile. Lizzie, moved to tears, returns the smile.

As the twilight sets in, the hunting party makes its way back to Netherfield Hall. Lizzie, now facing away from a mirror, is adorned in a white silk gown. Sharing a heartfelt moment, the sisters exchange smiles. Lizzie proceeds down a staircase, her movements tinged with uncertainty. Startled by a footman, she manages a grateful smile before nervously scanning her surroundings, unsure of the drawing room's location. Her search leads her into a dimly lit corridor and eventually into the billiard room where Darcy, playing alone, acknowledges her presence with a swift bow. Lizzie, momentarily frozen in the doorway, quickly retreats. Darcy watches her departure with a pensive look before resuming his game.

In the drawing room, Lizzie immerses herself in a book. Darcy, after a brief glance at an ongoing card game, approaches her and takes a seat at a nearby desk, prompting raised eyebrows among the onlookers. As Darcy becomes aware of being addressed, Lizzie smiles. Their eyes lock in a thoughtful exchange.

The scene transitions to Mrs. Bennet being conveyed in a carriage, with Lydia and Kitty eagerly leaning out to view the imposing red brick facade of Netherfield Hall. They are then welcomed inside, while Darcy exits the scene. Mr. Bingley shoots a stern look at his giggling sisters. Lizzie, overwhelmed, closes her eyes in embarrassment.

Darcy is seen taking a bath in a copper tub, where a servant pours water over him. Shaking water from his hair, Darcy relaxes against the bath's end. Meanwhile, Lizzie strolls through the estate grounds, pausing to smile at a proud gray and white Great Dane. As the dog dashes away, she joyfully pursues it. Darcy, freshly out of his bath and dressed in a robe provided by a servant, moves to the window where he observes Lizzie playfully wrestling a stick from the dog's mouth, intently watching her every move.

The atmosphere shifts as Mr. Hurst sleeps soundly in a chair, with Mrs. Hurst seated beside him.
892:
In the heat of the afternoon, a man wipes his perspiring forehead with a handkerchief before closing his book. Suddenly, Lizzie strides into the room with defiance, positioning herself nearer to her father. She then offers a wry smile to her hysterical mother. Meanwhile, outside, Lydia and Kitty set off on their journey, casting a glance back at their home.

As Charlotte approaches the house, she pauses momentarily, deep in thought. Inside, Mr. Collins is busy packing his belongings. He gives a courteous bow and is soon followed out by Charlotte. The scene shifts to a delicate hand meticulously working on a piece of floral embroidery. Lydia and Kitty, filled with excitement, rush back to their family home, Longbourn, bursting through the front door.

Jane gently places down her embroidery as Lizzie slumps wearily into an opposite chair. The housekeeper enters, delivering a letter to Jane before curtsying and exiting the room. Outside, workers are seen carrying trunks and boxes out of Netherfield.

Wrapped in cloaks and bonnets, Kitty, Lydia, and Lizzie navigate through the bustling town. Denny escorts Lydia, while Carter leads Kitty away, leaving Wickham to exchange hopeful smiles with Lizzie. She responds with a beaming smile, and they continue their stroll through the town together.

Later, Mrs. Bennet steps out of Longbourn, deeply engaged in conversation with Denny. As the three sisters trail behind their mother and the officers, Lizzie shares a smile with Wickham. He acknowledges Mrs. Bennet with a polite nod before he and the other officers depart. Just as the girls are about to re-enter the house, Lydia dashes after the officers, whispering something to Wickham before he strides off with Carter and Wickham.

Inside Longbourn, the drawing room sees tea things being cleared away, with Mr. Bennet, Mary, and Jane seated. Mrs. Bennet bustles in, prompting laughter from the girls. Mr. Bennet then exits the room. Upstairs, Jane washes her hands in a basin in her room, then dries them and sits at the top of the four-poster bed with Lizzie at the foot. Concerned, Lizzie moves to sit next to Jane, offering her a comforting smile.

A carriage, drawn by four white horses, arrives at Longbourn's drive. Mrs. Bennet rushes out, followed by Mr. Bennet and their daughters, to greet the portly gentleman Edward Gardiner and his wife stepping out of the carriage.

Charlotte Lucas enters the scene, followed by Jane. As they move through a crowded room, a girl with red hair watches them curiously. They walk past Lizzie, who is deep in conversation with Wickham. Nearby, Mrs. Bennet sits with Mrs. Phillips and Mrs. Gardiner. Lizzie, accompanied by Wickham, approaches them. Mrs. Bennet, after exchanging a glance with her sister, purses her lips and walks away haughtily. Taking Wickham's hand, Lizzie leads him to the dance floor, passing the girl with red hair who shyly smiles at Wickham.
895:
A balding undercover officer initiates contact by knocking on the cellblock door. Inside his cell, the notorious gang leader, Dillinger, leisurely flips through a magazine before glancing up. The officer ushers in Purvis, who sports a crisp suit, into the cellblock while other lawmen keep a keen watch from a side table. Dillinger, upon noticing Purvis, sets his magazine aside, rises, and saunters towards the bars of his cell. Both men scrutinize each other intensely; Dillinger tilts his head in curiosity, while Purvis maintains a calm gaze. The tension is palpable as other officers and agents observe intently. Dillinger's eyes scan the stoic G-man from head to toe, and he shakes his head, his brow furrowed. Purvis, with a furtive blink, cracks a faint smile. Dillinger straightens to his full height, offering a cocky smile while chewing gum. As Purvis prepares to depart, he pauses, turns to face Dillinger once more, his clean-shaven face outlined by sunlight. Dillinger watches Purvis from within his cell as both men walk away, hands tucked into their pockets. Purvis inspects Dillinger with barely a break in his stride before exiting with his agents, leaving the balding officer behind. Dillinger continues chewing his gum thoughtfully.

Meanwhile, a three-propeller plane with a curved, boxy underbelly and thick wings cruises the sky, its chevron-shaped windshield positioned behind the nose, and six windows serving as skylights over the cockpit. The plane later descends towards a rainy airfield. On board, Dillinger is jostled in his seat as the plane lands and taxis past distant hangars. Near one hangar, a man ignites a flare, raising it to signal a vast crowd. Two journalists capture the moment on movie cameras, one showing a police officer awaiting Dillinger's arrival. Additional journalists with flashbulb cameras and three lawmen armed with rifles are also present, the flare's light catching a gleam. The plane comes to a stop, and lawmen exit a nearby car as another flare is launched. Amidst whipping winds, two trench-coated lawmen escort the shackled Dillinger across the tarmac, his button-down shirt and open vest visible, his wet bangs hanging over his face. Flashbulbs pop as Dillinger, pushed forward by his armed escorts, stumbles toward a Sedan adorned with a sleek bird-winged hood ornament. A jerky handheld camera view shows a gunman joining Dillinger in the back seat. Two policemen stand on the running boards of the car as it begins to move, accompanied by officers on motorbikes. Inside, Dillinger slouches, his head bobbing, his gaze pensive and directed downward, as passing lights reflect off the car's polished black hood.
898:
As two individuals briefly glance at a parked car, they quickly return to their discussion. Inside the vehicle, a large escapee in the backseat fixates on a red traffic light, his chest heaving with anticipation. Nearby, Dillinger, his head slightly bowed, moistens his lips nervously before subtly reaching for a gun tucked into his waistband. As soon as the traffic light turns green, Dillinger shifts the car into gear and navigates it onto a new street, occasionally checking his surroundings by glancing over his shoulder. The escapee, now alert, also looks back. With a sly smirk, Dillinger shifts gears again, propelling the Ford away from the town as Youngblood vigilantly monitors their rear through the back windshield. The car soon cruises alongside a serene field.

Dillinger shares a light-hearted moment, shaking his head at a bewildered mechanic who mimics the gesture. Simultaneously, during an interview elsewhere, Hoover listens attentively to the broadcast, momentarily pinching the bridge of his nose in concentration.

In the privacy of her apartment, Billie sits anxiously in a chair, her hands fidgeting. Overcome by urgency, she rushes to the telephone, leaning against a wall as she presses the receiver to her ear. At the telephone exchange, Baum listens intently to the conversation. Billie, overwhelmed by despondency, clutches the phone, her eyes lowering in sad resignation. In a tender moment, Dillinger, standing in a phone booth, wears a faint smile. Billie, deeply affected, removes the receiver from her ear and holds it to her neck, resting her chin on her knuckles.

Outside Billie's apartment, two men discreetly watch from a car hidden beneath a bridge. Later, Purvis sits in a car outside the same apartment, where Baum joins him, handing over a file containing a transcript of Dillinger's recent call to Billie. Behind them, an el train smoothly crosses a bridge, its interior lights illuminating the night.

In another scene, a tan car stops, and Dillinger and Red step out. As Dillinger proceeds down an icy walkway around a corner, Sport emerges from a nearby safe house. Red positions himself on the car's side, gun raised, while Marty appears from the house behind Sport. Dillinger, assessing the situation, narrows his eyes and tilts his head before drawing his machinegun. Inside the safe house, a man stands by the doorway, ready with his weapon, while outside, Red keeps his gun trained on the house.

Later, Dillinger and Red forcefully enter a cigar shop, where Red quickly seizes two customers. Behind one of the counters, Gilbert stands, receiving a stern look from Dillinger. Gilbert then leads them upstairs to a dimly lit room filled with chalkboard-covered walls and rows of men busily talking on telephones. Overhead, small green-lampshaded lights hang next to clusters of dangling phone wires. D'Andrea, perched on the corner of a desk, exchanges a glance with Gilbert. A blonde man inside the room signals for Dillinger to raise his arms, to which Dillinger complies by lifting his hands.
899:
As tension escalates, Dillinger seizes the blonde man in a chokehold, menacingly pointing a gun at Gilbert. Nearby, D'Andrea observes Gilbert, whose hand hovers over his own firearm. D'Andrea then shifts his attention to Dillinger and Red. In a swift move, Dillinger releases the blonde man with a toss and secures his weapon back into its holster. Thoughtfully knitting his brows, Dillinger locks eyes with D'Andrea, who responds with a nonchalant shrug. A scowl forms on Dillinger's face as he glares at D'Andrea. The mustached gangster inches closer while Dillinger, tilting his head and narrowing his eyes, again meets D'Andrea's gaze before turning away. Eventually, Dillinger and Red make their exit.

Elsewhere, Hoover and Purvis proceed down a corridor. Outside, Hoover parts from Purvis to greet a group of well-dressed boys lined up, engaging them with handshakes. Hoover then faces the media. Simultaneously, in a cinema, these events are broadcasted on a newsreel. Here, Dillinger is seen conversing with a rugged gangster before nodding to Shouse. As Dillinger's image flashes on screen, he discreetly shields his face. Shouse attempts to stand, but Red forcefully pulls him back down. Nervously, Homer averts his gaze. Dillinger, visibly worried and with his face tilted downward, is bathed in light as the overhead fixture turns on, illuminating the audience members. The crowd briefly looks to the right, then refocuses forward as the lights dim and a new film begins. Nearby, Tommy engages Dillinger, who rubs his lips contemplatively before nodding. Exchanging a look with Red, they stand up, collecting their coats. A few rows in front, Homer dons his hat and steps into the aisle behind them. As they leave the theater, Red draws near to Dillinger.

In a bustling town square, people wander amid a stiff wind that ripples the awnings of nearby stores. On the opposite side, a policeman arrives on a motorcycle. Inside a bank, Baby Face, standing on a table, shoots through a window towards the officer and then fires at the ceiling. Outside, Homer seizes a man, using him as a hostage. Within the bank, Dillinger and Tommy share a look of exasperation. From a vault, Dillinger tosses a bag to Tommy and guides the bank president by the shoulder, soon joined by a woman. The gangsters use hostages as shields while exiting the bank, passing Homer who stands guard by their car with his hostage. Baby Face unleashes a barrage of gunfire into the square, causing two men to dive for cover. From a window across the street, a man takes aim with a gun. Reacting swiftly, Dillinger lurches forward, eyes wide, and drops to a seated position, his weapon still raised. He then spots Tommy, who lies fatally wounded in a pool of blood on the ground.
902:
In the midst of a violent confrontation, a man with two bullet holes in his head slumps, lifeless, in a chair. Stunned, Purvis opens a rear door and witnesses the chaotic clash between the G-men and gangsters. Amidst the skirmish, Homer dashes across the barroom to a distant window, while John hurries down the stairs, clutching two Tommy guns. He hands one to Baby Face, and together they position themselves at the barroom windows. Suddenly, liquor bottles on the barroom wall shatter explosively.

Upstairs, Red and Johnny take cover from the shattered windows before resuming their attack. Agent Winstead fires his shots, causing chips to fly from the wall above a guest room mirror. From behind a disabled car, Purvis unleashes a barrage, peppering the plaster walls of Dillinger's room. We find ourselves crouching alongside the gangsters in the second-story guest room, our view shifting jerkily from right to Dillinger. Outside, FBI gunfire riddles a balcony, and through an adjacent window, a gangster can be seen taking aim. The G-men continue their assault, and Agent Rice is shot in the leg.

Amidst the chaos, Red provides covering fire, enabling Dillinger to rush into a neighboring guest room and smash a window with his gun. Together, Dillinger and Red make their escape onto a rooftop and leap down into a dark yard on the other side of the launch. Back in the barroom, a jerky close-up follows Baby Face as he backs up to a side door. Outside, he emerges and opens fire toward the car. His shots kick up clouds of dirt, but Purvis responds, firing through the dust, his bullets splintering the door. Inside, Baby Face dashes past Homer and leaps through a bay window, escaping as Agent Pleg spots him fleeing.

Purvis locks eyes with Baum, who then sets off. As Purvis shoots at the side door, Homer returns fire. Baum races past Agents Clegg and Madala in pursuit of the fugitive. Meanwhile, Dillinger and Red continue their escape through the woods, unnoticed by Winstead, who spots them. Winstead and his partner set out in pursuit, following the duo as they race along a forested hillside. Red, carrying a cloth sack, stays close behind Dillinger as they hurry past a narrowed outcropping. Winstead and Hurt appear on the trail, and as Dillinger and Red pass a misty overlook, the agents reach a stand of twin trees and split up, with Hurt taking to higher ground while Winstead advances on the trail. Through the leafy canopy, the criminals can be seen scurrying away.

Winstead tosses his hat aside, sights Dillinger, and fires. Dillinger retaliates, but as Winstead rolls to avoid the gunfire, Dillinger's weapon runs dry. Winstead kneels and resumes firing, forcing Red and Dillinger to take cover behind trees. Winstead's shots strike the trunk shielding Dillinger, who calmly reloads, his breath misting in the cold, night air before he leans out and returns fire.
903:
Dillinger scans the hillside, finding no trace of anyone. Meanwhile, Red cautiously peers over Dillinger's shoulder from his vantage point in a tree. Dillinger, feeling the tension ease, lowers his weapon. The two men then set off together.

Hidden behind a tree, Winstead remains low, observing their departure. In a dramatic slow-motion scene, the criminals sprint along a misty overlook with Red in the lead. Suddenly, Agent Hurt opens fire from a higher position on the hill. Red is hit and falls, but Dillinger quickly helps him to his feet, and they continue their escape. Winstead, not far behind, resumes tracking them.

Dillinger confronts an unsuspecting man outside a cabin. Later, Red, wounded and clutching his side, is assisted into a stolen car by Dillinger, who opens the door for him. Meanwhile, Baby Face Nelson reaches an unpaved road. Baum, approaching in a vehicle, peers intently over the steering wheel. As the car's headlights grow brighter, Baby Face turns his back to it, casually waving a hand while stepping backward and keeping his Tommy gun concealed under his coat. Baum stops the car and exits from the passenger side, only to be immediately thrown down by Baby Face. The fugitive then tosses Baum's Tommy gun onto the front seat, takes the driver's seat, and drives off.

Purvis, running through the forest, soon comes upon the scene where his partner Baum lies fallen. He removes his hat and kneels beside his dying colleague, watching as the car carrying Baby Face drives steadily away. Purvis then moves out in pursuit, with Agent Madala following but pausing upon spotting Baum's body.

On the dirt road, Purvis takes aim at an approaching car, holding his handgun loosely and raising a hand in signal—it's Cowley's team. Cowley executes a sharp 180-degree turn, and Purvis positions himself on the running board of their vehicle, armed with a Tommy gun.

Baby Face encounters Homer and Shouse, who are aiming their guns at a Ford. As Cowley's car takes a tight turn, Purvis, scowling into the night, continues the chase around another curve. Their headlights briefly illuminate a dip in the road and then the stolen Ford climbing a rise ahead. Purvis opens fire, and Homer responds in kind. Baby Face swerves to dodge the incoming bullets. From Cowley's car, now closing the gap, Purvis continues shooting relentlessly. Homer reloads during a brief respite, while a curve in the road gives Purvis a better angle, allowing him to hit the Ford's hood. The Ford veers off into a field, rolling over twice before coming to rest on its tires. Inside, Shouse's lifeless face presses against the cracked windshield.

Homer abandons Baby Face, who is trapped behind the jammed front door. With a forceful kick, Baby Face manages to free himself. Purvis arrives and unleashes a barrage of bullets at Homer, whose chest erupts in red bursts as he falls. Attempting to escape, Baby Face shoots and hits Cowley. Purvis takes aim with his pistol, but Agent Madala is quicker, firing a shotgun at Baby Face. Purvis then follows up with his own shots. The paunchy gangster collapses. Baby Face, half-recovering, struggles to his knees and fires his Tommy gun one last time.
915:
Alvin nods in agreement and walks away. Pete and Homer, exuding confidence, swagger off. Dillinger leans in close to Red, engaging him in conversation. Meanwhile, Red's attention is drawn to a brunette in a red dress as she makes her way back to her table. Anna guides a young woman over to Red. As Red and Veronica stroll away, Anna follows them, leaving Dillinger by himself. Dillinger fixates on the brunette in the red dress, who responds with laughter and a radiant smile. The gang leader, sipping his drink, rises from his seat, his gaze firmly fixed on the exotic woman. He moves decisively through the crowd, stops right behind her, and leans onto her chair. She looks up at him, and he shakes his head in stunned disbelief. Her bright red lips curve into a coy smile. She exchanges a grin with the other women at her table before leaving with Dillinger, who cautiously locks eyes with her before looking away.

Billie leads the way to the dance floor, where Dillinger takes her hand while she places her other hand on his shoulder. They sway together, Billie smiling softly. Dillinger gazes off shyly but soon finds himself captivated by her lovely face. Billie stares back with defiance, her dark eyes probing his as they move to the music. A faint smile graces her lips, and Dillinger, summoning a breath, raises his eyebrows. Her smile widens.

On stage, the songstress surveys the crowded dance floor. Later, Billie and Dillinger walk through the club's foyer, with Billie wrapping her crimson jacket tightly around her body. Stepping outside, she winces against the wind. Dillinger turns her to face him and drapes his overcoat over her shoulders. She gives a bashful grin and continues down the sidewalk, wrapped in his jacket and arm.

In an elegant restaurant, Billie uneasily surveys her surroundings before her eyes meet Dillinger's. She smiles but then notices a snobbish female diner who scrutinizes her, causing Billie's smile to briefly falter. Dillinger flashes an amused smile and leans back. He then diverts his attention to another table. Their eyes lock once again, and under Billie's thick, dark eyelashes and graceful nose, a faint smile plays on her lips. Dillinger stands to help her up, holding her chair before guiding her out of the restaurant with a gentle hand on her back. They arrive at the coat check counter.

At a bar, a stocky man with slicked-back hair notices them. Dillinger glances at the man over his shoulder and leans toward Billie before stepping away. Billie, irritated, shifts her gaze, glares at him, and forcefully pulls on her coat before storming out. The two men exchange a handshake.

Nitti, a lean man with dark, slick hair and a handlebar mustache, slouches as he eats. A short, husky man with olive skin and a toothbrush mustache approaches Dillinger. They shake hands before D'Andrea leaves.
916:
Dillinger exchanges glances with Gilbert before forcefully pushing through a revolving door. Emerging outside, he encounters only a well-dressed couple and a uniformed doorman. With a frown, the gang leader surveys the sidewalk and then turns to confront the doorman. His expression remains one of dissatisfaction.

The scene shifts to a gleaming hood ornament of an archer on Purvis' Pierce Arrow. Inside an FBI field office, a chubby agent displays a jacket. Purvis, pacing, then turns to address his gathered task force. He briefly faces a secretary before gazing out a window at a neighboring high rise, then turns back to his men. One of the agents momentarily lowers his eyes. In a telephone exchange with Baum, Purvis plays a 78 record as night falls.

Dillinger strides past a brightly lit city park and later marches through a crowded lobby with vaulted arches. He locates Billie working behind a hatcheck counter. As a male guest extends his coat towards Billie, she notices Dillinger. Swiftly, Dillinger smacks the back of the bystander's head, causing the man to double over. With deft motion, the crime boss flips open the counter's pass-through, steps into Billie's work area, and forcefully grabs the man's wrist, yanking it over the counter. He then snatches the man's claim ticket, retrieves his coat, and tosses it back at its owner while Billie watches. Dillinger then retrieves Billie's coat, holding it open for her. With a coy smirk, she steps from behind the counter, her gaze briefly meeting a staring co-worker's, and slips into the coat.

In an apartment, a hand drops a rabbit's foot key chain beside a tabletop sculpture of two racing greyhounds. Dillinger leads Billie down a hall into a lavish living room. As she surveys the space, he positions a chair near a sofa and looks at her. Billie joins him, removing her coat. Dillinger places a plain cardboard box on the coffee table. Billie, complying, looks around with a subtle smile. Behind her, Red appears in his undershirt, leaning through an open interior window. He collects a couple of glasses from a counter and then casually walks off with two women. Sitting across from Billie, Dillinger places his hand on the large box, which she eyes coolly. He smiles subtly and shifts boyishly in his seat. Billie lifts the lid to reveal forest green tissue paper covering the contents. Gently unfolding the layers, she discovers a camel-haired coat with a thick fur collar. Lifting the gift from its box, she stares at it, swallows, and then raises her tender gaze to meet Dillinger's. Her full lips curl into a smile, and the crime boss grins back. They lock eyes, filled with warmth.

Later, on a bed, they passionately kiss each other. Silhouetted against a window, Billie leans over the reclined Dillinger, her bobbed hair brushing his brow.
919:
The movie opens with the iconic Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer logo, where a lion's head emerges from a crest encircled by a film garland. This is followed by a dramatic scene where light flares intensely from a torch held by a robed woman standing on a pedestal against a backdrop of towering clouds.

The action shifts to a breathtaking landscape where towering crags emerge majestically from a shimmering sea. The pace quickens as two sleek cars race through a coastal tunnel. The camera focuses on a shiny wheel spinning rapidly and the intense gaze of a driver focused on the road ahead.

Suddenly, a gun is snatched, and the driver quickly glances into his rearview mirror. He accelerates his gleaming Aston Martin past a line of traffic, skillfully evading pursuers who begin shooting. Bullet holes riddle the Aston's windows, escalating the tension. A truck's tire bursts and it swerves directly into the path of the Aston Martin, sliding dangerously along the wall. James Bond, the determined driver of the Aston, brakes sharply to avoid collision.

A piece of metal from the front of the truck strikes the car's door, causing it to lock with the truck. Bond brakes again, forcefully, which tears the door off his Aston, sending it spinning chaotically down the road. Regaining control, Bond speeds away. The road ahead is blocked in both lanes, and as one vehicle barrels toward him, Bond expertly maneuvers into a narrow gap. His pursuers, less fortunate, crash head-on into the truck.

Undeterred, another Alfa Romeo continues the chase. As Bond approaches a traffic jam, he swerves left into another tunnel, narrowly escaping the pursuers' sight. The chase leads them toward a quarry, with both the Aston Martin and the pursuing black Alfa Romeo speeding over a bridge, observed by police in a Land Rover with flashing blue lights.

Exiting the tunnel and rounding a corner, Bond skids to avoid the police Land Rover blocking his path. He speeds through the dusty quarry, the Alfa still in hot pursuit. Bond navigates around tracked excavators and down a bumpy track facing a newly carved quarry face. The police open fire but are met with gunfire from the Alfa. The Land Rover crashes into a building and off a cliff.

Amidst the chaos, Bond calmly shifts gears. His eyes widen in shock as the Land Rover reappears, bouncing dangerously close on the track ahead. A gunman from the Alfa leans out, firing as Bond ducks to avoid the shattering glass and bullets. The Alfa pulls alongside, and both cars scrape each other, dust flying from their paintwork. Suddenly, a bulldozer looms in their path, and both vehicles swerve around it.

In a decisive move, Bond grabs a machine gun. The Alfa, unable to keep up, hurtles off a precipice. Bond drives his now dusty and battered Aston Martin into a medieval Italian town, navigating through its narrow streets surrounded by stone buildings. The chase concludes under the shadow of a lofty campanile bell tower that stands prominently over the town's huddled structures.
923:
As the wooden gates swing open, James Bond proceeds down a long, straight brick tunnel. He pauses, exits his vehicle, and opens the boot to reveal a man blinking up at him. In a dramatic moment, Bond is spotlighted in a pool of light, raising his pistol and firing a bullet in super slow motion, surrounded by a burst of smoke. The bullet travels, creating a smoky trail over sand dunes, while light envelops the sun. A shadowy Bond aims his weapon as his silhouette crosses the sandy landscape.

A red dot moves laterally across the scene. Amidst this, a naked woman appears silhouetted by the sand, lying over the dunes in the dim light. Bond stands in the low light as fine sands flow like liquid around him, from which a woman's naked body emerges. Bond turns, gun in hand, as a gloom-shaped hood of lights surrounds the scene. The naked woman stands in silhouette as Bond falls into billowing sand. Sand and stars swirl in the grim light, the grid flexing and moving against the starry darkness.

A crowd of naked women poses in silhouette around the glaring sun, forming circles that animate into a flickering blur before dissolving and floating through space. Sand swirls in the light as high-heels pose, slowly turning. Bond falls towards the expanding crowd of people in the eye of the scene. Sand engulfs a pistol as Bond falls in slow motion onto the sandy ground. He raises his pistol and fires in super slow-motion, the bullet spinning slowly as it flies. A red dot travels sideways again as the sun flares behind a pile of naked women. The bullet lands in an explosion of sand.

A red and yellow checked flag billows in the breeze as a procession of people in bright costumes parades around a square, watched by huge crowds. Bond unceremoniously dumps the man from the boot onto a chair in a cellar, observed by M and another agent. Bond takes a gulp of whiskey as near-tired horsemen enter the square, which is laid out as a racetrack. A chair scrapes across a stone floor as Bond sits next to Mr. White, joined by M.

Tension escalates as Mitchell drops one agent, and as M falls, the horse race starts. Bond leaps onto the man, seizing the gun. The prisoner is hit and falls. Bond disarms Mitchell, kicking the gun away, only to be booted to the ground himself. Mitchell grabs the gun and flees. The fast and furious Palio horse race thunders around Siena's main square. Mitchell races down spiral stairs, splashing into water at the base of a tower, and dives through an iron gate. Ignoring the stairs, Bond takes a flying leap in pursuit. In the race, a rider falls. Bond chases his man down a watery tunnel, but his path is barred by a gate.
924:
The thrilling chase begins when the protagonist suddenly shifts his path, diving into an intense underground pursuit that mirrors the fervor of the race happening above ground. Amid this chaos, Mitchell crashes through structural supports, triggering the roof to begin collapsing onto Bond. As the race concludes, fireworks burst into the sky, celebrating the winner, while the track becomes overrun by invaders. Enthusiastic cheers fill the air, accompanied by tears and jubilation, as Bond emerges dramatically from a manhole.

Pushing through the dense crowd, Mitchell forcefully makes his way forward, with Bond hot on his trail. In a desperate move, Mitchell shoots at Bond, tragically striking a woman in the crowd before clambering over a barrier and onto the racetrack. Bond, undeterred, sprints after him. Their chase leads them through a courtyard, through a door, and up the stairs.

In his haste, Mitchell collides with an elderly woman, who is hoisting a crate of fruit with a rope. The impact causes the crate to crash to the ground. Undaunted, Mitchell leaps across the tiled rooftops, with Bond in relentless pursuit. Mitchell attempts a daring jump between buildings, followed closely by Bond. As a round strikes near Bond, causing a brief pause, he leaps, slides down the tiles, and jumps again, landing heavily on a ledge, all while trying to keep Mitchell in sight, who is now on a higher roof across from him.

Determined, Bond leaps down onto a balcony, then to another, using the metal railings to hoist himself up. Bursting into a room, he traverses through an apartment, spotting Mitchell climbing onto another nearby roof. Bond then jumps from a window onto a bus roof, quickly regaining his footing to leap to another ledge and slide down a drainpipe, his face set in grim determination as he finds himself on the same roof as Mitchell.

The chase leads them to an empty tower, where Mitchell reaches the top and leaps for a flight of steps, recently dislodged. Bond follows, firing at the fleeing double agent, who disappears from sight. Inside the tower, Bond pulls on bell ropes before ascending to the belfry, his gun at the ready. Suddenly, Mitchell launches an attack from a perch outside the tower. In the ensuing struggle, Bond grabs Mitchell's arm and strikes him with an elbow, resulting in both men crashing through a glass roof onto a scaffold below. Bond's gun falls to the floor far beneath them.

Hanging by one hand, Bond tries to destabilize the scaffolding beneath Mitchell, who falls but manages to grab onto a rope. The swinging rope dislodges a pane of glass, which shatters, sending sharp shards cascading down. Simultaneously, the rope gantry swings, causing a crate of bricks at the other end to fall. Both men grab ropes, ending up facing each other, dangling at opposite ends of a steel gantry. Exchanging blows, they smash into a scaffold, which topples, pulling on the rope and hauling them back into the glass roof. Mitchell falls onto the scaffold, while Bond, with his leg caught in a rope, plummets but is halted just before hitting the ground near his fallen gun.
925:
The gantry rotates, pulling James Bond away from a gun and dislodging Mitchell from the scaffold. Mitchell lands on a nearby scaffold tower while Bond yanks at the rope entwined around his leg. Mitchell then scrambles up to grab a gun positioned on the scaffold, while Bond reaches for another gun on the ground. Both men quickly snatch up their respective weapons, and Bond promptly fires.

As the Town Square's crowds begin to scatter, a police car navigates through the throng. Covered in dust, Bond strides confidently through the dispersing crowds toward a wooden gate within a tunnel. In the cellar, blood stains the floor, but the prisoner, Mr. White, has vanished. Bond surveys the scene with a dispassionate gaze. Rain starts to fall.

A black Range Rover pulls up to a high-rise apartment block. From one of its balconies, M gazes outward. Bond steps out of the Range Rover and enters the building through its glass door. Ignoring the stoic guard, he proceeds into an apartment, passing by masked forensic officers to join M on the balcony. A technical expert opens a door for M, prompting Bond to narrow his eyes in scrutiny.

Wearing sunglasses, Bond rides in the back of a taxi down a dusty street. He exits the taxi across from the faded sign and entrance of the Hotel Dessalines. Dressed in a dark polo shirt and light trousers, he enters the building and navigates the drab-tiled lobby, which is cluttered with washing lines. He proceeds down plain concrete corridors to a door, positioning himself to one side. Using a tool, he picks the lock and cautiously enters, peering around into a plainly furnished, empty living room. After closing the door, Bond moves further into the apartment.

Suddenly, a switch-blade snaps open, and a man bursts through glass doors, swinging the blade erratically. Bond forcefully throws him through the glass into the bedroom. Recovering, the man swings the blade again, but Bond counters with a phone. As the man falls, he grabs a pair of scissors.
